80.23(B)(3) Investigation. Whenever any work for which a permit is required by this code has been commenced without first obtaining said permit, a special investigation shall be made before a permit may be issued for such work. 
80.23(B)(4) Fee. An investigation fee, in addition to the permit fee, shall be collected whether or not a permit is then or subsequently issued. The investigation fee shall be equal to the amount of the permit fee required by this code. The payment of such investigation fee shall not exempt any person from compliance with all other provisions of this code nor from any penalty prescribed by law. 
(7)  80.25 (C), Notification , is deleted in its entirety. 
(8)  80.27 Inspector's Qualifications , is amended by deleting said section in its entirety and substituting the following therefor: 80.27 Inspector's qualifications. 
(A)  The office of the electrical inspector, within the inspection services division of the department of community development of the city, is hereby created, and such inspector is hereby authorized, directed and empowered to inspect any and all buildings, tents and other structures, public and private, and, as provided in this article, to condemn and order removed or remodeled and put into proper and safe condition for the prevention of fire and for safety to life and property, all electrical equipment installations and connections of electrical current for light, heat and power purposes, and to control the disposition and arrangement of such equipment so that persons and property shall not be in danger therefrom. 
(B)  The electrical inspector shall be appointed by the director of community development, after recommendation of the building official, and shall be directly responsible to the building official. 
(C)  The appointee shall be qualified as an electrical inspector, as determined by any state requirements, the job classification and the civil service commission. 
(9)  New section 80.28, Licensing , is added as follows: 
(A)  Licenses required. 
(1)  Electrical licenses shall be governed by Iowa Code ch. 103. 
(2)  All electrical contractors not currently registered with the city shall pay a registration fee as set by the city council. 
(3)  Any electrical license issued by the city, as allowed by state law, shall be required to pay a fee as set by city council annually. 
(10)  80.29, Liability for Damages , is amended by adding the word "city," in the blank. 
(11)  80.35, Effective date , is deleted in its entirety. 
(Ord. No. 2921, § 2, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 7-51. - Municipal infraction; penalty; abatement of violations. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article or the code adopted by this article, or who performs any work on any electrical systems or equipment within the city contrary to the provisions of this article or the code adopted by this article, or who fails to perform any act or duty required by this article or the code adopted by this article, shall be deemed to have committed a municipal infraction. Upon entry of a judgment by a court for such municipal infraction, the person shall be subject to a civil penalty as provided in section 1-9(a). Such judgment may also include an order of court to abate or correct the violation or violations, as authorized by section 1-8 and by Iowa Code § 364.22. 
(Code 2017, § 7-51; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Sec. 7-52. - Moved buildings. 
(a)  Residential moved buildings shall be brought into compliance with the electrical requirements of new residential-type buildings. Exception: Parts of an electrical system which were not damaged and had been installed in compliance with the electrical code which was in effect at the time of installation may be retained in said electrical systems. 
(b)  Electrical systems in any other moved buildings shall be brought into compliance with the provisions of this Code the same as for new construction. 
(c)  The permanent service connection shall not be made by the power company until the electrical system is completely installed and is approved by the inspector. 
(d)  The existing service on the moved building shall not be connected to the electrical power source unless specifically approved by an inspector. 
(Code 2017, § 7-53; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Sec. 7-53. - Unlawful connections. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection from a supply of electricity to any electric equipment that has been installed or which has been disconnected or ordered to be disconnected by the electrical inspector, until re-inspected and approved by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 2017, § 7-54; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Sec. 7-54. - Inspection of wiring required prior to installation of meter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to set a meter for electric purposes to any building or premises, wiring of which has not been inspected and approved by the electrical inspector. A violation of this section will cause the electrical inspector to give written notice and immediately cause the removal of such conditions and the discontinuance of such current. 
(Code 2017, § 7-55; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Sec. 7-55. - Alteration of identification or rating markings. 
    It shall be unlawful to cover, remove, alter, change or deface the maker's name or identification mark or any of the rating markings on electrical equipment. 
(Code 2017, § 7-56; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Sec. 7-56. - Supervision by building official. 
    The electrical inspector shall work fully under the supervision and jurisdiction of the building official and take all orders and perform any duties or services that may be designated by the building official pertaining to electrical inspections or other related duties. 
(Code 2017, § 7-57; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Sec. 7-57. - Conflict of interest. 
    It shall be unlawful for the electrical inspector or assistant electrical inspectors to engage in the business of the sales, installation or maintenance of electrical equipment, either directly or indirectly, and they shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business in the city, at any time, while holding the office provided for in this article. 
(Code 2017, § 7-58; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
Secs. 7-58-7-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAS REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-88. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the natural gas code of the city. 
(Code 2017, § 7-191; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-89. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    AGA means American Gas Association. 
    Approved , as to materials, workmanship and types of construction, means approval by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel, as the result of investigation, inspections or tests conducted by the inspector, or by reason of accepted principles or tests by nationally recognized authorities. 
    Category I vented appliance means an appliance that operates with a nonpositive vent static pressure and with a vent gas temperature that avoids excessive condensate production in the vent. 
    Combustible material means walls, floors, ceilings, shelves or other parts of a building constructed of wood, composition or paper, including walls constructed of wooden studding, lath and plaster. 
    CSAus means Canadian Standards Association; United States (replaces AGA logo and symbols). 
    Flue liner means a liner to be installed in a masonry chimney used to vent natural gas burning equipment up to 350,000 British thermal units per hour. 
    GAMA means Gas Appliance Manufacturer's Association. 
    Gas inspector means the manager or assistant manager of the gas operations department of the Cedar Falls Utilities. 
    Gas appliance means a fixture or apparatus manufactured and designed to use natural gas as a fuel. 
    Gas piping means any run of pipe or fittings that is used to convey natural gas, installed on any premises or in any building, but shall not include any portion of the service piping. 
    Gas piping system means any arrangement of gas piping supplied by one meter. 
    House piping means that portion of the gas piping leading from the outlet side of the gas meter, and any gas piping connected to and extending beyond that portion of the system. 
    IAS means International Approval Services (formerly AGA). 
    Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, that is eight-body feet or more in width or 40-body feet or more in length in the traveling mode or, when erected on site, is 320 cubic feet or more, which is built on a chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, including the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein. 
    Minor repairs means adjustment of appliances, replacement of parts, repairing leaks and similar work. 
    NFPA means National Fire Protection Association. 
    Protected combustible material means combustible material protected with a metal shield extending over an area exposed to the effects of heat from a gas appliance, so formed that an air space of not less than one inch is maintained between such shield and the combustible materials. In lieu of such air space, fireproof material not less than one-quarter inch in thickness or other approved equally effective insulating material may be used between such metal shield and any combustible material. 
    Service piping means the piping between the street gas main and the gas meter. 
    Type B vent means a vent for venting listed gas appliances with draft hoods and other category I gas appliances listed for use with type B gas vents. 
    Vent connection means a pipe designed to convey the products of combustion from a gas appliance to a flue liner. 
(Code 2017, § 7-192; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-90. - Conflicting provisions; subjects not covered by article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be applicable where federal or state laws or rules and regulations thereof preempt any provision. Subjects not regulated by this article or interpretation of this article should be referred to National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 54, National Fuel Gas Code current edition. 
(Code 2017, § 7-193; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-91. - Administration of article. 
(a)  The gas inspector shall administer this article. 
(b)  HUD approved manufactured homes are under federal jurisdiction and exempt from portions of this article. 
(Code 2017, § 7-194; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-92. - Gas inspector. 
(a)  The general manager of utilities shall appoint a qualified gas inspector, who shall be confirmed by the utility board of trustees. 
(b)  The inspector shall hold office during the pleasure of the utilities board and until a successor is appointed by the general manager and is confirmed by the utilities board of trustees. 
(c)  The inspector will be and will constitute the authority for administration of this article. 
(d)  The inspector or utility personnel authorized by the inspector shall inspect and supervise all work done or authorized to be done under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2017, § 7-195; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-93. - Bond; guarantee of service. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except as otherwise provided in this article, to install, alter or repair any gas piping, gas vent, or gas burning appliances until the person has first obtained a surety bond in the amount of $1,000.00, which must be approved by the inspector and held on file in the gas operations department at the Cedar Falls Utilities. 
(b)  The bond shall be accompanied by a guarantee of future 24-hour on call service on all equipment to be installed. This guarantee shall be limited to a period of two years from the date of installation of such equipment. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the person to keep a current bond on file in the gas operations department at the Cedar Falls Utilities. If the bond expires, no further installation permits shall be issued to the individual or company until a valid bond is issued and filed as provided herein. 
(Code 2017, § 7-196; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-94. - General inspections. 
(a)  Upon completion of the installation of any gas piping or gas appliance, and prior to the use thereof, the permit holder shall notify the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel that such piping or appliances are ready for inspection. 
(b)  The inspections shall be made by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel, who shall either approve that portion of the work as completed, or shall notify the permit holder wherein the work fails to comply with this article. The permit holder must notify the utilities when all work is completed for a final inspection. 
(Code 2017, § 7-197; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-95. - Authority to disconnect appliances or piping. 
    The gas inspector and authorized utility personnel are hereby authorized to disconnect any gas appliance or gas piping which shall be found not to conform to the requirements of this article; which may be found defective and in such condition as to endanger life or property; or which was not authorized by the utilities. Where such disconnection has been made, a notice shall be attached to such appliance or gas piping, which shall state that the appliance or piping has been disconnected, together with the reasons. Such notice shall not be removed, nor shall the appliance or gas piping be reconnected, until authorized by the inspector. (Also see section 7-109(c).) 
(Code 2017, § 7-198; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-96. - Certificate of inspection; smoke tests. 
(a)  No gas-fired equipment shall be placed in permanent operation without prior inspection and a certificate of inspection issued by authorized utility personnel. A white tag signifies compliance. 
(b)  Whenever a smoke test or other approved testing method is required, the test shall be performed in the presence of authorized utility personnel. 
(c)  If the final piping inspection shows the piping has been found to comply with the provisions of this article, a certificate of inspection shall be issued. A white tag signifies compliance. 
(d)  If the inspection of the gas-fired equipment shows that it complies with the provisions of this article, a certificate of inspection shall be issued. A white tag signifies compliance. 
(Code 2017, § 7-199; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-97. - Connecting or turning on service. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except an authorized utility employee, to turn on or reconnect gas service or a meter in or on any premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to turn on or connect gas on or in any premises unless all outlets are properly and securely connected to appliances or capped or plugged. 
(Code 2017, § 7-200; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-98. - Gas piping. 
(a)  All gas piping must be black steel, galvanized pipe or corrugated stainless steel tubing and fittings. Sizing of gas lines must be adequate to deliver gas supply to all appliances connected to piping without creating a pressure drop that will prevent the appliances from operating at their intended efficiency. 
(b)  All such pipe shall either be new or shall previously been used for no other purpose than conveying gas, and shall be clear and free from cutting burrs and defects in structure or threading and shall be thoroughly brushed and scale blown. 
(c)  Gas piping should be run exposed wherever possible. Where gas piping is installed in concealed areas such as walls, ceilings, etc., where corrosion is no problem, welded standard pipe, corrugated stainless steel tubing and fittings or threaded fittings, all with the proper air test of ten pounds for 15 minutes, may be used. Authorized utility personnel must inspect the installation. 
(d)  When gas piping is buried in an exterior location, either wrapped or coated pipe welded and air tested, or polyethylene pipe authorized by the gas inspector must be used. In general, no gas piping should be installed under a cement floor or slab. If this becomes necessary, wrapped black steel pipe or polyethylene pipe laid inside a gas tight duct with the duct vented to the outside must be used. The installer must furnish all necessary equipment and gauges for air testing pipelines belonging to the customer. It will be permissible to use plastic piping approved for natural gas, for outside underground lines only. 
(e)  A shutoff valve must be provided in the pipeline ahead of each gas appliance installed, ahead of the union or appliance connector. The shutoff valve on a furnace must be installed outside the furnace cabinet where accessible. Exceptions must be approved by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel. Approved flexible appliance connectors may be used to connect portable appliances such as ranges, dryers, etc. Flexible connectors in commercial applications will be required to be double walled or approved for commercial applications. Standard residential connectors will not be allowed in commercial applications. 
(f)  Flexible connectors will not be allowed to pass through a wall, ceiling, floor or cabinet on movable appliances. Only one flexible connector per appliance will be allowed. 
(g)  A drip leg shall be required on furnaces and water heaters only. Manufactured homes are exempt from this rule. 
(h)  Copper or aluminum tubing shall not be used for gas lines or connections, except where it is part of the appliance design. 
(i)  Pipe compound or thread tape shall be used on all fittings and of a make recommended by an approved source from its manufacturer as being approved for both LP and natural gas. 
(j)  All gas piping carrying a gas pressure in excess of nine inches water column shall be welded and air tested. All gas piping over two inches in size shall be welded and air tested. The air test shall be no less than 150 percent the proposed working pressure, but not less than ten psig. The air test will be for 15 minutes without pressure drop. 
(k)  Threaded pipe and fittings may be tested with an air test instead of the usual soap bubble test on all joints. The test is ten pounds for 15 minutes. Cedar Falls Utilities personnel shall witness all air tests referenced in this article and reserve the right to require a longer time for any air tests based upon pipe size, length of the pipe runs and other conditions. 
(l)  Gas piping may be installed in concealed locations with no access in accordance with the following rule: When gas piping that is to be concealed is being installed; only elbows, tees, caps and couplings shall be used. 
(m)  Manufactured homes may be connected to the gas meter with solid iron pipe or a Dormont type outdoor flex connector approved for manufactured home use. 
(n)  Any natural gas piping going through brick, block or concrete walls must be sleeved with plastic pipe to protect from deterioration. 
(Code 2017, § 7-201; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-99. - Installation of used appliances. 
    Used gas appliances may be reinstalled when, in the opinion of the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel, such appliances may be used without danger to life or property. Used furnaces shall require a smoke test or equivalent test witnessed by authorized utility personnel prior to installation. 
(Code 2017, § 7-202; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-100. - Approval of appliances. 
    Gas appliances shall be CSAus approved or approved by an equivalent-testing laboratory. A rating plate shall be attached in such a manner as to be easily read. Where gas appliances are installed that have not been so approved they will be subject to the judgment of the gas inspector as to their fitness for use. Alteration or protection before their use may be required in order to meet the gas inspector's safety requirements. 
(Code 2017, § 7-203; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-101. - Water heaters. 
(a)  Water heaters shall not be installed in bathrooms or in rooms less than 600 cubic feet in size unless adequate air intake and ventilation is provided. All water heaters must be provided with a positive automatic shutoff valve that will not allow gas to pass through the main burner in the event of a pilot outage. All water heaters must be equipped with an approved automatic opening and closing temperature and pressure relief valve. All water heaters installed in a garage area shall be at least 18 inches from floor level to the burner. 
(b)  All water heaters must be vented, and the vent must be so installed, regardless of horizontal or vertical height or lengths, that all products of combustion are carried to the outside air. Where there is a flue liner from a furnace or a space heater, the water heater must be vented into this liner or into a separate flue or vent. Water heaters should not be vented into oil burner stacks. 
(c)  Water heaters installed in manufactured homes shall be marked "for manufactured home use." 
(Code 2017, § 7-204; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-102. - Space heating appliances. 
(a)  Gas warm air furnaces, boilers and unit heaters, or any type of space heater, shall be CSAus-approved or approved by an equivalent testing laboratory. Clearance from combustible materials shall be according to manufacturer's recommendations or as required by the gas utility. 
(b)  All heating equipment installed in a garage area shall be at least 18 inches from floor level to the burner. 
(c)  Minimum sheet metal clearance for gas fired hot air furnaces shall be as follows, or, if this is not possible, the furnace shall be satisfactorily insulated with fireproof material: 
(1)  Plenums on forced air furnaces with a maximum high limit setting up to 250 degrees Fahrenheit shall have a clearance of two inches from combustible material and a one-inch clearance on heat runs three feet out from the plenum. 
(2)  Gravity furnaces where a limit higher than 250 degrees Fahrenheit is maintained, shall have adequate clearance from combustible material or be so insulated that they will be considered by an authorized gas inspector to be safe. 
(3)  All gas-fired appliances requiring natural venting must have a draft diverter properly designed to the manufacturer's specifications. 
(d)  Where a space heater, furnace, conversion burner or any other gas fired appliance is installed in a confined area such as a utility room or similar area, an adequate supply of combustion air must be supplied from other than the living quarters area. An outside air opening one inch larger than the combined venting area of connected equipment will be deemed adequate. 
(e)  Any house built or remodeled after 1973 must have adequate combustion and dilution air to provide for the proper, safe operation of the natural gas furnace. Fresh air taken from outside or from a ventilated attic shall be installed, preferably into the cold air return, by the furnace installer. 
(f)  No circulating air supply inlet for blower type warm air furnaces shall be located where there is a possibility of reversing the venting, picking up fumes, objectionable odors or flammable vapors. 
(g)  Where exhaust fans are installed in a building that can cause the gas vents to reverse, downdraft or spill when the gas appliance is burning, the appliance must be shielded or protected or an induced draft fan must be installed so that it will function properly or more outside air must be introduced. 
(h)  All furnaces shall be provided with an approved electrical disconnect located within reach of the furnace. 
(Code 2017, § 7-205; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-103. - Operating instructions for appliances. 
(a)  Operating instructions for appliances are to be left on the job by the installer. 
(b)  Instructions furnished by the manufacturer, outlining procedures as follows, should be attached to or near the installation: 
(1)  Instructions for the proper manner of operating the main shutoff gas valve and pilot valve and the proper sequence for lighting. 
(2)  Instructions outlining the proper sequence for turning off gas burners and closing gas main and auxiliary valves. 
(Code 2017, § 7-206; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-104. - Venting. 
(a)  Forced draft or exhaust systems may only be installed in areas for which they have been designed by the manufacturer, or where conditions make it appropriate. 
(b)  All gas appliances shall be vented unless otherwise approved by an authorized utility inspector. Some exceptions are domestic ranges, gas and air torches and dryers. All gas venting should be provided with ample vertical height and a horizontal length as short as possible. 
(c)  Appliance air and/or fresh air must be installed at least ten feet from gas meter setups. Appliance exhaust should not be vented directly below windows or above gas meter setups. Manufacturer installation instructions will be used on exhaust installations. Exceptions to the provision set forth in this subsection must be approved in advance by the gas inspector. 
(Code 2017, § 7-207; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-105. - Chimneys. 
(a)  For heating equipment, flue liners must be used where total gas burning input is more than 50,000 or less than 350,000 Btu's per hour. 
(b)  Installation of new furnaces that no longer use the chimney going up through the house and leave only the water heater in the chimney must have a properly sized chimney to accommodate the water heater only, even if this requires a smaller liner to be installed in the existing chimney. 
(c)  The flue pipe should extend through the chimney wall to the inner face of the liner, but not beyond, and should be firmly cemented to masonry. The flue pipe should be sealed into the chimney liner or attached to the type B vent by use of a tee or elbow. 
(d)  Flue connections from two or more appliances should not enter opposing or adjacent sides of the chimney or type B vent at the same level. Flue pipes must never be connected into a fireplace chimney flue. 
(Code 2017, § 7-208; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-106. - Chimney flues. 
(a)  Where gas vents are used to discharge gases directly to the outside without the use of masonry chimneys, type B insulated vents may be used. The manufacturer's instructions for clearance from combustible materials and clearance plates must be used. 
(b)  A CSAus or equivalent testing laboratory approved draft hood must be used on all gas-fired appliances requiring venting, except incinerators, where a field control must be used as provided by the manufacturer. 
(c)  The draft hood, in all cases, must be located at a point level with or higher than the top of the highest flue passage in the appliance. In order to be able to develop full rating on some heating appliances, it will be necessary to install the draft hood as high as possible. This is true of revertible flue furnaces, where it is specifically recommended that the relief opening of the draft hood is at least one foot higher than the highest point of the flue passage. For conversion of revertible flue type appliances, it is recommended that a small opening or passage of not less than one inch pipe size be provided between the top of the highest point in the flue passage of the appliance and its vertical flue pipe. 
(d)  If there is a bypass, the bypass shall be opened slightly and locked in position. 
(e)  All draft hoods shall be installed in the position for which they were designed. In no case shall a draft hood be installed in a false ceiling or in a separate room from the heating system, or in any manner that will permit a difference in pressure between the draft hood relief opening and the combustion air supply. 
(Code 2017, § 7-209; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-107. - Installation of gas-fired equipment in sleeping quarters. 
(a)  Only properly vented space heaters may be installed in sleeping quarters. Ample fresh air intake or area must be available. 
(b)  All gas furnaces, space heaters or boilers, or any gas appliance where pressure fluctuation may interfere with its proper operation, must be equipped with a pressure regulator. All such appliances must also be equipped with an automatic pilot controlled safety shutoff that will shut the gas off to the main burner in the event of pilot failure. 
(Code 2017, § 7-210; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-108. - Approved flue liners. 
    Approved flue liners are as follows: vitrified steel pipe, stainless steel pipe, lap joint vitrified clay pipe, flexible stainless steel, type B liners or butt to butt tile. Use of the latter is limited to manufacturer's recommended use only. Type "B" vents shall be installed as close as possible to the appliance, to meet GAMA regulations. 
(Code 2017, § 7-211; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-109. - Starting up and checking out gas-fired equipment. 
(a)  All gas appliances shall be properly assembled and checked out by the installer. The appliance shall then be shut off and an authorized utility inspector notified for its checkout and inspection. 
(b)  All permits shall be taken out in advance of any installation and the authorized utility inspector shall be notified when the installation is completed. This applies to owners who do their own installing as well as to contractors. 
(c)  When the appliance installation or piping has passed the authorized utility inspector's inspection, it will be tagged with an acceptance tag. If the work or appliance is not satisfactory, it will be tagged with a caution or rejection tag and may either be left in service or shut off, depending on the safe condition of the appliance. The installer will be notified, either by the inspector at the job or by phone, regarding the failure of the installation to pass inspection. An authorized utility inspector will shut off service to the appliance or the gas meter if the installer fails to correct all defects in the appliance or piping. 
(Code 2017, § 7-212; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-110. - Burners firing 500,000 BTUs per hour or larger input. 
    Minimum requirements for burners firing 500,000 BTUs per hour or larger input are as follows: 
(1)  All such burners must be equipped with approved electronic controls. 
(2)  Main burner shutoff valves shall be an approved type, with handles permanently attached. 
(3)  Main burner shutoff valves shall be rated to close against a minimum of 15 pounds per square inch gas pressure in three seconds or less. 
(4)  Where gas pressure exceeds 15 pounds per square inch in the gas utility mains, the safety shutoff valve shall be rated to close against these pressures. 
(5)  Electrical wiring shall provide for closing of this valve on: 
a.  Power failure or interruption. 
b.  Action from any safety limit switches. 
c.  Pilot failure. 
(6)  Two electrically operated gas valves on the main burner gas lien are required. One shall be the input control valve and the other the safety shutoff valve and each shall be so constructed that it will perform its specific job. 
(7)  A one-eighth-inch pipe tap is to be provided with a nipple and cap in the manifold for connecting a manifold pressure gauge for test purposes. 
(8)  A high and low gas pressure switch shall be installed downstream from the input valve and set as close to manifold pressure as possible without causing nuisance shutdowns. When used with an automatic reset type valve, this control must be equipped with a manual reset feature. When used with a manual reset type safety shutoff valve, this control may be either the automatic reset type or the manual reset type. 
(Code 2017, § 7-213; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-111. - General burner firing. 
(a)  All burners must be adjusted for input size by fixed orifice and pressure regulator adjustment with the manual valve in the wide-open position for final checkout. A manual pilot shutoff valve and a pilot safety shutoff valve must be installed. 
(b)  A low water cutoff with an automatic feeder must be provided on all steam boilers. Adequate protection to ensure automatic filling or shutdown of the burner must be provided for gas fired hot water boilers. When a pressure or temperature control is used as an operating controller, an additional high pressure or high temperature safety control must be installed to serve as the high limit to shut burners off in the event of overpressurizing or too high a temperature. 
(c)  A double acting, properly sized field control with a stack temperature switch must be installed; or, if a diverter is used, a temperature switch must be installed at the bottom of the draft diverter on this size of appliance. This switch must be wired into the safety shutoff valve. 
(d)  Wiring and operating diagrams shall be placed on the job as close to appliances as is practical. 
(e)  Specially fired gas burning appliances not complying with the requirements of this section shall not be connected to the gas utility piping system unless individual clearance has been made with the gas inspector. The appliance must be something other than a boiler, furnace, water heater, etc. It must be proven safe for its particular use to the satisfaction of the inspector, and be provided with whatever controls are required to make it a safe appliance to operate. 
(Code 2017, § 7-214; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-112. - Proximity of appliances to combustible materials. 
(a)  Gas appliances so constructed that the burners are not shielded by metal or other approved insulating material shall not be located within 12 inches of any combustible material. 
(b)  All gas appliances, except floor and wall furnaces, so constructed that metal shields or other approved insulating materials are an integral part of their construction, shall not be installed so as to permit such metal shields or other approved insulating materials to be within six inches of combustible material or within three inches of protected combustible material, unless approved by CSAus or an equivalent testing laboratory for less clearance. 
(c)  Gas appliances having open flames, such as gas plates and ranges shall not be installed within three feet of any combustible ceiling material. 
(d)  The top and side walls of a warm air gas furnace shall be not less than six inches from protected or unprotected combustible material, unless approved by CSAus or an equivalent testing laboratory for less clearance. 
(e)  Every floor of combustible construction under a gas burning warm air furnace shall be covered with one-quarter inch of fireproof millboard or other equivalent fire protective material. The floor protection shall project at least 12 inches beyond all sides of the furnace or to the furnace enclosure. The floor covering may be omitted on a wood floor under any gas burning warm air furnace, if the combustion chamber is not less than 24 inches from the floor and is separated by a metal plate or shield, unless approved by CSAus or an equivalent testing laboratory for less clearance. 
(Code 2017, § 7-215; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-113. - Incinerators. 
(a)  All gas-fired incinerators shall be CSAus or equivalent approved. 
(b)  Incinerators shall not be connected to any flue liners except vitrified steel pipe. 
(c)  An approved barometric draft control shall be installed on all incinerators. 
(d)  The smoke pipe connection from an incinerator to an approved flue liner shall be at least 24-gauge galvanized steel. Sheet metal screws shall secure the joints. 
(Code 2017, § 7-216; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-114. - Gas lights and grills. 
(a)  Where outdoor gas lights and grills are installed, copper or plastic tubing approved for natural gas may be used outside any building. 
(b)  All taps or connections must be made downstream from the meter. Steel pipe and fittings must be used aboveground and connected to the tubing underground. 
(c)  A gas shutoff must be used, and should be installed in the iron pipe as close to the meter as possible. 
(d)  The tubing or pipe should be laid in a trench from the building to the light or grill and deep enough so that it will not be broken by normal activity in the area where it is installed. 
(Code 2017, § 7-217; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-115. - Fireplace logs, gas logs and fireplace inserts. 
(a)  Fireplace logs, gas logs and fireplace inserts that have one of the following testing laboratory certifications will be approved: 
(1)  American Gas Association (AGA). International Approval Services (IAS) (formerly AGA). 
(2)  Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL). 
(3)  Building Officials and Code Administrators International (BOCA). 
(4)  Resources, Applications, Designs and Controls, Inc. (RADCO). 
(5)  International Conference of Building Officials (ICBO). 
(6)  City of Los Angeles General Approval. 
(7)  Southern Building Code Congress. 
(8)  Canadian Standards Association; United States (CSAus) (replaces AGA logo and symbols). 
(b)  All flue dampers must be permanently blocked open a minimum of one inch across the damper. 
(c)  Fresh air will be required for new natural gas fireplaces. The fresh air must not be taken from a garage area. 
(d)  Glass doors will not be required on any installation, but are recommended. 
(e)  Log lighters will be allowed, however, the valve should be installed out of the path of radiant or direct heat from burning wood. 
(Code 2017, § 7-218; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-116. - Corrugated stainless steel tubing (CSST). 
    Any person installing or purchasing for installation any CSST must be certified for each manufacturer of CSST being installed. The installer must also carry the installer's certification card of the CSST manufacturer to exhibit to authorized Cedar Falls Utilities personnel upon request. All installations of CSST shall conform to the manufacturer's specifications, and shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  CSST shall not be installed on any exposed surface where damage may occur unless it is properly protected. 
(2)  Air tests are required except as otherwise provided in this subsection. The first test will be the rough-in air test at ten pounds for 15 minutes. At this time all strike plates, sleeves, and shields shall be in place. The "final air test" will be ten pounds for 15 minutes after walls, ceilings, etc., have been installed. On retrofit jobs, where the CSST is pushed through a chase that is already closed in, only one test will be required. 
(3)  Two-pound CSST systems are authorized only with approval of Cedar Falls Utilities prior to the installation of the gas service to the building. 
(4)  If the two-pound CSST installation contains a regulator at the two pound/inches water column manifold, the regulator shall be vented to the outside with a bug cap attached. 
(Code 2017, § 7-219; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Secs. 7-117-7-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 7-146. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or cause to be installed any gas piping, gas vent, flue liner or natural gas appliance without obtaining a permit to do so. Such permit shall be signed by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel. 
(Code 2017, § 7-236; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-147. - Exception. 
    A permit will not be required under this division for minor repairs. 
(Code 2017, § 7-237; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-148. - Issuance. 
    Any permit required by this division may be issued to any building or appliance owner to do any construction work regulated by this division, provided that the building or appliance owner or permanently employed maintenance personnel of the building owner shall personally perform all labor in connection therewith. The building or appliance owner applying for the permit is not required to be bonded in accordance with section 7-93. 
(Code 2017, § 7-238; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-149. - Fee. 
(a)  A permit fee will not be charged for a permit required under this division if a permit is taken out prior to the start of the work or while the work is in progress. If a permit is issued more than one day after completion of the work, a fee in the amount established by resolution from time to time will be charged. 
(b)  Owner's permits will be issued without charge. 
(Code 2017, § 7-239; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Sec. 7-150. - Permit for temporary use of gas. 
    When temporary use of gas is desired, the gas inspector may grant a permit for such use for a period not to exceed 30 days, provided the gas piping which is to be used has been given a test equal to that required for a final inspection. 
(Code 2017, § 7-240; Ord. No. 2321, § 2, 1-8-2001) 
Secs. 7-151-7-168. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-169. - Title; Uniform Plumbing Code; adoption; purpose and scope; conflicting provisions. 
(a)  This article shall be known as the Cedar Falls Plumbing Code, and may be so cited and may be referred to hereinafter as the "code". 
(b)  The 2015 Edition of the Uniform Plumbing Code, including chapters 1 through 17, all inclusive, as published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, except as such codes are amended in this article, is hereby adopted by reference and is effective as if fully set forth in this article. 
(c)  The purpose of this section and section 7-170 is to establish local installation standards modifying and superseding certain articles, paragraphs and subsections of the 2015 Edition of the Uniform Plumbing Code. Any and all plumbing systems shall be installed in conformity with the rules and regulations set forth in this article and the code adopted in this article. Where, in any specific case, different sections of this article specify different materials, methods of installation or other requirements, the most restrictive shall govern. 
(d)  An official copy of the code adopted by this article, including a certificate by the city clerk as to its adoption and effective date, is on file in the office of the city clerk, in either hardbound or electronic version, available for public inspection. 
(Code 2017, § 7-256; Ord. No. 2870, § 1, 7-5-2016) 
Sec. 7-170. - Uniform Plumbing Code; amendments. 
(a)  The provisions of this section specify certain amendments, by deletion, addition or substitution, of the 2015 Edition of the Uniform Plumbing Code. Where this section states that a section, subsection, enumeration or exception is deleted, only the specific section, subsection, enumeration or exception is deleted. Where this section states that a part, section or subsection is deleted in its entirety, all references listed thereafter associated with this specific part of section (with subsections, enumerations and exceptions) or subsection (with enumerations and exceptions) are deleted. 
2015 UPC Chapter 1 Amendments 
(1)  Section 102.2, Existing Construction, is amended by adding the following after the last sentence: 
If an existing building is damaged by fire or otherwise or altered in such a manner as to require the replacement of 50 percent or more of the plumbing equipment, the entire building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this article for new buildings. If the type of occupancy of an existing building is partially or entirely changed, the plumbing system shall be made to conform to the requirements of this article for the new type of occupancy. 
(2)  Section 103.0, Duties and Powers of the Authority Having Jurisdiction, is amended by adding the following after the last sentence: 
(a)  The office of the plumbing inspector for the city is hereby created, and such inspector is hereby authorized, directed and empowered to inspect any and all buildings or structures, public or private, and as provided in this article, to condemn and order removed or remodeled and put into proper and safe condition all plumbing and plumbing related structures for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall be appointed by the director of community development after recommendation of the building official, and such inspector shall be directly responsible to the building official. 
(c)  The appointee shall be a qualified plumber and shall have at least ten years of practical experience in the plumbing trade or five years as a plumbing inspector, or, in lieu of such experience, a combination of trade school, practical experience and inspection experience considered by the building official as being suitable for minimum requirements, shall be possessed of such executive ability as requisite for the performance of required duties, shall have thorough knowledge of the standard materials and methods used in the installation and maintenance of plumbing equipment, and shall be well versed in improved methods of construction for safety to persons and property, the statutes of the state relating to sanitation and plumbing and any orders, rules and regulations issued by authority thereof and in the Uniform Plumbing Code. 
(d)  The plumbing inspector shall hold a current journeyman plumber's license with the State of Iowa, or shall be required to pass an examination for journeyman prior to appointment. 
(3)  Section 103.1 is amended by adding the following new subsections: 
103.1.1 Supervision of Building Official. The plumbing inspector shall work fully under the supervision and jurisdiction of the building official and take all orders and perform any duties or services that may be assigned by the building official pertaining to plumbing inspections or other related duties. 
103.1.2 Conflict of Interest. It shall be unlawful for the plumbing inspector to engage in the business of the sales, installation or maintenance of plumbing equipment, either directly or indirectly, and the inspector shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business in the city, at any time, while holding the office provided for in this division. 
103.1.3 Records. 
(a)  The plumbing inspector shall keep records of applications for plumbing permits and of all inspections. The records shall be available to the public. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall keep an accounting record for the collection of permit fees. 
(c)  The plumbing inspector shall keep records of sewer connections from city mains to the property line and from the property line to each building connected to city services. 
103.1.4 Interpretation of Regulations. The plumbing inspector shall have full power to exercise judgment in a reasonable and proper manner and rule accordingly on all special cases in regard to any matters in this article or not specifically covered thereby, subject to section 107.0 pertaining to appeals. 
(4)  Section 103.3.1, Licensing , is deleted in its entirety and the following is substituted therefor: 
103.3.1 Licenses Required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing any plumbing system within the scope of this article unless such person has obtained from the State of Iowa board of plumbing examiners and appeals, a master plumber's business license, nor shall any such business or dealer employ any but licensed master plumbers, journeyman plumbers or apprentice plumbers employed by and working under the direction of a holder of the license for one of the classes of licenses prescribed by this article. 
(b)  All plumbing contractors not currently registered by the city shall pay a one time registration fee as set by the city council. 
(c)  A plumbing business, other than pipe layers, shall show proof of a state issued master plumbing contractor license and shall execute and file with the city building official (or a specified inter-governmental agency if so designated by the building official) a certificate of insurance written by a company authorized to transact business in the state, in limits established annually by resolution by the city council; said certificate to be written on a standard form and carrying an endorsement naming the city, and its employees (or the inter-governmental agency designated by the building official) as additional insureds as its interest may appear and conditioned upon the faithful performance of all duties required of such contract by any ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. It shall be a further condition of said certificate of insurance that the obligator will hold the city (through the specified intergovernmental agency if so designated) harmless from any and all damages sustained by reason of neglect or incompetency on the part of such contractor, his agents or employees in the performance of the work done under a license or permit issued upon the filing of said certificate. 
(d)  Upon payment of the annual license fee set by city council, a pipe layer's license may be issued to a company that meets the insurance requirements of subsection (b) of this section set by the city and may be required to take an exam approved by the plumbing inspector. 
(e)  Said certificate of insurance shall be issued by December 31 of each year, and shall be refiled on or before said date for each subsequent year and shall be in continuous full force and effect. That it is the intent and purpose of said certificate of insurance to also bind the individual, company, firm, association or partnership, whether it be trade name, corporation, or other business association or arrangement with which the principal is associated. 
(5)  Section 104.4.3 Expiration , is amended by deleting subsections 104.4.3 and 104.4.4 in their entirety and substituting the following therefor: 
104.4.3 Expiration. Every permit issued under the provisions of this code shall expire 12 months from the date of issue, unless the application is accompanied by a construction schedule of specific longer duration, in which instance the permit may be issued for the time period of the construction schedule, with the approval of the building official. If the work has not been completed, including all required inspections, by the expiration date of the permit, no further work shall be done until the permit has been renewed by the owner, or the owner's agent, and payment of the renewal fee has been received. The building official is authorized to grant one or more extensions of time, for periods of not more than six months each, without payment of the renewal fee. Extensions shall be requested by the owner or the owner's agent and justifiable cause demonstrated by the owner. 
(6)  Section 104.5, Permit Fees , is amended by deleting it in its entirety and substituting the following new subsection 104.5: 
104.5.1 Permit Fees. 
(a)  Fees will be charged for new installations, replacement of old installations with new installations, or change of location, and, in the case of plumbing fixtures, for the removal of fixtures. 
(b)  The schedule of permit fees shall be as established annually by resolution by the city council. 
(c)  Payment of fees for permits shall be made on or before the tenth day of the month following the date of the statement from the plumbing inspector. All fees shall be paid to the plumbing inspector, and be payable to the city. The plumbing inspector shall receipt for the fees in duplicate, and one of the receipts shall be given to the applicant. 
(d)  Failure to comply with subsection (c) of this section will automatically cause the person to cease work. 
(7)  Section 106.0, Violation and Penalties , is amended by deleting subsection 106.3 and substituting the following in its place: 
106.3 Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a municipal infraction punishable as provided in section 1-9. 
106.3.1 If any plumbing work, including construction or repair, is being performed within the city contrary to the provisions of the code adopted by this article, it shall be deemed a municipal infraction and, in addition to the penalties described in this section, shall be corrected in accordance with the code adopted by this article. 
106.3.2 The doing of any act prohibited or declared to be unlawful or an offense by this article or the code adopted by this article, or the omission or failure to perform any act or duty required by this article or the code adopted by this article is, unless otherwise specified, a municipal infraction, punishable as provided in section 1-9. 
106.3.3 Any person violating any provision of this article may be subject to an additional civil penalty and possible denial, revocation or suspension of license pursuant to Iowa Code ch. 105. 
(8)  Section 107.0, Board of Appeals , is deleted in its entirety and the following is substituted therefor: 
107.0 Board of Appeals. 
107.1 Membership; Appointment of Members; Term of Office. 
(a)  The board of plumbing appeals shall consist of five members, one member of the city council, appointed each year, one owner, officer, director, shareholder or employee of a plumbing company, one master plumber, one journeyman plumber and one public member, each appointed for a period of four years. The plumbing inspector shall serve as secretary to the board but is nonvoting. Appointments shall be made by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. Should a vacancy in the board occur, it shall be the duty of the secretary of the board to notify the mayor of the vacancy, and the mayor and city council shall, at a regular meeting, as soon possible thereafter, appoint a new member to the board to fill the vacancy for the unexpired term. 
(b)  Expiration of appointments, except for the city councilmember, shall be staggered, so that one member is appointed or reappointed each year. Terms of appointment shall expire on December 31. If the mayor and city council fail to appoint at the scheduled time, the expired term member will be held over until re-appointment or replacement. 
(c)  In so far as reasonably practicable, appointees for membership on the board shall be residents of the city, or, if that is not reasonably practicable, shall have a place of employment in the city. Appointees who are neither residents of the city nor who have a place of employment in the city may be eligible for appointment to the board upon a finding of the unavailability of qualified applicants, as determined by the mayor. Any person who is a member of the board on the date of adoption of this ordinance who does not meet the qualifications for membership set forth herein shall continue to be eligible to serve as a member of the board until both the expiration of his current term and the member's nonreappointment by the mayor to an additional term. 
107.2 Meetings; Records. 
(a)  All meetings of the plumbing appeals board shall be held in the council chambers, or other location indicated in a public notice posted 24 hours prior to any meeting. 
(b)  Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transacting of all business, but any action taken by the board shall require a majority vote of all members of the board. 
(c)  The board shall annually elect one of its members as the chairman of the board. 
(d)  The secretary of the board shall keep a record of the board meetings. 
107.3 Compensation of Members. The members of the plumbing board of appeals shall serve without compensation. 
107.4 Appeals. 
(a)  Any person shall have the right to register an appeal with the plumbing board of appeals for a review of any decision of the plumbing inspector, provided that such appeal is made in writing within ten days after having been notified of such decision by the plumbing inspector. Upon receipt of such appeal, the board of appeals shall proceed to determine whether the action of the plumbing inspector complies with this article and shall make a decision in accordance with its findings within ten days of receiving the appeal. No appeal shall be considered unless the appeal is filed within the period of ten days. The board of appeals shall have no authority to waive requirements of this code. 
(b)  An appeal to the city council of any ruling of the board may be made by filing a written notice of such appeal with the city clerk within ten days from the date of the ruling being appealed. The city council shall give the appellant and the board a minimum of five days written notice by certified mail of the date, time and location of hearing of said appeal. All interested persons shall be given the opportunity to be heard at such hearing and the city council may affirm, modify or overrule the action of the board based upon the evidence submitted before the city council.

402.6.1 Closet Rings (Closet Flanges). 
Closet rings (closet flanges) for water closets or similar fixtures shall be of an approved type and shall be bronze, copper, hard lead, cast-iron, galvanized malleable iron, ABS, PVC, or other approved materials. Each such closet ring (closet flange) shall be approximately seven inches (178 mm) in diameter and, where installed, shall, together with the soil pipe, present a 11/2 inch (38 mm) wide flange or face to receive the fixture gasket or closet seal. Closet bends or stubs shall be cut off so as to present a smooth surface even with the top of the closet ring before rough inspection is called. Closet rings (closet flanges) shall be adequately designed and secured to support fixtures connected thereto.

Secs. 7-172-7-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITION ON DISCHARGE OF STORMWATER AND GROUNDWATER TO CITY SANITARY SEWER 

Sec. 7-196. - Discharge of stormwater or groundwater into city sanitary sewer system. 
    The discharge of water from any roof, surface, ground, sump pump, footing tile or from any other natural precipitation source into the city sanitary sewer collection system has the potential to cause damage to property and to overload the city wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment system. Such discharge may result in the backup of sewage into living quarters of residential dwellings, or into other buildings or structures in the city, thereby creating a potential public health hazard, and potentially exceeding the capacity of the city wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment system. Therefore, the city finds that it is essential to the maintenance of public health, safety, comfort, and welfare, to the minimization of damage to property, and to the maintenance of the functioning and capacity of the city wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment system, that the provisions of this division be strictly enforced. Since Ordinance No. 1275 was adopted on February 10, 1969, this Code has prohibited the discharge of stormwater from any dwelling, building or other structure into the city's sanitary sewer system. The provisions of this division shall apply to every dwelling, building or other structure in the city, for the construction of which a city building permit was issued after February 10, 1969. 
(Code 2017, § 7-259; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-197. - Restrictions and definitions. 
    No water from any roof, surface, ground, sump pump, footing tile, or from any other natural precipitation source shall be discharged into the city sanitary sewer system. Any dwelling, building or other structure subject to the provisions of this division which, because of the infiltration of water into basements, crawl spaces and the like, require a seepage collection system, a "beaver drain," or any sump pump system to discharge water, shall have a permanently-installed discharge line which shall not at any time connect to or discharge such stormwater into the city sanitary sewer system. For purposes of this division, a permanent installation shall be one which provides for a year-round discharge connection to the city subdrain/storm sewer system. If there is no city subdrain/storm sewer system available to the property, the surface discharge point shall be located no closer than ten feet from any property line, or as otherwise approved by the director of community development or his designee. Such discharge line shall consist of a rigid discharge line inside the structure, without valving or quick connections for altering the path of discharge and, if connected to the city subdrain/storm sewer system, shall include a check valve. 
(Code 2017, § 7-260; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-198. - Sump, pump, and rigid pipe; method of installation. 
(a)  Any such discharge line shall consist of a pipe that shall be installed through the outside foundation wall of the dwelling, building or other structure, with rigid pipe (plastic, copper or galvanized) 11/2 inches (40 mm) inside diameter minimum, without valves or quick connections that would alter the path of discharge. The discharge shall be directed away from the foundation wall of the structure. 
(b)  No discharge shall be directed so as to impact neighboring properties or any city street, sidewalk or right-of-way. 
(c)  Where a sump pit exists in any such dwelling, building or other structure subject to this division, it shall have a pump installed with rigid piping as specified in this section. 
(d)  Any plumber, contractor, or other person who knowingly installs a sump, pump and/or piping that is not in conformance with the provisions of this division shall be liable to the city for all damages caused by such improper installation, and shall further be subject to the penalties set forth in section 7-204. 
(Code 2017, § 7-261; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-199. - Disconnections ordered. 
    Any owner of any dwelling, building, or other structure in the city that is subject to this division, which has a roof, surface, ground, sump pump, footing tile or other natural precipitation source that is now connected to and/or discharging into the city sanitary sewer system, shall immediately disconnect and/or remove the same. Any disconnects or openings in the city sanitary sewer system shall be closed or repaired in a manner approved by the director of community development or his designee. 
(Code 2017, § 7-262; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-200. - Inspections. 
    Every owner of any dwelling, building or other structure that is subject to the provisions of this division, shall allow the city director of community development or his designee, to gain admittance to the owner's property in order to inspect such dwelling, building or other structure, to confirm that there is no sump pump or other prohibited discharge from said property into the city sanitary sewer system. The owner of any such property may meet the requirements of this section by contracting with a licensed plumber who is authorized to do business in the city to perform such inspection. Such plumber shall inspect the owner's property and the sump pump system, and shall complete, sign and return an inspection form to the city, documenting the results of the inspection. The inspection form shall be furnished to the owner or the licensed plumber upon request. All costs associated with an inspection by a licensed plumber retained by the property owner under this section shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
(Code 2017, § 7-263; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-201. - Time limit for owner to allow inspection by the city or by a licensed plumber. 
    The owner of any dwelling, building or other structure shall have a period of 30 days from the date the city sends a written notice to the owner requesting admittance to the owner's property for an inspection, to either allow a city inspection of the property, or to contract with a licensed plumber to perform the inspection, and notify the city of the results thereof, as provided in section 7-200. Such inspection, whether performed by the city inspector, or by the licensed plumber hired by the property owner, shall be completed within said 30 day period. 
(Code 2017, § 7-264; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-202. - Time limit for disconnection of discharge into city sanitary sewer system. 
(a)  Upon completion of a city inspection of a property, or upon the city's receipt of an inspection form from the licensed plumber hired by the owner of the property, the city shall determine whether any such property is improperly discharging stormwater into the city sanitary sewer system, and shall send a notice to the property owner regarding the results of said inspection. If the property is found to be discharging stormwater into the city sanitary sewer system, then the owner shall have a period of 90 days from the date the city sends such written notice to the owner, to obtain a plumbing permit, and to disconnect the owner's sump pump or other prohibited discharge into the city sanitary sewer system, and to request an inspection, certifying that all work necessary to disconnect the owner's sump pump or other prohibited discharge from said property into the city sanitary sewer system has been completed. 
(b)  All work that is necessary to comply with the provisions of this division which requires the issuance of any plumbing, building or other permit under this Code shall be inspected by the city inspection services division for compliance with all applicable Code requirements. 
(Code 2017, § 7-265; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-203. - Sanitary sewer surcharge. 
    Any owner who fails to timely comply with the requirements of either section 7-201 or 7-202 shall thereupon be subject to and shall pay a monthly surcharge on the property owner's city sewer bill in the amount of $100.00 per month. Said surcharge shall commence on the first day of the month following the expiration of the 30-day period set forth in section 7-201, or the 90-day period set forth in section 7-202, as applicable, when either the property owner has failed to timely allow a city inspection or has failed to timely correct any illegal connections to the city sanitary sewer system, or has failed to contract with a licensed plumber to inspect the property and correct any illegal connections to the city sanitary sewer system. Such surcharge shall continue to be imposed on the owner's city sanitary sewer bill for as long as the property owner continues to own the property without complying with the requirements of this division. This monthly surcharge is intended to offset the added cost to the city associated with having the city wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment system process clear or clean water unnecessarily, when the status of the property owner's connection or non-connection to the city sanitary sewer system cannot be ascertained, or when the owner has failed to timely disconnect any discharge of stormwater to the city sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 2017, § 7-266; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Sec. 7-204. - Penalties and enforcement. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this division shall be subject to the penalties set forth in this section. 
(1)  If any person is found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this division, the city shall send written notice stating the nature of the violation, and providing the person with at least 30 days to correct the violation. Any person who has received a written notice from the city described in this subsection (a) and who continues to be in violation of the provisions of this division shall be deemed to have committed a municipal infraction, and shall be subject to a civil penalty as provided in section 1-9(a). Each day that a municipal infraction occurs or is permitted to continue constitutes a separate offense. 
(2)  Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this section does not preclude the city from also seeking alternative relief from the court in the same action. Such alternative relief may include, but is not limited to, abatement or injunctive relief. 
(3)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this division shall be liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage incurred by the city resulting from such violation. The city hereby also retains any and all available civil remedies, including, but not limited to, injunction or abatement actions to remedy any violation of this division. 
(Code 2017, § 7-267; Ord. No. 2842, § 1, 5-4-2015; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 7-6-2015) 
Secs. 7-205-7-231. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-232. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building means a structure designed, built or occupied as a shelter or roofed enclosure for persons, animals or property and used for residential, business or mercantile storage or commercial, industrial, institutional, assembly, educational or recreational purposes, which when loaded on any carrier of any kind has a loaded height exceeding 13 feet, six inches and a loaded width exceeding eight feet. 
    Building mover means any person who engages in the work of moving in any way, or raising, lowering or supporting by shoring, or upon temporary blocking, jacks or wedges, any building or other structure, or any part thereof. 
(Code 2017, § 7-411) 
Sec. 7-233. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a municipal infraction and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished accordingly. 
(Code 2017, § 7-412) 
Sec. 7-234. - Transfer of license or permit. 
    No license or permit issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable. 
(Code 2017, § 7-413) 
Sec. 7-235. - Revocation of license or permit. 
    Any person who shall, in the application for a license required by this article, or for a house moving permit, make any false or untrue statement, who shall violate the provisions of this article, who shall fail to pay any cost or expense incurred by the city as a result of his operations, or whose bond or insurance as required by this article has been cancelled or otherwise terminated, shall, upon such finding, have his license revoked. 
(Code 2017, § 7-414) 
Sec. 7-236. - Moving of certain buildings prohibited; safety of route. 
(a)  No building shall be moved upon or through the streets of the city which exceeds 34 feet, including overhang, in width, or which exceeds 30 feet loaded height without prior approval by the city council of the city. 
(b)  No building shall be moved upon or through the streets of the city to a lot in the city if the value of the building before moving is less than 50 percent of the value of a new building of the same type. No building shall be moved in or through the streets of the city to a lot in the city if the building is in such a deteriorated condition that in the opinion of the building official it is unsafe and a hazard. 
(c)  No building shall be moved on any route which in the opinion of the building official endangers other buildings or property. 
(Code 2017, § 7-415; Ord. No. 2164, § 1, 9-9-1996) 
Sec. 7-237. - Responsibility for injuries or damage. 
    Any injury done to any street, avenue, highway, alley, public ground, sidewalk, curb, crossing or pavement when a building is moved shall be promptly repaired to the satisfaction of the director of municipal operations and programs, and the cost of any injury or damage done to any person or to any property, either public or private, shall be promptly paid, and the bonds provided for in section 7-276 shall stand as security therefor. 
(Code 2017, § 7-416) 
Sec. 7-238. - Report of damage. 
    The house mover shall report any damage done to any street, avenue, highway, boulevard, alley, sidewalk, curb, tree or telephone or light pole or wires, or to any other public or private property, except property owned by the house mover or the structure being moved, to the building official, within 12 hours from and after the occurrence causing the damage. 
(Code 2017, § 7-417) 
Sec. 7-239. - Parking on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person moving a building to stop, stand or park a house, equipment, material or structure upon privately owned property without first having obtained the consent of the owner or person in charge of the privately owned property. Upon complaint of the owner or person in charge of the privately owned property, failure of the person to obtain the consent is declared to be an offense. 
(Code 2017, § 7-418) 
Sec. 7-240. - Use of streets; hours for movement; emergency storage on street. 
(a)  In no case shall paved streets, alleys, avenues or public grounds be used for the purpose of moving any building unless they are in the most practical direct route from the place of origin to the place of destination. The movement, when commenced, shall be continued from sunrise to 3:00 p.m., day by day, until completed, with the least possible obstruction to the thoroughfares occupied. 
(b)  No building being moved shall be stored on the streets of the city unless authorized by the building official. No such authorization shall be granted unless application for the occupancy is made to the building official, in writing, setting forth the reasons therefor. The occupancy shall be granted only if the applicant demonstrates that an emergency exists which was not the making of the individual moving the building or to which the mover did not contribute. Before authorization for street occupancy can be granted, the applicant must sign a statement assuming liability for any damage to persons and property, including property of the city, and indemnify the city for any claims against the city arising out of the occupancy. Barricades of a type meeting the city engineer's specifications as to size and illumination shall be kept in a conspicuous place at each end and side of the building during the night, which shall be between sunset and sunrise. 
(Code 2017, § 7-419) 
Sec. 7-241. - Temporary no parking zones. 
    Parking shall be prohibited on streets included in the routing for the moving of a building if deemed necessary by the city. At least 48 hours in advance of the time of moving, the person moving the building shall post signs provided by the city designating the streets included in the routing as no parking zones. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in such no parking zones when the temporary no parking signs are posted. If any automobile is parked illegally in violation of the provisions of this section, and a summons has been issued by the police operations division, the person moving the building shall be responsible for the expense of towing the vehicle away, but may recover the expense from the violator. The person moving the building shall assume all risk of damage to any vehicle either towed away or parked in the route. The person moving the building shall remove all temporary no parking signs on the streets included in the routing immediately after the building being moved has passed the street assigned for no parking. The person removing the building shall return the no parking signs to the city after their removal, and shall pay the city for any signs lost, damaged or destroyed. 
(Code 2017, § 7-420) 
Sec. 7-242. - Inspection of streets. 
    The party moving any building shall, within one day after the building reaches its destination, report such fact to the city clerk, who shall thereupon notify the director of municipal operations and programs, who shall immediately inspect the streets and alleys or public grounds over which the building was moved and ascertain the condition of the streets, alleys or public grounds. If the removal of such building has caused any damage to the streets, alleys or public grounds or electric light wires or cables or other property belonging to the city, the city shall repair the damage done at the expense of the party taking out the permit, and shall hold the sureties on the bond given by the house mover responsible for the payment of the expense. 
(Code 2017, § 7-421) 
Sec. 7-243. - Report to fire chief. 
    Every house mover shall report to the fire chief each night the exact location where the building is to remain. 
(Code 2017, § 7-422) 
Sec. 7-244. - Removal of utility poles and wires. 
    Whenever in moving any building it shall be necessary to cut or move any electric light, telephone, traffic or other wire, pole or fixture, the owner of the wire, pole or fixture shall have the right to cut or move it or supervise the cutting or moving, and a written notice shall be given by the moving permittee to the owner at least 48 hours before the time required for cutting or moving, specifying the place, the person who requests the cutting or removal, and the time when the cutting or removal will be required. The expense of cutting or removing the wires, poles or fixtures or supervising the cutting or removal shall be paid by the moving contractor, if the owner of the wires, poles or fixtures has done the work in accordance with the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city relating thereto. If the owners of the wires, poles or fixtures have failed to comply with the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city relating thereto, then the owner shall bear all expenses of cutting or removing the wires, poles or fixtures. 
(Code 2017, § 7-423) 
Sec. 7-245. - Clearing and filling of old building site; abandonment of utility connections. 
(a)  After a building is moved, all abandoned water, sewer, electrical and other service connections shall be plugged and filled in. In addition, all abandoned septic tanks and dry wells shall be pumped out and filled with sand. Permission to so abandon utilities, septic tanks and dry wells shall first be obtained from the city, and any other necessary release shall be obtained from the utility companies. The releases and permission must be filed with the application for a permit to move the building. 
(b)  Every permittee under division 3 of this article shall remove all rubbish and materials and fill all excavations to existing grade at the original building site within 60 days after the building is moved, so that the premises are left in a safe and sanitary condition. Within 90 days after the building is moved, but no less than 30 days after final grading of the site, or at the earliest opportunity during the growing season that is conducive to plant germination, the site shall be seeded with grass or similar acceptable vegetative ground cover. The owner of the property shall make reasonable efforts to ensure proper germination of the planted vegetation, and the property owner shall thereafter maintain the property in compliance with all applicable city ordinances.
