(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this division is to provide minimum standards and regulations applicable to alarm systems and alarm users as defined in this division. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm agent means a person designated in writing to the police of the city by an alarm user to respond to an alarm call at the alarm user's protected premises when the alarm user is out of the city or otherwise unable to respond to an alarm call. 
    Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices, or a single device such as a solid state unit, arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which the police are expected to respond. The term "alarm system" shall include automatic holdup alarm system, burglar alarm system, holdup alarm system, local alarm system and manual holdup alarm system. The term "alarm system" shall not include proprietary alarm system, an alarm system on a motor vehicle (unless connected to an alarm system on or at a protected premises), or a system which monitors temperature, humidity or any other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a protected premises. 
    Alarm user means any person in control of premises, as owner or lessee, on which premises an alarm system is located or maintained within the city. 
    Automatic holdup alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the action of an attacker or robber. 
    Burglar alarm system means an alarm system which is designed to detect and signal the presence, entry or attempted entry of an intruder into a protected premises. 
    City means the City of Cedar Falls, Iowa. 
    False alarm means an alarm signal necessitating a response by a police officer where an emergency situation does not exist. A false alarm does not include an alarm signal resulting from a power interruption caused by severe weather conditions in the city. 
    Holdup alarm system means an alarm system designed to signal a robbery or attempted robbery at a protected premise. 
    Local alarm system means an alarm system which, when activated, generates either an audible sound or a visual signal, or both, on the protected premises designed to be seen or heard by persons outside the protected premises. 
    Manual holdup alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the action of the person attacked or by another observer. 
    Proprietary alarm system means a system that is designed to sound and/or record an alarm signal only at a control center located within the protected premises. 
    Police means a police officer or officers of the city. 
    Police chief means the chief of police of the city or his designee. 
    Protected premises means that part of a building to which protection is afforded by an alarm system. 
(Code 2017, § 16-236; Ord. No. 2463, § 1, 12-22-2003) 
Sec. 13-137. - False alarms; fees for false alarms. 
(a)  An alarm user shall be charged a fee for each false alarm as provided in this section, in such amount as shall be established by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(b)  Each alarm user shall be allowed five false alarms without being charged a false alarm fee during each calendar year. All false alarms after the first five false alarms in each calendar year shall be subject to a false alarm fee as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  If an alarm user, or his designated alarm agent, fails, for whatever reason, to respond to the protected premises as a result of an alarm call within 30 minutes of the time the police have responded to the alarm and have arrived at the location of the protected premises, that alarm call shall be considered a false alarm, and a false alarm fee shall be charged in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(d)  If an alarm user fails to pay any false alarm fee within 30 days of the date of invoice for such fee from the city, the alarm user shall incur a finance charge of 11/2 percent per month for each month or part of a month from the date of the original invoice until the fee and all finance charges are paid in full. 
(Code 2017, § 16-237; Ord. No. 2463, § 1, 12-22-2003) 
Sec. 13-138. - Disconnection of alarm system and/or termination of police response to alarm. 
(a)  If an alarm user fails to pay any false alarm fee together with any finance charges thereon within 30 days of the date of invoice from the city, the police chief may issue notice of intention to disconnect the alarm user's alarm system from its connection to the police department of the city, and/or notice of intention to refuse to authorize the police of the city to respond to an alarm call at the alarm user's protected premises. Such notice shall contain a brief statement of the grounds to be relied on for disconnecting the system and/or refusing to authorize the police to respond to alarm calls at the alarm user's protected premises, and shall advise the alarm user of his right to request a hearing, and the time limitation and procedure to request such a hearing. Notice shall be given either by personal service on the alarm user or by depositing said notice in the United States mail in a sealed envelope, postage prepaid, addressed to the alarm user at the address where the protected premises are located, or at the alarm user's last known address if different from the address of the protected premises. 
(b)  An alarm user shall have 20 days from the date of mailing of the notice to request a hearing before the police chief. Such request must be in writing and must be postmarked or delivered to the chief of police at the city hall of the city within said 20-day period. If the alarm user submits a timely written request for hearing, then notice of the date, time and place of hearing before the police chief shall be sent by the police chief to the alarm user at least ten days prior to the date set for such hearing. Such notice shall be given in the same manner as the notice under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  At the hearing, the alarm user shall be given an opportunity to present whatever information and evidence the alarm user desires to submit in support of the request. The police chief shall allow information and documentation to be submitted by the police in support of the notice given under subsection (a) of this section. The police chief shall issue a written decision either authorizing disconnection of the alarm user's alarm system and/or authorizing the police to refuse to respond to an alarm call at the alarm user's protected premises, or denying such authorization. A copy of the decision shall be sent to the alarm user in the same manner as the notice under subsection (a) of this section. The decision shall advise the alarm user of the right to appeal the decision to the city council, and of the time limitation and procedure for the appeal. 
(d)  If the alarm user has submitted a timely request for hearing under this section, the chief of police shall not disconnect the alarm user's alarm system from its connection or refuse to authorize the police to respond to an alarm call at the alarm user's protected premises under a final decision is made by the chief of police on the request. 
(Code 2017, § 16-238; Ord. No. 2463, § 1, 12-22-2003) 
Sec. 13-139. - Appeals. 
(a)  Right of appeal. An alarm user aggrieved by the decision of the chief of police shall have the right to appeal to the city council. Notice of appeal must be in writing and filed with the city clerk of the city within 15 days after service of the decision of the chief of police. The notice of appeal shall briefly state the basis for such appeal. 
(b)  Appeal procedure. 
(1)  Upon receipt of the notice of appeal, the city clerk shall place the matter on the agenda of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council. The city council shall set the matter for hearing at least 14 days but not more than 28 days in the future. The city clerk shall give the appealing party written notice of the time and place of the hearing by ordinary mail in the same manner as provided for in section 13-138(a). 
(2)  At the time and place set for the hearing upon the appeal from the decision of the chief of police, the city council shall give the appealing party a reasonable opportunity to be heard in order to show cause why the determination by the chief of police should not be upheld. The burden of proof shall be on the appealing party to show that the action taken by the chief of police is arbitrary, capricious, or in excess of his authority. The determination of the city council shall be final and conclusive. 
(c)  If an alarm user has filed a timely appeal of the decision of the chief of police, the chief of police shall not disconnect the alarm user's alarm system from its connection or refuse to authorize the police to respond to an alarm call at the alarm user's protected premises until a final decision is made on the appeal. 
(Code 2017, § 16-239; Ord. No. 2463, § 1, 12-22-2003) 
Sec. 13-140. - Reconnection of alarm system. 
    Any alarm user, whose alarm system has been disconnected from the police department and/or with respect to whom the police have issued a refusal to respond to alarm calls, may apply for a new connection at the same or a different protected premise. The chief of police shall not be required to allow a new connection from the alarm user unless all false alarm fees and finance charges have been paid in full, and unless the police chief, in his sole and absolute discretion, is satisfied that the alarm user shall meet the obligations imposed upon the alarm user by the provisions of this division, and provided that sufficient space is available at the police department or dispatch center for the connection. 
(Code 2017, § 16-240; Ord. No. 2463, § 1, 12-22-2003) 
Secs. 13-141-13-163. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SURVEILLANCE CAMERAS FOR BUSINESSES 

Sec. 13-164. - Purpose. 
    This division is enacted to reduce the potential for situations where employees of certain businesses or persons utilizing the services of certain businesses are exposed to potential death and/or injuries because of actions of people with criminal intent. 
(Code 2017, § 16-260; Ord. No. 2040, § 1, 12-13-1993) 
Sec. 13-165. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means an establishment for retail sale of petroleum products and other supplies for motor vehicles, as well as for the retail sale of a variety of other items typically sold in grocery stores, or an establishment that provides lodging for paying guests or any other establishment that normally has only one clerk or employee on duty or financial institution's automated teller machine or similar device which dispenses currency to a patron, and said establishment routinely remains open for business for some or all of the hours between 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 2017, § 16-261; Ord. No. 2040, § 1, 12-13-1993) 
Sec. 13-166. - Surveillance camera required. 
    Any business as defined herein shall be equipped with a functioning surveillance camera between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. or that portion of those hours the business is open, each day (night) that the business is open. The surveillance camera shall be positioned so as to record on film or videotape the image of all persons entering the business and/or all persons approaching within five feet of the cash register. All proposed installations and positioning of a surveillance camera shall be submitted in advance to the city police division for determination and approval that the same meets the requirements set out in this division. 
(Code 2017, § 16-262; Ord. No. 2040, § 1, 12-13-1993) 
Sec. 13-167. - Exemptions. 
    Any business may apply to the chief of police for exemption from the provisions of this division if that business has undertaken alternate security measures which are substantially equal to or more effective in preventing criminal activity and assisting in the apprehension of the perpetrator and for protecting employees. The chief of police shall provide written standards which the chief of police, or designee, will consider in determining alternate security measures. If the chief of police or designee approves such alternate security measures submitted by the business, then the business is not required to comply with the provisions of this division for as long as the approval of the chief or designee is effective. If the application for exemption is denied by the chief of police or designee, the business may then appeal to the administration committee of the city council for further review of the application for exemption and the decision by the administration committee for the city council shall be final, except, to such extent as the same may be changed by judicial review. 
(Code 2017, § 16-263; Ord. No. 2040, § 1, 12-13-1993) 
Sec. 13-168. - Right of inspections. 
    Cameras shall be maintained in proper working order and positioned correctly at all times and shall be subject to inspection by the chief of police or designee. 
(Code 2017, § 16-264; Ord. No. 2040, § 1, 12-13-1993) 
Sec. 13-169. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision, section or paragraph of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00 or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days. That each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 2017, § 16-266; Ord. No. 2040, § 1, 12-13-1993) 
Chapter 14 - MOBILE HOMES, MOBILE HOME PARKS AND MOBILE HOME SUBDIVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home means any vehicle without motive power used or so manufactured or constructed as will permit the vehicle to be conveyed or used as a conveyance upon the public streets and highways, and so designed, constructed or reconstructed as will permit the vehicle to be used as a place for human habitation by one or more persons, but shall also include any such vehicle with motive power not registered as a motor vehicle in the state. This definition shall include modular homes. 
    Mobile home accessory building or structure means any awning, cabana, ramada, storage structure, carport, fence, windbreak or porch established for the use of the occupant of the mobile home upon a mobile home space. 
    Mobile home park means any site, lot, field or tract of land under one ownership, upon which two or more occupied mobile homes are harbored, either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle or enclosure used or intended for use as part of the equipment of such mobile home park. The term "mobile home park" shall not be construed to include mobile homes, buildings, tents or other structures temporarily maintained by any individual, educational institution or company on their own premises and used exclusively to house their own labor or students. 
    Mobile home space means a designated portion of a mobile home park designed for the accommodation of one mobile home and its accessory buildings or structures for the exclusive use of the occupants. 
    Mobile home subdivision means a grouping of mobile homes on not less than 20 acres of contiguous area, where each mobile home unit rests on a lot of separate ownership. The lots shall have been properly subdivided in accordance with chapter 20. 
    Travel trailer means a towed recreational vehicle up to 35 feet in length and a maximum of eight feet wide. 
(Code 2017, § 17-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a municipal infraction and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished accordingly. 
(Code 2017, § 17-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Compliance with chapter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any premises owned or occupied by him to be used in violation of the terms of this chapter. A violation of this chapter by the occupant of a mobile home shall raise the presumption that such violation was consented to by the person owning or occupying the premises. 
(Code 2017, § 17-3) 
Sec. 14-4. - Parking of mobile homes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any mobile home: 
(1)  On any street or other public place within the corporate limits of the city for a period of time in excess of two hours, and then only between the hours of sunrise and sunset, with the direction of the police operations division. 
(2)  For more than 48 hours on the premises of one occupied dwelling or business building, or more than 24 hours on any lot which is not a part of the premises of any occupied dwelling or business building, except in a mobile home park or mobile home subdivision. 
(Code 2017, § 17-4) 
Sec. 14-5. - Occupation of mobile home outside of park or subdivision. 
    A mobile home may be parked and occupied outside a mobile home park or subdivision only in the following instances: 
(1)  If the mobile home is used in conjunction with a construction project and not for living purposes. 
(2)  If the mobile home is used in the rendition of a public service. 
(3)  If the mobile home is used by public authorities in emergencies. 
(4)  If the mobile home is used as on-lot temporary housing for an owner and family while the owner's substantially damaged residence is being reconstructed for occupancy. The occupancy must have prior approval by the city council and shall be subject to the following considerations: 
a.  All property owners in the subdivision wherein the owner's lot is located shall consent, by signed petition, to the temporary housing. 
b.  All property owners not within the subdivision, but within 330 feet of the proposed on-lot utilization, shall consent, by signed petition, to the temporary housing. 
c.  Location of the mobile home for the temporary occupancy shall be satisfactory to the city council. 
d.  Satisfactory provisions shall be made for removal of the mobile home within two weeks of issuance of the occupancy approval for the reconstructed dwelling. In no case shall the mobile home remain in excess of one year. 
e.  Provision of all public utility services such as water, sewer and electric service shall be to the satisfaction of the city council. 
(5)  If the mobile home is provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency to be used as on-lot temporary housing for an owner and family whose residence has been substantially damaged due to a natural disaster that has been the subject of a Presidential Declaration. 
a.  The occupancy must have prior approval by the city staff of the department of community development and shall be subject to the following considerations: 
1.  The on-lot temporary location of the mobile home is necessary because the owner's residence is being reconstructed for occupancy. A building permit for the reconstruction of the owner's primary residence must be obtained within 30 days of the placement of the mobile home on the private lot. 
2.  All owners of abutting properties to the proposed on-lot utilization shall be given prior written notice. The written notice shall be sent by regular mail and certified mail to the property owner's last known address with no written objections received by the department of community development within ten days from the date of mailing. If written objections by abutting property owners are received by the department of community development within ten days of the date of mailing, the matter of the on-lot temporary location of the mobile home shall be considered by the city council at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting. If the applicant for the on-lot temporary location of the mobile home obtains written consent from all abutting property owners, city staff may grant the occupancy before the ten-day waiting period expires. 
3.  Location and proper elevation of the mobile home for the temporary occupancy shall be satisfactory to the department of community development. Owner shall provide a site plan and an elevation survey, if necessary, to city staff. 
4.  Provision of all public utility services such as water, sewer and electric service shall be to the satisfaction of the department of community development. 
5.  A signed contract between the owner and the city shall be executed prior to occupancy, which shall include satisfactory provisions for the removal of the mobile home at the owner's expense within two weeks of issuance of the occupancy approval for the reconstructed dwelling. In no case shall the mobile home remain on the private lot in excess of 18 months. 
b.  The provisions of subsection (5)a.1 of this section may be waived if there is substantial proof, satisfactory to the city council, that there are no other available sites for the mobile home to be located in any mobile home park or mobile home subdivision as determined by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. In the event there is a request pursuant to this subsection, the matter shall be considered by the city council at its next regularly scheduled city council meeting subsequent to the expiration of ten days from the date of mailing of notice to all abutting property owners. 
(Code 2017, § 17-5; Ord. No. 2663, § 1, 8-18-2008) 
Sec. 14-6. - Nonconforming mobile homes. 
(a)  Generally. Mobile homes in existence at the time of the adoption of Ordinance No. 1666, and which are not located in a mobile home park or subdivision complying with this chapter, are hereby declared to be nonconforming uses, and such mobile homes shall not be enlarged, extended, reconstructed, substituted or structurally altered when located outside a mobile home park or mobile home subdivision. Any mobile home in existence at the adoption of Ordinance No. 1666 which was not an authorized nonconforming use under previous ordinances regulating mobile homes shall not be authorized to continue as a nonconforming use pursuant to this chapter or amendments thereto. If such mobile home is damaged to an extent of more than 50 percent of its replacement value, or the mobile home is removed from its present location, it shall not thereafter be restored or placed in other than a mobile home park or mobile home subdivision. If the nonconforming use of a mobile home is discontinued for a period of one year, the mobile home must thereafter comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Permit required; contents of application. All mobile homes declared by this section to be a nonconforming use must apply for and obtain a permit as a nonconforming use from the city clerk. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The street and number of the premises whereon the mobile home is located. 
(2)  The owner of the premises, if other than the occupant of the mobile home. 
(3)  A site plan showing the proposed location of the mobile home on the lot. 
(4)  A statement of the nature and location of sanitary facilities used by the mobile home occupants. 
(5)  A statement that all wastewater from the mobile home is emptied into a proper sanitary sewer connected fixture. 
(6)  A statement that all garbage shall be disposed of in a sanitary manner. 
(7)  If rented, a certificate of occupancy from the minimum housing code inspector. 
(c)  Issuance of permit. If the application required in subsection (b) of this section contains the necessary true information, a permit shall be issued as a nonconforming use permit at no charge. 
(Code 2017, § 17-7) 
Sec. 14-7. - Minimum number of spaces in park or subdivision. 
    No mobile home park or subdivision, nor any initial stage thereof, shall contain less than 30 mobile home spaces. 
(Code 2017, § 17-8) 
Sec. 14-8. - Recreation areas in parks and subdivisions. 
    Not less than eight percent of the gross area of every mobile home park or subdivision shall be developed as recreation areas easily accessible to all park residents. Recreation areas may include, but are not limited to, such facilities as recreation buildings, adult recreation areas, child play areas and swimming pools. 
(Code 2017, § 17-9) 
Sec. 14-9. - Drainage of parks and subdivisions. 
    Each mobile home park or subdivision shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to ensure drainage free from stagnant pools of water. No sidewalks shall be used as drainageways. Drainage plans including retention areas shall be provided in accordance with city policy and the city engineer's specifications. 
(Code 2017, § 17-10) 
Sec. 14-10. - Off-street parking for parks and subdivisions. 
    Each mobile home park and subdivision shall provide two off-street parking spaces per mobile home space or mobile home lot. Each mobile home space or lot shall have two permanent concrete or asphalt surfaced off-street automobile parking spaces, with a minimum of 180 square feet per parking space. The mobile home space or lot off-street parking requirement may be included within the square foot requirements of the space or lot. 
(Code 2017, § 17-11) 
Sec. 14-11. - Screening in parks and subdivisions. 
    Fences, walls and plantings shall be required in mobile home parks and subdivisions to the extent needed to provide for adequate privacy and screening of objectionable views such as laundry drying yards, garbage and trash collection stations, nonresidential uses, playgrounds and rear yards of adjacent properties. 
(Code 2017, § 17-12) 
Sec. 14-12. - Site maintenance for parks and subdivisions. 
    A covenant shall run with the land, in favor of the city and all persons having a possessory interest in any portion of a mobile home park or subdivision, that the owners of the park or subdivision or their successors in interest will maintain all private facilities such as interior streets, parking areas, sidewalks, sewers and other utility services and plantings in compliance with city ordinances and the final development plan as approved by the city council. 
(Code 2017, § 17-13) 
Sec. 14-13. - Accessory buildings or structures. 
    All additions to mobile homes, accessory buildings, structures, awnings, cabanas, carports, basements and garages are subject to the building, electrical, plumbing, fire and zoning codes of the city. Inspection shall be required, permits obtained and associated permit fees paid in conformance with these or other applicable codes prior to occupancy by any person. 
(Code 2017, § 17-17) 
Sec. 14-14. - Conversion of mobile home; use for home occupation; certificate of occupancy required for rental. 
    No mobile home shall be converted, regardless of the lot area, nor shall any mobile home be utilized for a home occupation unless it meets the requirements for a home occupation as defined by the zoning chapter. If rented, the mobile home shall have a certificate of occupancy from the minimum housing code inspector. 
(Code 2017, § 17-18) 
Secs. 14-15-14-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 

Sec. 14-32. - Development procedures. 
(a)  Submission of preliminary plan. The owner of any tract of land comprising an area of not less than 20 acres wishing to develop a mobile home park shall submit to the city planning and zoning commission six copies of a preliminary plan of the proposed development, accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in such amount as established by the council from time to time. The preliminary plan shall show, in schematic form, the generally proposed location of all of the following: 
(1)  Mobile home spaces or lots. 
(2)  Site topographic features. 
(3)  Buildings, other than garages and other buildings accessory to particular mobile home spaces, and their proposed height, use and exterior design. 
(4)  Access drives. 
(5)  Public streets abutting or within the proposed development. 
(6)  Proposed private streets within the development. 
(7)  Proposed location of public or private utility services, lines or structures, including sewers, streets, sidewalks, fuel tanks and electrical, gas and water lines. 
(8)  Public or private recreation areas. 
(9)  Required peripheral yards. 
(10)  Private off-street parking facilities. 
(11)  Landscaping and planting areas. 
(12)  Walls and fences. 
(13)  Storage areas. 
(14)  Development stages and timing of each. 
(15)  Floodway and floodplain areas as shown by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(16)  Storm protection shelters for occupants of the park. 
(b)  Approval of preliminary plan. Following the requirements for amendment to the zoning chapter, the planning and zoning commission shall review the conformity of the proposed development with the standards of the comprehensive plan and with recognized principles of civic design, land use planning and landscaping architecture. The commission may approve the plan as submitted or, before approval, may require that the applicant modify, alter, adjust or amend the plan as the commission deems necessary, to the end that it preserves the intent and purpose of this article to promote public health, safety, morals and general welfare. 
(c)  Submission of final plan. If the city council approves the preliminary plan, the applicant shall submit six copies of a final development plan indicating not less than one stage of the proposed development, showing specifically and in detail the location of all items required on the preliminary schematic plan, and in addition: 
(1)  The location of all public streets, subdivisions and landowners within 300 feet of the contiguous holdings of the owner. 
(2)  The location and dimensions of the property's exterior boundaries, proposed mobile home spaces or lots, streets, drives and easements therein. 
(3)  The location of existing property lines, easements, buildings, tree masses, soil types and other physical features which may affect the final development. 
(4)  The location and width of proposed and existing streets, highways, roads and pedestrian ways. 
(5)  The location of public and private parks and open spaces. 
(6)  Lot and block numbers of proposed and existing lots and mobile home spaces. 
(7)  North arrow, scale, date, and the subdivision's or park's name, address and legal description. 
(8)  The location of solid waste receptacles, sidewalks, lighting facilities, common buildings, service buildings and storm shelters. 
(9)  Landscaping plan. 
(10)  The location of utility easements, lines and hydrants. 
(11)  Street names and address or lot numbers. 
(12)  The location of floodway and floodplain areas. 
(13)  Locations for mail pickup and delivery services. 
(d)  Required engineering data. The applicant shall also submit complete engineering data covering cross sections, profiles and proposed grades for the improvements required, all to the satisfaction of the city engineer. 
(e)  Inspection and certification of improvements. Provision shall be made for inspection and certification of completion of all improvements by a registered engineer in the state, other than a city-employed engineer, prior to occupancy of any lot. 
(f)  Approval of final plan. The final development plan shall be reviewed by the commission for compliance with the preliminary plan. After no more than 60 days, the commission shall forward its recommendations to the city council. After final approval by the council, a plan of the district shall be filed with the building official and maintained as a permanent part of the records of the city. 
(Code 2017, § 17-36) 
Sec. 14-33. - State licenses required prior to issuance of occupancy permit. 
    Any owner of any mobile home park shall obtain all required state licenses prior to issuance of an occupancy permit by the city for any lot, space or accessory structure. 
(Code 2017, § 17-37) 
Sec. 14-34. - Identification map; lot numbers. 
(a)  A logical and systematic method shall be used in preparing an identification map of all mobile home spaces, streets and service buildings located in a mobile home park. This map shall meet the requirements of the fire operations division and be filed as a permanent part of its records. 
(b)  Lot numbers a minimum of three inches in height shall be placed on a post a minimum of four feet in height, the posts being located in a systematic manner consistently on each space throughout the mobile home park. 
(Code 2017, § 17-38) 
Sec. 14-35. - Utilities. 
    Each mobile home space in a mobile home park shall be provided with utility connections for water, sanitary sewer and electricity. The construction of all utilities, including telephone, street lighting and television wires and cables, shall be in compliance with applicable ordinances, and utilities shall be installed entirely underground by the developer thereof in accordance with the rules, regulations and specifications of the public utility or agency providing such service. 
(Code 2017, § 17-39) 
Sec. 14-36. - Lighting. 
    Walkways and roadways in a mobile home park shall be properly maintained and shall be lighted at night to provide an average maintained horizontal illumination of 0.4 footcandle in all walkway and roadway areas. 
(Code 2017, § 17-40) 
Sec. 14-37. - Streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  Each mobile home site in a mobile home park shall have direct access to a street which is constructed in accordance with city specifications for residential streets and which has a minimum width of not less than 22 feet. On collector streets within the park or where on-street parking is extensively utilized, wider streets may be required. These streets shall be maintained in good condition as provided for by section 14-12. 
(b)  Common sidewalks shall be provided along all entrance streets and in areas of high pedestrian traffic such as in the vicinity of the community buildings and recreation facilities. Sidewalks shall be at least four feet wide and constructed in accordance with city specifications, including specifications for handicapped ramps. 
(c)  Individual walks shall be provided to connect all mobile home sites to common sidewalks, to paved streets, or to paved driveways or parking spaces connected to a paved street. Such individual walks shall be at least two feet wide and constructed of asphalt or Portland cement concrete pavement. 
(Code 2017, § 17-41) 
Sec. 14-38. - Distance between structures; patios. 
    Mobile homes in a mobile home park shall be so located on each space that there shall be at least a 20-foot clearance between any mobile home and another mobile home or any principal building within the mobile home park. Accessory structures attached to mobile homes shall be considered an integral part of the mobile home in determining clearance requirements. In addition, each mobile home space shall be provided with a paved patio of at least 80 square feet. Accessory buildings may not be closer than five feet to a lot line or eight feet to a mobile home unit or other principal structure. 
(Code 2017, § 17-42) 
Sec. 14-39. - Lot area. 
    Each mobile home lot area in a mobile home park shall not be less than 3,500 square feet. 
(Code 2017, § 17-43) 
Sec. 14-40. - Lot setbacks. 
    Individual lots in a mobile home park shall provide a minimum of a 20-foot front yard, ten-foot rear yard and five-foot side yards. 
(Code 2017, § 17-44) 
Sec. 14-41. - Lot width and depth. 
    Individual lots in a mobile home park shall not be less than 90 feet deep or 35 feet wide. 
(Code 2017, § 17-45) 
Sec. 14-42. - Accessory buildings and service connections to comply with applicable codes. 
    The accessory buildings and service connections of all mobile home units in a mobile home park shall be provided in accordance with applicable building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, housing, fire and gas codes. Permits and associated fees shall be required for all construction, additions, modifications and demolition, where applicable by such codes or other codes. 
(Code 2017, § 17-46) 
Sec. 14-43. - Occupancy by travel trailers. 
    No place, site, lot or space shall be established or maintained for the occupancy of a travel trailer in a mobile home park, except that a mobile home park or a portion of a mobile home park may be designated an approved area for travel trailers by the city in the approval process set out in this article. No travel trailer shall occupy a mobile home space for 30 days or more without meeting the requirements of this section. 
(Code 2017, § 17-47) 
Secs. 14-44-14-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOME SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 14-75. - Development procedures. 
(a)  Submission of preliminary plan. The owner of any tract of land comprising an area of not less than 20 acres wishing to develop a mobile home subdivision shall submit to the city planning and zoning commission six copies of a preliminary plan of the proposed development, accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in such amount as established by the council from time to time. The preliminary plan shall show, in schematic form, the generally proposed location of all of the following: 
(1)  Mobile home lots. 
(2)  Site topographic features. 
(3)  Buildings, other than garages and other buildings accessory to particular mobile home spaces, and their proposed height, use and exterior design. 
(4)  Access drives. 
(5)  Public streets abutting and within the proposed development. 
(6)  Proposed location of public utility services, lines or structures, including sewers, streets, sidewalks and electrical, gas and water lines. 
(7)  Public or private recreation areas. 
(8)  Required peripheral yards. 
(9)  Private off-street parking facilities. 
(10)  Landscaping and planting areas. 
(11)  Walls and fences. 
(12)  Storage areas. 
(13)  Development stages and timing of each. 
(14)  Floodway and floodplain areas as shown by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(15)  Storm protection shelters for occupants of the subdivision. 
(b)  Approval of preliminary plan. Following the requirements for amendment to the zoning chapter, the planning and zoning commission shall review the conformity of the proposed development with the standards of the comprehensive plan, and with recognized principles of civic design, land use planning and landscape architecture. The commission may approve the plan as submitted or, before approval, may require that the applicant modify, alter, adjust or amend the plan as the commission deems necessary to the end that it preserves the intent and purpose of this article to promote public health, safety, morals and general welfare. 
(c)  Submission of final plan or detailed site plan. If the city council approves the preliminary plan, the applicant shall submit six copies of a final development plan or detailed site plan, accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in such amount as established by the city council from time to time. The final development plan or detailed site plan shall indicate not less than one stage of the proposed development, showing specifically and in detail the location of all items required on the preliminary schematic plan and, in addition: 
(1)  The location of all public streets, subdivisions and landowners within 300 feet of the proposed subdivision. 
(2)  The location and dimensions of the property's exterior boundaries, proposed mobile home spaces or lots, streets, drives and easements therein. 
(3)  The location of existing property lines, streets, easements, buildings, tree masses, soil types and other physical features which may affect the final development. 
(4)  The location and width of proposed and existing streets, highways, roads, and pedestrian ways. 
(5)  The location of public and private parks and open spaces and their improvements. 
(6)  Street names and numbers of proposed and existing lots. 
(7)  North arrow, scale, date, and the subdivision's or park's name, address and legal description. 
(8)  The location of solid waste receptacles, sidewalks, lighting facilities, common buildings, service buildings and storm shelters. 
(9)  Landscaping plan. 
(10)  The location of utility easements, lines and hydrants. 
(11)  The location of floodway and floodplain areas. 
(d)  Submission of homeowner's agreement. The applicant shall also submit a draft homeowner's agreement, including a declaration of covenants, conditions and restrictions, articles of incorporation and bylaws for the homeowner's association controlling all common areas if such means exist in the proposed site plan. The agreement shall be prepared in accordance with the Horizontal Property Act of the state. 
(e)  Review by planning and zoning commission. The final development or detailed site plan and homeowner's agreement plan shall be reviewed by the commission for compliance with the preliminary plan. After no more than 60 days the commission shall forward its recommendations to the city council. After final approval by the council, a plan of the district shall be filed with the building official and maintained as a permanent part of the records of the city. 
(f)  Approval of final plan and other documents. Upon approval of the detailed site plan, or in conjunction with the plan, the developer shall submit a preliminary plat, final plat and final draft of the homeowner's agreement, prepared and filed in accordance with chapter 18, for planning and zoning commission and city council review and approval. All city policies with regard to public improvements and their construction standards and design shall apply to all public improvements in the plat. The planning and zoning commission and city council may approve the plats, owner's dedication and homeowner's agreements as submitted or, before approval, may require that the applicant modify, alter, adjust or amend the materials as the planning and zoning commission and city council deem necessary, to the end that it preserves the intent and purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare. The preliminary and final plats shall be exempt from the processing fees required by chapter 18 if fees have previously been paid for preliminary plan and final development or detailed site plan approval. 
(g)  Installation of improvements. Before the final plat of the subdivided area shall be approved and recorded, the subdivider shall make and install the improvements required in the detailed site plan and preliminary plan in accordance with the construction plans approved by the city engineer. If the improvements have not been constructed, inspected and certified complete by the city engineer, then the subdivider shall enter into a contract with the city to ensure completion of the improvement within a specific time. The performance of such contract shall be secured by the filing of a bond or cash, to be approved by the council. The bond or cash shall not be less than the appropriate cost of the improvements as estimated by the city engineer. 
(Code 2017, § 17-66) 
Sec. 14-76. - Identification map. 
    A logical and systematic method shall be used in preparing an identification map of all mobile home lots, streets and service buildings located in a mobile home subdivision. This map shall meet the requirements of the fire operations division and be filed as a permanent part of its records. 
(Code 2017, § 17-67) 
Sec. 14-77. - Utilities. 
    Each mobile home lot in a mobile home subdivision shall be provided with utility connections for natural or LP gas, public water, public sanitary sewer and electricity. The construction of all utilities, including telephone, street lighting and television wires and cables, shall be in compliance with applicable ordinances, and utilities shall be installed entirely underground by the developer thereof in accordance with the rules, regulations and specifications of the public utility or agency providing such service. 
(Code 2017, § 17-68) 
Sec. 14-78. - Lighting. 
    Private walkways and roadways in a mobile home subdivision shall be properly maintained and shall be lighted at night to provide an average maintained horizontal illumination of 0.4 footcandle in all walkway and roadway areas. Public streets and sidewalks shall be lighted in accordance with the rules, regulations and specifications of the city and public utilities. 
(Code 2017, § 17-69) 
Sec. 14-79. - Streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  Each mobile home lot in a mobile home subdivision shall have direct access to a public street which is constructed in accordance with city specifications for residential streets. 
(b)  Public sidewalks shall be provided along all streets. Sidewalks shall be at least four feet wide and constructed in accordance with city specifications, including specifications for handicapped ramps. 
(c)  All driveways and curb openings shall be constructed in accordance with the city engineer's specifications and in accordance with chapter 19. 
(Code 2017, § 17-70) 
Sec. 14-80. - Distance between structures. 
    Mobile homes in a mobile home subdivision shall be so located on each lot that there shall be at least a 20-foot clearance between any mobile home and another mobile home or any principal building within the mobile home park. Accessory structures attached to mobile homes shall be considered an integral part of the mobile home in determining clearance requirements. Accessory buildings may not be closer than five feet to a lot line or eight feet to a mobile home unit or other principal structure. 
(Code 2017, § 17-71) 
Sec. 14-81. - Lot area. 
    Each mobile home lot area in a mobile home subdivision shall not be less than 5,000 square feet. 
(Code 2017, § 17-72) 
Sec. 14-82. - Lot setbacks. 
    Individual lots in a mobile home subdivision shall provide a minimum of a 20-foot front yard, a ten-foot rear yard and side yards equal to ten percent of the lot width, with no side yard less than five feet on any one side. Corner lots shall provide front yard setbacks on both street sides. 
(Code 2017, § 17-73) 
Sec. 14-83. - Lot width and depth. 
    Individual lots in a mobile home subdivision shall not be less than 90 feet deep or 50 feet wide at the building line. Each lot shall have at least 40 feet of street frontage. 
(Code 2017, § 17-74) 
Sec. 14-84. - Service connections. 
    All lot services in a mobile home subdivision shall be provided in accordance with applicable building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, housing, fire and gas codes. 
(Code 2017, § 17-75) 
Sec. 14-85. - Occupancy by travel trailers. 
    No place, site, lot or space shall be established or maintained for the occupancy of a travel trailer in a mobile home subdivision. 
(Code 2017, § 17-76) 
Chapter 15 - NUISANCES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Public nuisances prohibited; authority to abate. 
    The creation or maintenance of a nuisance is unlawful and is prohibited. The mayor or the mayor's designee is authorized to abate nuisances either by issuance of a municipal infraction punishable as provided in section 1-9(c)(10), or by administrative abatement procedures set forth in this article. 
(Code 2017, § 18-1; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007) 
Sec. 15-2. - Nuisance defined; certain acts, conditions declared as nuisances. 
    Whatever is injurious to the senses or an obstruction to the free use of property so as essentially to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property by the public or community shall be deemed a nuisance. Nuisances shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The erecting, continuing or using of any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive smells or other annoyances, becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort or property of individuals or the public. 
(2)  The causing, permitting or allowing of any refuse, solid waste, garbage, noxious substances, hazardous wastes, junk or salvage materials to be collected or to remain in any place. The term "noxious substances" includes, but is not limited to, substances, solid or fluid, which are offensive, detrimental to health, hurtful or dangerous, including any dead animal or portion thereof, together with human or animal excrement. 
(3)  The causing, preventing or allowing any refuse, solid waste, garbage, noxious substances or hazardous wastes, junk, salvage material or other offensive substances to be thrown, left or deposited in or upon any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, park, public square, lot, whether vacant or occupied, or upon any pond or pool of water. 
(4)  The obstructing or impeding, without legal authority, of the passage of any navigable river, harbor or collection of water. 
(5)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist any stagnant water standing on any property, including any container or material kept in such a condition that water can accumulate and stagnate therein. 
(6)  The corrupting or rendering unwholesome or impure of the water of any river, stream or pond, or unlawfully diverting the river, stream or pond from its natural course or state, to the injury or prejudice of others. 
(7)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist any ditch, drain or watercourse which is now or hereafter may be constructed so as to prevent or unduly interfere with the surface and overflow water drainage from adjacent lands, or any stormwater detention basin not properly maintained, as determined by the city engineer. 
(8)  Facilities for the storage or processing of sewage, such as septic tanks, cesspools and drain fields, which have failed or do not function properly, or which are overflowing, leaking or emanating odors; or septic tanks, cisterns and cesspools which are abandoned or no longer in use, unless properly emptied and filled with clean fill; or any cesspool or septic tank which does not comply with the county department of health regulations. 
(9)  The obstructing or encumbering, by fences, buildings, structures, signs or otherwise, of the public roads, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places or burying grounds. 
(10)  Any gathering of persons or vehicles upon a public street or sidewalk or any use of property abutting a public street or sidewalk which obstructs pedestrian or vehicular traffic or other lawful use of streets or sidewalks, except as permitted by permit or ordinance. 
(11)  Houses of ill fame, kept for the purpose of prostitution and lewdness, gambling houses, or places resorted to by persons using controlled substances, as defined in Iowa Code § 204.101(6), in violation of law, or houses where drunkenness, quarreling, fighting or breaches of the peace are carried on or permitted to the disturbance of others. 
(12)  Unoccupied buildings or unoccupied portions of buildings which are unsecured or abandoned. 
(13)  Billboards, signboards and advertising signs, whether erected and constructed on public or private property, which so obstruct and impair the view of any portion or part of a public street, avenue, highway, boulevard or alley or of a railroad or street railway track as to render dangerous the use thereof. 
(14)  Cotton-bearing cottonwood trees and all other cotton-bearing poplar trees. 
(15)  The depositing or storing of inflammable junk, such as old rags, rope, cordage, rubber, bones and paper, by dealers in such articles, within the fire limits of the city, unless it is in a building of fireproof construction. 
(16)  The depositing or allowing the depositing of any mud, dirt, gravel or other debris on any public street, alley, sidewalk, or other public property. 
(17)  The emission of dense smoke, noxious fumes or fly ash in the city. The city may provide the necessary rules for inspection, regulation and control. 
(18)  Dense growth of all weeds, vines, brush or other vegetation, including dead bushes, and dead woody plants, or other overgrown or unkempt bushes or other growth, in the city so as to constitute a health, safety or fire hazard. 
(19)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist conditions which are conducive to the harborage or breeding of vermin; or allowing to exist infestations of vermin, such as rats, mice, skunks, snakes, bats, starlings, pigeons, wasps, cockroaches or flies. 
(20)  Trees infected with infectious disease as identified by the city arborist or operations and maintenance division manager; or any dead, diseased or damaged trees or plant materials which may harbor serious insect or disease pests or disease injurious to other trees or plant materials, or any healthy tree in such a state of deterioration that any part of such tree is likely to fall and damage property or cause injury to persons. The stump of any tree that is removed must be cut flush with ground level, unless the stump is made into a decorative, tasteful yard element. 
(21)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist any noxious weeds described as a nuisance in section 17-246. 
(22)  The following items stored in outdoor areas or in partially enclosed sheds, lean-tos or other structures not totally enclosed by structural walls, roof and properly functioning doors: building materials not part of an active building project authorized by a current city building permit, abandoned, inoperable vehicles or junk vehicles (as defined in section 15-33), non-registered or unlicensed vehicles, auto parts, miscellaneous steel, plastic, rubber or metal parts or junk, tires, packing boxes, wooden pallets, tree limbs, brush piles, discarded lumber, not including neatly stacked and cut fire wood, broken or unused furniture and appliances, any upholstered or finished furniture intended for indoor usage such as couches, beds, mattresses, desks, chairs, shelving or wooden tables, other broken or unused household furnishings or equipment including carpeting, appliances and other typical household items intended for indoor usage, plastic tarps, trash bags containing leaves, debris, garbage or other items, trash and garbage not properly contained within a trash disposal container or any other discarded or miscellaneous item or items not normally required in the day to day use of the exterior area of the property, when stored continuously in excess of 48 hours on any portion of any property outside of a totally enclosed structure located on the property. 
(23)  Any attractive nuisance dangerous to children in the form of abandoned vehicles, abandoned or broken equipment, including abandoned refrigerators, hazardous pools, ponds, excavations, materials, including building material, debris, or neglected machinery. 
(24)  Real property maintained in such condition as it becomes so defective, unsightly, or in such condition of deterioration or disrepair that the same causes substantial depreciation of the property values of the surrounding properties or is materially detrimental to properties and improvements. 
(25)  Any violation of the provisions requiring removal of accumulations of ice and snow set forth in chapter 19. 
(26)  Any wall, fence or hedge in such condition as to constitute a hazard to persons or property or to cause depreciation in the value of any adjacent or nearby property. 
(27)  Any discarded or unused material on real property that is not consistent with the condition and visual appearance of surrounding adjacent real properties. Types of unacceptable materials include those items enumerated in subsection (13) of this section and also include dirt and gravel piles, rock piles, incomplete landscaping projects, eroded soil areas, pits, holes and excavations. 
(28)  The causing of the accumulation of building debris and/or construction materials, tools, equipment or machinery on any property within the city limits of the city after the expiration of a building permit as outlined in chapter 7, the occasioning of which becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort, or property of individuals or the public. 
(29)  Creating, maintaining, causing or allowing to exist for a continuous period of more than 30 days, any manmade excavation, hole, or other depression in the ground in or on any lot or parcel of land in the city of a depth of more than three feet below the surrounding grade, other than as part of the active construction of a building or other structure on the lot which will ultimately close in and completely cover such excavation, hole or depression. Upon a finding by the court that the owner of the lot or parcel of land has violated the provisions of this subsection, the lot owner shall be required to fill in any such excavation, hole or depression and grade the same to a topographic elevation equal to or level with the surrounding adjacent grade, and seed the site with grass or similar vegetative ground cover, and take reasonable measures to ensure the proper germination of the planted vegetation. 
(30)  On properties being used by an allowable commercial use, any items stored on the property that are not normally utilized in the daily operation of the commercial use must be stored in structures totally enclosed by structural walls, roof and properly functioning doors. 
(31)  All structures, both commercial and residential, including detached accessory structures, on any commercial, residential, agricultural or industrial property shall be free from significant structural defects. The term "free from significant structural defect" means: 
a.  The roof and roofing material are of such a nature and condition that they do not permit water, snow or ice to penetrate into the structure. Roofing materials shall be in good condition and made up of consistent materials and consistent coloration throughout the roof area. 
b.  Drainage gutters and downspouts are securely attached to the structure and in proper functioning order. 
c.  All exterior trim and exterior exposed surfaces, including siding materials, must be sound, in good condition and securely attached to the structure. 
d.  Exterior walls must be free of holes and made of a consistent material, such that patches or repairs consisting of dissimilar materials or colors compared to the prevailing surface material of the exterior walls are not present. 
e.  The foundation of the structure is sound, capable of supporting the structure and not deteriorated to the point that failure is judged to be inevitable, but not necessarily imminent. The foundation shall be plumb and free from cracks, breaks and holes so as to prevent the entry of animals. 
f.  Windows and doors, including outer screen or storm windows and doors, must be intact, containing no holes, squarely hung with properly operating latches or locks so as to be securely closed, and where the windows have intact glass or normal window material that allows the entry of light with no holes in said window surface areas. 
g.  All points of egress/ingress into and out of the structure must be of a secure and safe design and made of standard building materials and must also provide clear and easy access via properly installed steps, porches, entryway landings and hand rails that are intact, with no protruding or loose boards or surface materials causing a hazard, and which provide ready access to all points of entry to the structure. 
h.  Exterior wall surfaces are properly painted and/or maintained with appropriate exterior wall materials, including wood, vinyl, steel or metal siding materials, stucco or exterior insulation finish system (EIFS) materials, brick or similar masonry materials, that are in all cases intact, not in a condition of deterioration, are of uniform coloration and are not patched with dissimilar materials. Plastic wrap material shall not be considered to be an acceptable siding material. No flaking or chipped paint or outer loose material dominates or detracts from the exterior appearance of the structure. 
i.  All fencing, including gates, shall be maintained in good condition, free from damage, breaks, holes or missing structural members. All fencing shall be of consistent materials and coloration. 
j.  Detached accessory structures, including garages and storage sheds, must conform to the standards outlined above. In addition, all doors and windows must be of functional design and materials and in proper working order. No plastic wrap material or tarps shall be used to substitute for doorways or windows. 
k.  All exterior wires which are hanging or unsecured on the exterior of the structure must be fastened to the structure in order to avoid life safety issues. 
l.  Reconstruction and repair: Materials and practices used in the reconstruction/repair of any building structure, whether of roofing materials, siding materials, foundation, walls, windows, doorways, entryways or detached accessory structures shall be of standard quality and appearance, consistent with currently applicable International Building Code requirements and consistent with the appearance and character of the structure under repair and consistent with other properties in the immediate vicinity of the premises. 
m.  Vacant structures: All vacant structures shall comply with the above-cited maintenance provisions with the exception that windows and doors may be secured with boards or other materials intended to provide security and protection to the structure. All vandalized portions of the structure must be promptly repaired including repainting of areas that are defaced with paint or graffiti. 
(32)  All real property defaced by graffiti vandalism which is visible to the public view. 
(33)  Any hazardous thing or condition on property which may contribute to injury of any person present on the property, including, but not limited to, open holes, open foundations, open wells, or dangerous trees or limbs. 
(34)  Any thing or condition on property creating a fire hazard, as determined by the fire chief, or in violation of chapter 9. 
(35)  Any thing or condition on property creating an imminent threat to human health or in violation of any health or sanitation law. 
(36)  Building construction sites maintained in violation of chapter 7, buildings. 
(37)  Any violation of the noise ordinance set forth in article III of this chapter. 
(38)  Any violation of junk vehicles set forth in article II of this chapter. 
(39)  Any area located outside of any building or structure on private property, whose sidewalks, walkways, stairs, driveways, parking lots, parking spaces or similar areas are not kept in a proper state of repair, or are not maintained free from hazardous conditions. 
(40)  Any vegetation that creates mold, blocks private sidewalks, entrances, doors or windows, or which creates other obnoxious or unsafe situations. 
(41)  Any vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer which, although operable, contains stored gasoline or other fuel, paper, cardboard, wood or other combustible materials, garbage, refuse, solid waste, debris, or the like. 
(42)  Residing in, or living in, or using for night-time living accommodation purposes, such as sleeping activities, making preparation to sleep overnight, including the laying down of bedding for the purpose of sleeping, a tent, camper, motor home, travel trailer, camper, recreational vehicle, or any other vehicle, on any private property in the city for a period of more than 30 days, except as otherwise expressly provided for in section 26-176(c)(13) or 26-177(e)(17). 
(Code 2017, § 18-2; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007; Ord. No. 2882, §§ 1-4, 9-19-2016; Ord. No. 2942, § 1, 6-3-2019) 
Sec. 15-3. - Additional conditions subject to chapter. 
    The requirement of the removal, correction or abatement of nuisances enumerated in this chapter shall not be confined to the things known to the common law or specially declared by law as nuisances, but shall also extend to anything constituting a nuisance in fact, including as well anything designated in this Code and judicially declared as dangerous, offensive, unhealthy or obstructive. 
(Code 2017, § 18-3; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007) 
Sec. 15-4. - Responsibility for abatement; abatement defined. 
(a)  The owner, agent, lessee, occupant or other person in charge of any building or premises where any of the things forbidden by this chapter exist, or whence any of such things have originated, or any person responsible for the existence, origin or continuance of any of such things, shall correct, remove or abate such thing without delay. 
(b)  Abatement may include, but not be limited to, repair, removal, cleaning, extermination, cutting, mowing, grading, draining, securing, repairing a building or structure, boarding unoccupied buildings, barricading or fencing, removing dangerous portions of buildings or structures, and demolition of dangerous structures or abandoned buildings. 
(Code 2017, § 18-4; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007) 
Sec. 15-5. - Abatement by city after notice; procedure; payment of costs. 
(a)  In case of the failure of any person to correct, remove or abate a nuisance on written notice issued by the mayor or the mayor's designee, served in the manner of an original notice, or by certified mail to the last known address of the owner, agent, lessee, occupant or other person in charge of the building or premises where the nuisance exists, and designating the time allowed for such removal, correction or abatement, the time thus allowed depending on the urgency of the case, then and at once upon such failure the mayor or the mayor's designee shall cause the nuisance to be summarily removed, corrected or abated, and the mayor or the mayor's designee, chief of police and such other officers as may be directed by the city council or mayor or the mayor's designee therefor shall have the power at all times during the daytime to enter into and upon the premises and make thorough examination thereof for the purpose of ascertaining its sanitary conditions or the existence of nuisances therein, and to do whatever may be necessary to remove, correct or abate such nuisances. 
(b)  Whenever the owner, occupant or agent of any premises upon which any nuisance is found is unknown or cannot be found, then the nuisance may be abated without notice. 
(c)  Emergency abatement procedure. When the mayor or the mayor's designee determines that a nuisance exists on a property and constitutes an imminent and compelling danger to health, safety, or welfare of persons or property, the mayor or the mayor's designee is authorized to abate or have abated the nuisance without prior notice and opportunity of hearing. The cost of any such emergency abatement procedure may be assessed against the property for collection in the same manner as property taxes as set forth in subsection (d) of this section. However, prior to such assessment, the city shall first provide the property owner or other responsible person an opportunity to appear and be heard as provided in section 15-6. 
(d)  Whenever any nuisance is found on any premises and is abated under the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance, the city officers shall report to the council a detailed statement of the costs thereof, which shall be paid in the first instance by the city, together with a description of the premises in or upon which the nuisance was found and the name of the owner or occupant of such premises, if known. The city shall either institute an action in the name of the city against the owner, tenant or other occupant of the premises for the recovery of the expenses incurred in abating such nuisance, or, if the city council so directs, the expense of abatement shall be assessed upon the premises chargeable therewith and become a lien thereon, or the city may both institute such an action and assess a lien against the property. The city clerk shall thereupon certify for taxation purposes and for purposes of the establishment of a property lien to the county treasurer all such abatement costs, together with an administrative expense of $5.00, to be collected in the same manner as a property tax. 
(e)  Costs of abatement. Abatement costs shall include, but shall not be limited to, the cost of removing or eliminating the nuisance, the cost of investigation, such as title searches, inspection and testing, the costs of notification, filing costs and other related administrative costs and any other costs or expenses incurred by the city in the abatement of the nuisance. 
(Code 2017, § 18-5; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007) 
Sec. 15-6. - Abatement hearing; appeal. 
    Any person ordered to abate a nuisance as provided in section 15-5 may have a hearing before the administration committee of the city council, or such other person or committee as the administration committee may designate, as to whether a nuisance exists, and what steps must be taken to abate the nuisance. A request for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the city clerk on or before the date stated in the notice of abatement issued by the city, or it shall be conclusively presumed that a nuisance exists and that it must be abated as ordered. Within 14 days after the conclusion of the hearing, the administration committee or its designee shall render a written decision as to whether a nuisance exists, and shall notify the city and the appealing party of its decision by ordinary mail. If the administration committee or its designee finds that a nuisance exists, it shall include in the notification and order what steps must be taken to abate the nuisance and the time within which such steps must be taken. 
(Code 2017, § 18-6; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007) 
Sec. 15-7. - Resisting, obstructing or interfering with city officer. 
    Any person who resists, obstructs, or otherwise interferes with any city officer who has been designated by the mayor or the mayor's designee to enter upon and inspect any premises, or to correct or abate any nuisance on such premises, shall be guilty of a municipal infraction and shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 2017, § 18-7; Ord. No. 2625, § 1, 5-29-2007) 
Secs. 15-8-15-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INOPERABLE VEHICLES 

Sec. 15-33. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby declared that the parking, dismantling, or storage of inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts upon public or private property within the corporate limits of the city is a threat to the public health, welfare and safety and constitutes a nuisance. 
(Code 2017, § 18-36; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-34. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the City of Cedar Falls. 
    Dismantle means to take apart; disassemble; tear down. 
    Inoperable vehicle means any vehicle that has any one of the following characteristics: 
(1)  Any vehicle that does not display current state registration. 
(2)  Any vehicle with a broken, or missing windshield, missing window, headlight, or any other missing glass. 
(3)  Any vehicle with a broken, loose, or missing fender, door, bumper, hood, roof, steering wheel, trunk lid, muffler or tailpipe. 
(4)  Any vehicle that is the habitat of rats, mice, snakes or any other vermin or insects. 
(5)  Any vehicle that lacks an engine, one or more wheels, or other parts that render the vehicle inoperable, such as a truck without an engine or a trailer missing a wheel. 
(6)  Any vehicle that does not have all tires inflated. 
(7)  Any vehicle that is not capable of moving in both forward and reverse gears. 
(8)  Any vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer which contains stored gasoline or other fuel, paper, cardboard, wood or other combustible materials, garbage, refuse, solid waste, debris, or the like. 
    Parking means the placement on public or private property of any vehicle or vehicle part for any period of time not exceeding 48 hours. 
    Permit means to allow or fail to prevent. 
    Person means any firm, person, partnership or corporation. 
    Storage means the placement on public or private property of any vehicle or vehicle part for any consecutive period of time exceeding 48 hours. 
    Vehicle means any implement of conveyance designed or used for the transportation of people or materials on land, water, or air, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, snowmobiles, boats, airplanes, helicopters, tractors, trailers, campers, motor homes, wagons, etc. 
    Vehicle part means an individual component or subassembly of a vehicle. 
(Code 2017, § 18-37; Ord. No. 2882, § 5, 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 15-35. - Violation declared. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, dismantle, or store any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part or to permit the parking, dismantling, or storage of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part other than as herein provided by section 15-43. 
(Code 2017, § 18-38; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-36. - Owner of motor vehicle or vehicle parts prima facie responsible. 
(a)  The owner of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part is prima facie responsible for the parking, dismantling, or storing of such vehicle or vehicle part upon public or private property in violation of this article. Any owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within the city upon which one or more inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts are found is prima facie responsible for permitting such parking, dismantling, or storage of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part upon such property in violation of this article. No person shall be charged with more than one violation of this article for any one vehicle. The owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part and the owner of real estate upon which such inoperable vehicle or vehicle part are found may both be charged. 
(b)  Each day the owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part and the owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within the city is found in violation of this article and permits the violation to continue after the notice period provided in section 15-38 shall be a new violation of this article. 
(Code 2017, § 18-39; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-37. - Notice. 
(a)  Upon discovery of any inoperable motor vehicle or vehicle part stored upon private property within the corporate limits of this city, any police officer, or other city officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, may notify in writing the owner of said motor vehicle or vehicle part, and the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored that: 
(1)  The motor vehicle or vehicle part constitutes a violation under the provisions of this article. 
(2)  The owner must abate the violation by removing or repairing same in accordance with the terms of section 15-38. 
(3)  Failure to remove or repair same shall be sufficient cause for removal and disposal by the city and assessment of costs. 
(b)  In the alternative, the city may cause to be issued to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle part, or to the owner of the property on which the vehicle or vehicle part is found, a citation for a municipal infraction setting forth the violation of this article and seeking an order of removal on conviction. 
(c)  The notice provided by this section relates only to the abatement of a violation of this article and is not an element of a violation, provided, however, that a second and/or any subsequent citation shall not be issued until after the notice provided herein. 
(Code 2017, § 18-40; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-38. - Duty of owner to remove or repair. 
    The owner of the inoperable vehicle or vehicle part which violates the provisions of this article, or the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored, shall within ten days after service of a written notice from any police officer, or other city officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, remove or repair same. 
(Code 2017, § 18-41; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-39. - Abatement. 
    If the owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part or the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored, shall fail to remove or repair same in accordance with the requirements of section 15-38, any police officer, or other city officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, may abate such violation by causing same to be towed to a place of safekeeping and the cost of the towing and storage shall be charged to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle part, or to the owner of the property upon which it was parked, dismantled, or stored. 
(Code 2017, § 18-42; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-40. - Auction sale. 
    Inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts impounded by the city may be sold at auction as provided in Iowa Code § 321.89 for motor vehicles otherwise impounded. All revenues derived from the sale of inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts, however, shall accrue to the city. 
(Code 2017, § 18-43; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-41. - Interpretation. 
    Where any other ordinance of the city is more stringent or more restrictive than the requirements set forth herein, or any ordinance of the city affords any other remedy, nothing herein shall be construed to waive or limit the use of and/or compliance with the provisions of such other ordinance. 
(Code 2017, § 18-44; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-42. - Violation. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of this article may be charged as a municipal infraction or a misdemeanor. 
(Code 2017, § 18-45; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Sec. 15-43. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts parked, stored, or dismantled: 
(1)  Within a garage or other fully enclosed building. 
(2)  Within a fully enclosed vehicle. 
(3)  On the premises of a business operating in a properly zoned area, when necessary to the operation of said business, as authorized under the zoning chapter of the city. 
(Code 2017, § 18-46; Ord. No. 2760, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Secs. 15-44-15-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE 

Sec. 15-75. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    A-weighted sound level means the total sound level of all sound as measured with a sound level meter using the A weighting network. The unit of measurement is the decibel on the A weighting network, which is abbreviated db(A). 
    Animal or fowl means any living creature, domestic or wild, retained by and associated with a dwelling or other premises as a pet or beast of labor, or for other purposes which serve the wishes of the owner thereof.
