(e)  Any sidewalk cafe area that serves alcoholic beverages must be situated so that no part of the sidewalk cafe area is less than 300 feet from the boundary of any area of the city that is zoned residential under the zoning chapter. 
(f)  No part of the sidewalk cafe area shall be located within that portion of the public sidewalk lying between the lines formed by the extension of the exterior building lines to the adjacent intersecting streets, or within ten feet of any public alley. 
(g)  The sidewalk cafe area shall be delineated by, and the sidewalk cafe elements divided from, that portion of the adjacent public sidewalk lying outside of the sidewalk cafe area, by a barrier at least three feet in height, consisting of: 
(1)  Fencing or other rigid structure; or 
(2)  Ropes of a design or type approved by the director of public works and the design committee of the respective district. 
(h)  All sidewalk cafe elements must either: 
(1)  Be removed from the public right-of-way within 30 minutes of the closing time of the sidewalk cafe each night, restoring the sidewalk cafe to its normal condition as a pedestrian walkway; or 
(2)  Be orderly secured within 30 minutes after the closing time of the sidewalk cafe each night, by means of chains and locks or some other secure means, in such a way that such cafe elements cannot be used to cause damage to persons or property. If the proprietor attaches any sidewalk cafe elements to approved public property, the proprietor shall be responsible for restoring property to its original condition or condition of suitable agreement with the city, such as seasonal plugs, whenever the elements are removed per subsection (n) of this section. Upon completion of the repairs, the city will inspect for compliance. 
a.  The proprietor may select either of the above alternatives, provided that, if the proprietor selects the alternative set forth in subsection (h)(2) of this section, the proprietor shall be responsible for insuring that such sidewalk cafe elements do not cause damage to persons or property and do not inhibit or obstruct regular sidewalk maintenance including, but not limited to, ordinary repair and snow removal. Except as expressly provided for in subsection (h)(2) of this section, no property shall be stored on the public right-of-way. 
b.  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (h)(2) of this subsection, if the proprietor elects to close the sidewalk cafe during certain times of the year, as provided for in section 19-96(10), then all sidewalk cafe elements shall be removed. 
(i)  Sidewalk cafe elements may consist of tables, chairs, fencing, planters and plants, and umbrellas and awnings and similar fixtures if approved by the city as part of the sidewalk cafe permit process. 
(j)  A sidewalk cafe may not use or incorporate into the sidewalk cafe area any public fixtures such as benches, seats, planters, trash receptacles, lampposts, or any other publicly owned structures located in any part of the public right-of-way. 
(k)  Except as otherwise expressly provided in subsection (h)(2) of this section, stacking of chairs or tables in the sidewalk cafe area is not permitted at any time. 
(l)  Outdoor heaters are allowed if approved by the city as part of the sidewalk cafe permit process, or subsequently approved by the city in the same manner as the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(m)  No advertising or signage shall be permitted in a sidewalk cafe area except that the name of the establishment may be printed on chairs, tables, umbrellas or other amenities as approved by the city. 
(n)  In the event of any damage to the surface of any part of the public sidewalk lying within or immediately adjacent to the confines or boundaries of the sidewalk cafe area, the proprietor of the sidewalk cafe and the adjacent restaurant shall repair the damage to the specifications of the director of public works of the city. If the proprietor fails or refuses to repair such damage within 30 days after written notice from the city to do so, the director of public works of the city shall cause the work to be done and billed to the proprietor. All costs, including administration and city staff time shall be computed and will be invoiced as part of the project. Any failure of the proprietor to reimburse the city for the cost of such work shall be grounds for termination of the proprietor's sidewalk cafe permit. Any such costs shall be deducted from the proprietor's cash deposit, and the balance may be collected from the proprietor by legal proceedings instituted by the city, including placing a lien on the property. 
(o)  The sidewalk cafe shall be equipped with an inside or outside water source to clean the sidewalk cafe area, as provided in section 19-95(5). 
(p)  No bottles, cans or pitchers shall be used to serve beverages. 
(q)  The city reserves the right to limit the number of permits issued for sidewalk cafes if necessary to maintain adequate pedestrian flow, to permit adequate access to building entrances, to safeguard pedestrian and traffic safety, to preserve the aesthetic quality of the surrounding area, or for any other valid public purpose. 
(Code 2017, § 23-68; Ord. No. 2827, § 2, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 2941, § 6, 6-3-2019) 
Sec. 19-95. - Operation of sidewalk cafes. 
    Operation of sidewalk cafes shall comply with all of the following provisions: 
(1)  If alcoholic beverages are served in the sidewalk cafe area, the proprietor of the sidewalk cafe shall obtain the necessary liquor control license or wine or beer permit from the Iowa Alcoholic Beverages Division which covers the sidewalk cafe area, and shall otherwise comply with all requirements of the Iowa Alcoholic Beverages Control Act, Iowa Code ch. 123, and chapter 5, alcoholic and malt beverages. 
(2)  The sidewalk cafe, as a part of a restaurant, must be licensed by the state and/or county health departments and comply with all requirements of laws applicable to establishments that sell food to the public for consumption on the premises. 
(3)  The hours of operation for sidewalk cafes shall be from no earlier than 7:00 a.m. to no later than 10:30 p.m. daily, and except as otherwise expressly provided under section 19-94(h)(2), the sidewalk cafe area shall be restored to its normal condition as a pedestrian walkway at all other times, including during certain times of the year that the sidewalk cafe is not open for business, as provided in section 19-96(10). 
(4)  Food and beverages, other than alcoholic beverages, must be available for service to and consumption by patrons in a sidewalk cafe during all hours of operation. 
(5)  The proprietor of the sidewalk cafe area and the restaurant with which it is affiliated, or its employees or agents, shall clean the sidewalk cafe area on a daily basis, including cleaning of tables, chairs, trash receptacles, and the surface of the sidewalk within the sidewalk cafe area. All garbage, trash, litter and other debris shall be picked up and collected whenever the trash receptacles appear to be full. All garbage, trash and other debris located on the public sidewalk adjacent to the sidewalk cafe area, and extending for ten feet on any side thereof, shall be the responsibility of the sidewalk cafe proprietor, or its employees or agents, to pick up and dispose of properly, during all hours of operation, and before closing. No trash receptacles or sidewalk cafe elements shall be hosed down in the sidewalk cafe area or in any part of the public sidewalk at any time, and the sidewalk within or adjacent to the sidewalk cafe shall not be hosed down during cold weather, when ice could form thereon. 
(6)  The sidewalk cafe area shall be served by waiters or restaurant staff at all times during all hours of operation. 
(7)  Sidewalk cafes shall not play or allow the playing of music, whether live or recorded, that involves the use of sound amplification equipment, and no speakers, microphones, or other sound amplification equipment shall be used in conjunction with televisions, radios or other audio or video devices in a sidewalk cafe area at any time during the hours of operation. 
(8)  Lighting of the sidewalk cafe area shall not unreasonably reflect onto adjacent properties or cause disturbance to residential quarters located above or adjacent to the sidewalk cafe area. 
(9)  The city may require additional restroom capacity in the restaurant located within the building adjacent to the sidewalk cafe area in order to comply with the requirements of city or state building, fire or other applicable codes. 
(10)  Occupancy limits, including the occupancy load of the sidewalk cafe area, shall comply with all applicable city or state building, fire, or other applicable codes. 
(11)  No entrances or exits to the adjacent building shall be blocked or obstructed by any sidewalk cafe elements or other materials or property. 
(12)  The only entrance into or exit out of a sidewalk cafe area shall be through the adjacent building, unless such entrance or exit is located at and adjacent to the main entrance to the building in which the restaurant is located. 
(13)  A sidewalk cafe serving alcoholic beverages shall have an employee who shall monitor the sidewalk cafe area at all times during the hours alcoholic beverages are served or are available for service. 
(14)  The operation of each sidewalk cafe shall be in entire conformity with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, including all applicable fire code requirements. 
(15)  Patrons of the sidewalk cafe shall wear shirts and shoes at all times, or they shall not be admitted to or served in the sidewalk cafe area. 
(16)  The sidewalk cafe and the adjacent restaurant shall be subject to inspection by any city employee or agent of any of the city divisions or departments headed by any of the city officials identified in section 19-97(a), at any time during business hours. 
(Code 2017, § 23-69; Ord. No. 2827, § 3, 9-2-2014) 
Sec. 19-96. - Application for sidewalk cafe permit. 
(a)  Before a restaurant may lawfully establish a sidewalk cafe on the public sidewalk adjacent to its building, the proprietor of the restaurant shall file an application with the city clerk for a sidewalk cafe permit on a form furnished by the clerk. The application shall be accompanied by each of the following items: 
(1)  Proof that the applicant holds a valid license or permit to operate a restaurant. 
(2)  Proof of insurance as required in this division. 
(3)  Written consent to the establishment of a sidewalk cafe from the owner of the building in which the restaurant is located, if the applicant is not the owner of the building. 
(4)  Written approval of the design review committee of Community Main Street, Inc., for a sidewalk cafe to be located in the downtown Parkade of the city, or of College Hill Partnership, for a sidewalk cafe to be located in the College Hill area of the city. 
(5)  A significantly detailed, accurate site plan showing the dimensions of the proposed sidewalk cafe area; the position and number of tables, chairs and other sidewalk cafe elements; the type and designs of roping, fencing or other barrier, as approved by Community Main Street or the College Hill Partnership, to divide the area from the adjacent public sidewalk; the distance between the boundaries of the sidewalk cafe area and all adjacent street curbs, buildings, property lines, street intersections, alleys, and fixtures in the public sidewalk; occupancy load of the sidewalk cafe area, and any other items reasonably required by the city clerk or other city staff to ensure that the proposed sidewalk cafe area will comply with all applicable requirements of this division and all other laws, ordinances and regulations applicable to sidewalk cafes, and which shows that the proposed sidewalk cafe shall not unreasonably interfere with: 
a.  Adequate pedestrian flow; 
b.  Access to building entrances; 
c.  Pedestrian and traffic safety; and 
d.  The aesthetic quality of the surrounding area. 
(6)  A nonrefundable permit fee in such amount as shall be determined from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(7)  A public right-of-way easement agreement on a form furnished by the city clerk, for the use of the portion of the public right-of-way to be occupied by the sidewalk cafe, as provided in this division, including an indemnification provision as provided in this division. 
(8)  A cash deposit in the sum of $250.00 to cover any damage to the public sidewalk included within the sidewalk cafe area. If the fencing or other items are permanently affixed to public property, the property owner will furnish the city with a cost estimate during the application process that provides a detailed summary of the repairs and costs to repair the items in public property. The cash deposit shall be refunded by the city clerk upon expiration, non-renewal or other termination of the sidewalk cafe permit, if there is no damage to the public sidewalk after removal of the sidewalk cafe elements from the public right-of-way. 
(9)  Proof that the applicant holds a valid liquor control license or wine or beer permit for the restaurant which is adjacent to the proposed sidewalk cafe and proof that the applicant has applied to the state alcoholic beverages division for approval to extend the "premises" covered by such license or permit to include the entire sidewalk cafe area, if the applicant is applying for authority to serve alcoholic beverages in the sidewalk cafe area. No sidewalk cafe permit shall be issued by the city clerk until such liquor control license or wine or beer permit has actually been issued as provided in this subsection. 
(10)  A listing of the effective dates during the calendar year that the proprietor intends to operate the sidewalk cafe. Sidewalk cafes may be installed no earlier than April 1, and all components thereof shall be removed from the public passageway on or before November 15 of each year. 
(b)  The proprietor shall specify the beginning and ending dates during the calendar year that the sidewalk cafe will be open. The proprietor may revise the effective dates of operation by written notice to the city no more often than once during each permit year, and may revise such effective dates at the time the permit is renewed each year. 
(Code 2017, § 23-70; Ord. No. 2827, § 4, 9-2-2014) 
Sec. 19-97. - Review of application. 
(a)  The city clerk shall submit a copy of the application and all accompanying documents to the following city staff for review and for either approval or denial: 
(1)  The city building official. 
(2)  The city fire chief. 
(3)  The city police chief. 
(4)  The city planning and community services manager. 
(5)  The city director of public works. 
(b)  Within 15 days after receipt of such documents, each such city official shall forward to the city clerk his approval or denial of the application, and in case of denial, the reason or reasons for denial. The applicant shall be notified of the results of the reviews and shall be afforded a period of 15 days to supplement, correct or modify the application to address the city officials' reasons for denial. 
(c)  If the city officials all approve the application, and the applicant has complied with all other requirements of this division, the city clerk shall issue a sidewalk cafe permit to the applicant, including the requirement for city council approval of a public right-of-way easement agreement. 
(d)  After 30 days from the date of filing of the application, if the applicant has not received all necessary city staff approvals, or if the application has been denied by one or more of such city officials, the application shall be considered denied. The applicant may file a written appeal of the denial to the administration committee of the city council within 45 days of the date of original filing of the application with the city clerk. The administration committee shall schedule a hearing within 20 days of the date of the notice of appeal. The applicant shall be notified in writing of the date, time and place of hearing. The committee shall afford the applicant the opportunity to present information to the committee in support of the application. Within ten days after such hearing, the administration committee shall issue its decision, which may either affirm or reverse the denial of the application, or affirm the application subject to certain conditions. The decision of the administration committee shall be final. No new application for a sidewalk cafe permit shall be submitted by the same applicant for the same location for a period of six months from the date of the decision of the administration committee denying any application for a sidewalk cafe permit. 
(e)  If the application is granted by the city officials or by the administration committee after appeal, the city clerk shall issue the sidewalk cafe permit for a period of one year, or until the date for renewal of the applicant's liquor control license or wine or beer permit, whichever is less. Thereafter, the permit shall be applied for, and, if approved as provided herein, issued, for successive one-year periods that run concurrent with the applicant's liquor control license or wine or beer permit. If the application does not include a request to serve alcoholic beverages, the initial permit and all renewal permits shall be issued for a one-year period. 
(f)  The city reserves the right to either deny an application for a sidewalk cafe permit which otherwise meets the requirements of this division or to require the proprietor to meet additional terms and conditions for issuance of a permit beyond the requirements set forth in this division if, in the reasonable determination of the city, either granting the sidewalk cafe permit, or granting it without such additional terms and conditions, would not adequately protect and preserve the rights, privileges, and property of the city or of its residents, or would not adequately protect or preserve the peace, safety, health, welfare, comfort and convenience of the city's residents. 
(Code 2017, § 23-71; Ord. No. 2827, § 5, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 2941, § 6, 6-3-2019) 
Sec. 19-98. - Insurance requirements. 
    A sidewalk cafe shall not be established under this division unless the applicant furnishes proof of insurance which meets the following requirements: 
(1)  Commercial general liability insurance coverage in the amount of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage with a $2,000,000.00 aggregate. The city shall be named as an additional insured on the policy. An endorsement shall be issued as a part of the insurance policy, evidencing compliance with this requirement. 
(2)  Workers' compensation insurance and employer's liability insurance which meets the requirements of state law. 
(3)  Dramshop and liquor liability insurance coverage which meets the requirements of the state code, if the application includes a request to serve alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  The insurance policy or policies shall be issued by an insurance company having authority to do business in the state with a rating of A- under Best's Key Rating Guide. 
(5)  The insurance policy or policies shall contain a provision requiring 30 days advance written notice to the city if the policy is to be cancelled, not renewed, or if any material change in coverage is to be made. 
(6)  Failure to furnish or continue to provide required insurance coverage shall be grounds for revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(Code 2017, § 23-72; Ord. No. 2554, § 2, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 19-99. - Revocation of sidewalk cafe permit. 
(a)  A sidewalk cafe permit issued under this division shall be revoked if the holder of the sidewalk cafe permit does any of the following: 
(1)  Fails to maintain a valid restaurant license covering the building adjacent to the sidewalk cafe. 
(2)  Fails to maintain a liquor control license or wine or beer permit covering either the restaurant adjacent to the sidewalk cafe area, or the sidewalk cafe area itself, if the application for the sidewalk cafe permit includes a request to serve alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  Fails to furnish or maintain insurance required by this division. 
(4)  Fails to pay the fee for issuance or renewal of the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(5)  Fails to file an application for renewal of the sidewalk cafe permit at least 60 days before the existing permit expires. 
(6)  Fails to operate the sidewalk cafe in strict compliance with all of the provisions of this division, of all other city ordinances, and of state law. 
(7)  The permit holder, or any of its agents or employees, is convicted of a violation of Iowa Code ch. 123, the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, chapter 5, alcoholic and malt beverages, or of any other provision of state law or this Code, or a judgment for a municipal infraction is entered against the permit holder or any of its agents or employees for any such violation of law or ordinance, with respect to the sidewalk cafe area, or with respect to the restaurant located in the building adjacent to the sidewalk cafe area. 
(8)  Fails to comply with the provisions of the sidewalk cafe public right-of-way easement agreement required by section 19-100. 
(9)  Creates or allows to exist a safety hazard, health hazard, or public nuisance under state law or city ordinance, in connection with the sidewalk cafe or its operation. 
(10)  Refuses to allow or resists an inspection of the sidewalk cafe or the adjacent restaurant by any city employee or agent of any of the city divisions or departments headed by any of the city officials identified in section 19-97(a), for the purpose of determining compliance with the provisions of this division, any other city ordinance, any provision of the state law, the public right-of-way easement agreement, or any of the terms or provisions of the owner's sidewalk cafe application or permit. 
(11)  Any other failure of the permit holder or any of its employees or agents to comply with any of the provisions of this division relative to sidewalk cafes. 
(12)  Operates the sidewalk cafe in a manner which, in the reasonable determination of the city, does not adequately protect and preserve the rights, privileges, and property of the city or of its residents, or does not adequately protect and preserve the peace, safety, health, welfare, comfort and convenience of the city's residents. 
(b)  Upon the occurrence of any of the events described in subsection (a) of this section, the city clerk shall give the sidewalk cafe permit holder written notice of revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit, and the permit holder shall thereupon immediately cease to operate the sidewalk cafe covered by the permit. 
(c)  The permit holder may appeal the revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit by written notice of appeal mailed or delivered to the city clerk within ten days of the date of notice of revocation. During the pendency of the appeal, the permit holder shall not be allowed to operate the sidewalk cafe. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the appeal, the city clerk shall notify the chair of the administration committee of the city council of the appeal, and a hearing before the administration committee shall be scheduled within 20 days of the date of the notice of appeal. The permit holder shall be notified in writing of the time and place of hearing on the appeal, and shall be afforded an opportunity to present any information to the administration committee. The administration committee shall issue a written decision within ten days of the date of the hearing, either affirming or reversing the revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit. The decision of the administration committee shall be final. 
(e)  The city shall retain the right to terminate any sidewalk cafe permit at any time upon seven days' written notice, and may require the removal of all sidewalk cafe elements from the public sidewalk, if the city council, after due consideration, determines that there is a reasonable and substantial need for the use of the public right-of-way being occupied by the sidewalk cafe, for a valid public purpose. The determination of the city council shall be final, and there shall be no right of appeal from such decision. 
(Code 2017, § 23-73; Ord. No. 2554, § 2, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 19-100. - Sidewalk cafe public right-of-way easement agreement. 
(a)  Before a proprietor may lawfully operate a sidewalk cafe in the city, the proprietor must apply for and obtain from the city a public right-of-way easement agreement as part of the sidewalk cafe permit application, on a form approved by the city clerk, but only after approval by the city council as required by state and local law. 
(b)  The applicant must agree to comply with all state laws and city ordinances governing use of the public sidewalks and other public right-of-way. 
(c)  An annual fee for issuance of the public right-of-way easement agreement shall be established from time to time by city council resolution. 
(d)  Each public right-of-way easement agreement shall be for a period of one year, to coincide with the sidewalk cafe permit, except the first easement agreement, which shall be for a partial year, the same as the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(e)  All sidewalk cafe public right-of-way easement agreements shall be issued by the city clerk, but only after the applicant has complied with all other requirements for issuance of a sidewalk cafe permit contained in this division, but only after approval by the city council as required by state and local law. 
(f)  The city shall retain the right to terminate any public right-of-way easement agreement, at any time upon seven days' written notice, and may require the removal of all sidewalk cafe elements from the public sidewalk, if the city council, after due consideration, determines that there is a reasonable and substantial need for the use of the public right-of-way being occupied by the sidewalk cafe, for a valid public purpose. The determination of the city council shall be final, and there shall be no right of appeal from such decision. 
(g)  The use of the public right-of-way by any proprietor of a sidewalk cafe pursuant to an approved public right-of-way easement agreement shall not interfere with the city's or the city utilities' access to public utilities located within the city's public right-of-way. 
(h)  The public right-of-way easement agreement shall contain such provisions as the city may deem appropriate to regulate and control the use of the public right-of-way, and shall include a provision requiring the sidewalk cafe permit holder to indemnify, hold harmless and defend the city, its agents, employees, and insurers, from all claims, demands, and causes of action, together with costs and expenses, including attorneys' fees, incurred by the city arising out of the operation of the permit holder's sidewalk cafe, and to release the city, its agents, employees, and insurers, from any liability to the sidewalk cafe permit holder, its employees, agents, and insurers, arising out of any actions of the city in administering, inspecting, and overseeing (including termination of) the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(Code 2017, § 23-74; Ord. No. 2554, § 2, 10-10-2005) 
Sec. 19-101. - Violation of division. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division shall be deemed to have committed a municipal infraction and, upon entry of a judgment for such violation against such person, shall be subject to a civil penalty of $100.00 for a first offense, $500.00 for a second offense, and $1,000.00 for a third or subsequent offense, together with a court order for such other relief as is provided in section 1-9(a)(3). In addition, any such violation by the holder of a sidewalk cafe permit issued under this division, or an employee or agent of such permit holder, shall be grounds for revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit, as provided in section 19-99. 
(Code 2017, § 23-75; Ord. No. 2554, § 2, 10-10-2005) 
Secs. 19-102-19-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS/PAVEMENT CUTS 

Sec. 19-131. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to clarify the responsibilities of the city and persons, firms or corporations for the excavation and reconstruction of streets. 
(Code 2017, § 23-86; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-132. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City engineer means the city engineer or the officer designated by the city council to perform the duties prescribed for the engineer by this article. 
    Excavations/pavement cuts means any opening in street, sidewalk or right-of-way; usually for the purpose of placing or repairing underground utilities. 
    Person means person, firm or corporation proposing to evacuate. 
(Code 2017, § 23-87; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-133. - Standard excavation specifications. 
    The city engineer shall prepare complete plans and specifications for the excavation and reconstruction of sidewalks or streets, which, upon approval of the city council, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The specifications shall include descriptions and location of barricades and warning lights. All excavations and improvements in public property, whether performed by others or by the city, shall be performed under the supervision and inspection of the city engineer, and in accordance with the plans and specifications adopted in accordance with this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-88; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-134. - Permits for excavations. 
    No person shall make any excavations unless such person shall obtain a permit from the city engineer. The permit shall state that the person will comply with the ordinances of the city and with the specifications for excavations adopted by the city. The permit also shall state that the work will be done under the direction and approval of the city engineer. All such permits shall be issued upon payment of a charge established annually by resolution by the city council and a copy of the permit with the application, shall be filed and preserved in the office of the city engineer. The permit shall state when the work is to be commenced and when the work is to be completed. The time of completion for the improvements may be extended by the city engineer. The city engineer may withhold the issuance of any permit for any excavations for a sufficient period to determine the necessity for the proposed improvements or when weather conditions will adversely affect the improvements. 
(Code 2017, § 23-89; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992; Ord. No. 2067, § 23, 10-10-1994) 
Sec. 19-135. - Exemption. 
    No permit is required to begin work in cases of emergencies, such as the breakage of water, gas or sewer lines, or electrical cables. However, a permit shall be obtained on the first working day after the emergency excavation/pavement cut has been made. 
(Code 2017, § 23-90; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-136. - Contractor's bond. 
    Any person doing any excavation work within the city must first file a bond with the city clerk, with a copy to the city engineer, in the sum of $5,000.00, or the estimated total cost of the excavation work covered by the permit as determined by the city engineer, whichever is greater, conditioned on: 
(1)  The faithful performance of all duties and regulations required by this article regulating the excavation within the city; 
(2)  The prompt payment to the city of any sums that may become due by reason of this article; and 
(3)  The payment of all fines imposed on said person for violation of this article when said violations occur during the life of the bond. In addition, such person shall provide a certificate of liability insurance to the city clerk with a copy to the city engineer, which policy shall indemnify the city from all liability for damages arising from negligence in doing, protecting or completing the excavation work. Said insurance policy shall have limits in the aggregate of $1,000,000.00 and shall include the city as an additional named insured. Said bond and liability insurance policy shall provide coverage on a calendar year basis. 
(Code 2017, § 23-91; Ord. No. 2758, § 1, 1-23-2012) 
Sec. 19-137. - General work standards. 
    All excavation/pavement cuts shall be done in a good, workmanlike manner and in accordance with the applicable city specifications found in the standard specification for municipal improvements for the city. 
(Code 2017, § 23-92; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-138. - Inspection and approval. 
    Upon final completion, the city engineer shall inspect the work. He may order corrections if the work does not meet specifications. When the work does meet all requirements of this article, the specifications and the permit, the engineer shall indicate this on both copies of the permit. 
(Code 2017, § 23-93; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-139. - Barricades and warning lights. 
    Proper warning lights and barricades shall be placed to protect persons from materials, equipment and dangerous conditions. Placement and maintenance of adequate warnings is the responsibility of the constructor. 
(Code 2017, § 23-94; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-140. - Charges for backfilling, restoring surfaces. 
    If a permittee does not perform the repair in accordance with these requirements, the city shall perform the repair and the cost thereof will be billed to the permittee. Cost is determined as follows: The cost of backfilling trenches, including large, irregular and abnormal trenches, and the restoring of pavements, walks and other surfaces shall be made against the individual, firm or corporation who made the excavation and such cost shall be based on two and one-half times the actual cost of labor, materials and the use of equipment. 
(Code 2017, § 23-95; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-141. - Underground facilities; permittee's liability. 
(a)  Before the starting of any excavation, the permit holder shall familiarize himself with underground facilities in the particular area. In general, the sources of this information are as follows: in the office of the city engineer, the municipal utility, the telephone company and the cable television company. 
(b)  The permit holder shall use extra precaution around underground piping and cables so as not to disturb or break them and especially around gas mains and buried electric cables. No work shall be done within ten feet of any utility facility without the presence of a representative of the utility involved. 
(c)  All exposed gas, water, steam or sewer lines, or buried cables or raceways, old or new, must be inspected before the trench is backfilled. 
(d)  The permit holder shall be fully responsible for all damages done by him to any utility facilities. 
(Code 2017, § 23-96; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-142. - Special methods of construction. 
    Methods other than those specified above may be permitted upon special request. The permit holder shall submit specifications for approval by the city engineer prior to granting of an excavation/pavement cut permit. 
(Code 2017, § 23-97; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-143. - Excavation/pavement cuts during winter. 
    No person, firm or corporation or utility shall be granted a permit to excavate or open any street or sidewalk from October 15 of each year to April 1 of the next year unless an emergency or special condition exists and permission is obtained, in writing, from the city. Any person, firm or corporation wishing to obtain an excavation/pavement cut permit between the aforementioned dates shall first explain fully, in writing, the nature of the emergency situation to the city before permission is granted. If a hazardous condition which would endanger life and/or property, exists, excavation work shall not be delayed. However, a written explanation shall be delivered to the city as soon as possible and an excavation/pavement cut permit obtained for the opening made. 
(Code 2017, § 23-98; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-144. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to have committed a municipal infraction and shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 2017, § 23-99; Ord. No. 1984, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Secs. 19-145-19-171. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 

Sec. 19-172. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to clarify the responsibilities of the city and the owners of abutting property for the maintenance, repair, replacement or reconstruction of sidewalks. 
(Code 2017, § 23-121) 
Sec. 19-173. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City engineer means the city engineer or the officer designated by the city council to perform the duties prescribed for the engineer by this article. 
    Defective sidewalk means any public sidewalk exhibiting deficient characteristics, as defined by the city engineer and approved by the city council. A list of the deficient characteristics shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
    Owner means the person owning the fee title or the contract purchaser for purposes of notification required under this article. For all other purposes, the term "owner" shall include the lessee, if any. 
    Sidewalk improvements means the reconstruction, repair, replacement or removal of a public sidewalk or the excavating, filling or depositing of material in the public right-of-way in connection therewith. 
(Code 2017, § 23-122) 
Sec. 19-174. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to have committed a municipal infraction, and shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 2017, § 23-123) 
Sec. 19-175. - Standard specifications; supervision by city engineer. 
(a)  The city engineer shall prepare complete plans and specifications for the construction, reconstruction and repair of sidewalks and driveway crossings in the sidewalk, which, upon approval of the city council, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The specifications shall include descriptions and standards for location of barricades and warning lights. 
(b)  All sidewalk improvements on public property, whether performed by the owner of the abutting property or by the city, shall be performed under the supervision and inspection of the city engineer, and in accordance with the plans and specifications adopted in accordance with this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-124) 
Sec. 19-176. - Permit required; issuance. 
    No person shall make any sidewalk improvements unless such person shall obtain a permit from the city engineer. The permit shall state that the person will comply with the ordinances of the city and with the specifications for sidewalks adopted by the city. The permit also shall state that the work will be done under the direction and approval of the city engineer. A charge, in such amount as established by the council from time to time, shall be made for all such permits. A copy of the permit, with the application, shall be filed and preserved in the office of the city engineer. The permit shall state when the work is to be commenced and when the work is to be completed. The time of completion for the sidewalk improvements may be extended by the city engineer. All permits for sidewalk improvements not ordered by resolution of the city council shall be issued in compliance with this article. The city engineer may withhold the issuance of any permit for any sidewalk improvements for a sufficient period to determine the necessity for the proposed improvements, or when weather conditions will adversely affect the sidewalk improvements. 
(Code 2017, § 23-125) 
Sec. 19-177. - Commencement of work without permit; failure to comply with specifications. 
    Whenever any sidewalk improvements are made that do not conform to the provisions of this article and with the city specifications, or when any sidewalk improvements are made without a permit, the city engineer shall serve notice to obtain a permit upon the property owner and upon the contractor doing the work. If the sidewalk is in the course of construction, the notice shall order the work to stop until a permit is obtained and the work is corrected to comply with the specifications. If the sidewalk work has been completed, the owner shall obtain a permit immediately and perform any needed corrections within five days from receipt of the permit. If the owner fails to comply with this notice, the engineer shall have the work completed, and the costs shall be assessed to the property owner as provided in section 23-135(c). 
(Code 2017, § 23-126) 
Sec. 19-178. - Bond; insurance. 
(a)  Any person constructing or building sidewalks within the city must first file a bond with the city clerk, with a copy to the city engineer, in the sum of $5,000.00, or the estimated total cost of the construction work covered by the permit as determined by the city engineer, whichever is greater, conditioned on: 
(1)  The faithful performance of all duties and regulations required by this article regulating the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks within the city; 
(2)  The prompt payment to the city of any sums that may become due by reason of this article; and 
(3)  The payment of all fines imposed on said person for violation of this article when such violations occur during the life of the bond. 
(b)  In addition, such person shall provide a certificate of liability insurance to the city clerk with a copy to the city engineer, which policy shall indemnify the city from all liability for damages arising from negligence in doing, protecting or completing the sidewalk work. Said insurance policy shall have limits in the aggregate of $1,000,000.00, and shall include the city as an additional named insured. Said bond and liability insurance policy shall provide coverage on a calendar year basis. Owners doing only their own sidewalk work are not required to furnish a bond or liability insurance policy if the owners execute an agreement with the city to hold the city harmless from any and all claims that may arise out of the sidewalk work. 
(Code 2017, § 23-127; Ord. No. 2758, § 2, 1-23-2012) 
Sec. 19-179. - Inspection and approval of work. 
    Upon final completion of sidewalk improvements, the city engineer shall inspect the work. He may order corrections if the work does not meet specifications. When the work does meet all requirements of this article, the specifications and the permit, the engineer shall indicate this on both copies of the permit. 
(Code 2017, § 23-128) 
Sec. 19-180. - Barricades and warning lights. 
    Proper warning lights and barricades shall be placed at sidewalk improvements to protect persons from materials, equipment and dangerous conditions. Placement and maintenance of adequate warnings is the responsibility of the constructor, the owner and the lessee of the property. 
(Code 2017, § 23-129) 
Sec. 19-181. - Interference with sidewalk improvements. 
    No person shall knowingly or willfully drive any vehicle upon any portion of any sidewalk or approach thereto while it is in the process of being improved, or upon any portion of any completed sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove or destroy any part or all of any sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove, destroy, mar or deface any sidewalk at any time or destroy, mar, remove or deface any notice or warning device provided for by this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-130) 
Sec. 19-182. - Authority to order sidewalk improvements. 
    The city engineer may order the reconstruction, repair or replacement of permanent sidewalks upon any street or court. Notice of this order shall be sent to the owner by certified mail. The notice shall include the fact that the owner may request a hearing by the city council within 15 days of receipt of the notice. 
(Code 2017, § 23-131) 
Sec. 19-183. - Duty of abutting property owner to repair defective sidewalk. 
    It shall be the duty of the abutting property owner at any time, or upon receipt of 30 days' notice from the city, to repair, replace or reconstruct all broken or defective sidewalks in the street right-of-way abutting the property owner's property. The abutting property owner shall be liable for damages caused by the failure of the abutting property owner to use reasonable care in the repair, replacement or reconstruction of broken or defective sidewalks abutting the property owner's property. If, after the expiration of the 30 days as provided in the notice, the required work has not been done or is not in the process of completion, the city engineer shall proceed to repair, replace or reconstruct the sidewalk. Upon completion of the work, the city engineer shall prepare and submit to the city council an itemized and verified statement of expenditures for material and labor, and the legal description of the property abutting the sidewalk on which work has been performed. These costs shall be assessed against the abutting property for collection in the same manner as a property tax. The assessment of such costs against the property does not relieve the abutting property owner of liability for damages imposed by this section. The city does not have a duty to repair, replace or reconstruct broken or defective sidewalks. 
(Code 2017, § 23-132; Ord. No. 2410, § 1, 1-13-2003) 
Sec. 19-184. - Notification of city in case of inability to repair or barricade sidewalk. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk, or of the contractor or agent of the owner, to notify the city immediately if the owner is unable to make necessary sidewalk improvements or to install or erect warnings and barricades as required by this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-133) 
Sec. 19-185. - Removal of snow and ice. 
    The abutting property owner is responsible for the removal of the natural accumulations of snow and ice from the sidewalks abutting the property owner's property within a reasonable amount of time. The abutting property owner shall be liable for damages caused by the failure of the abutting property owner to use reasonable care in the removal of the snow or ice. If the abutting property owner fails to remove the natural accumulations of snow or ice within a reasonable amount of time, the public works department may have the natural accumulations of snow or ice removed without notice to the property owner. Upon completion of the work, the public works director shall prepare and submit to the city council an itemized and verified statement of the costs and a legal description of the property, and the costs shall be assessed against the abutting property for collection in the same manner as a property tax. The assessment of such costs against the property does not relieve the abutting property owner of liability for damages imposed by this section. The city does not have a duty to remove natural accumulations of snow or ice from the sidewalks. 
(Code 2017, § 23-134; Ord. No. 2410, § 2, 1-13-2003; Ord. No. 2941, § 6, 6-3-2019) 
Sec. 19-186. - Assessment for repair or clearing cost. 
(a)  Notice. When the city engineer submits a bill for sidewalk improvements or for removal of accumulations as provided in sections 19-177, 19-183 and 19-185, the city clerk shall send a notice of such facts to the owner of the abutting property. The notice may be given either by personal service or by certified mail to the last known address of the owner. The notice shall contain a statement of the work performed, the cost of the work that is being assessed and a description of the property affected, and shall state the fact that the person may pay the amount assessed by a certain date without interest or penalty. The notice also shall indicate that the person may object to such assessment and give the place and time at which the city council will hear such objections. The time set for hearing shall be at least 15 days after the service or mailing of the notice. 
(b)  Hearing. At the time and place designated in the notice, the city council shall consider all objections to the assessment, correct all errors or omissions, and adopt a corrected list as the amounts to be assessed against the property. 
(c)  Billing and certifying to county. Thirty days after the city council's decision, the city clerk shall certify any unpaid amounts to the county auditor. The unpaid assessments shall constitute a lien against the property and shall be collected by the county treasurer in the same manner as other taxes. Any assessment that exceeds $500.00 may be paid in installments as set by the city council, not exceeding 15, in the same manner and at the same interest rates as for special assessments under Iowa Code ch. 384, div. IV (Iowa Code § 384.37 et seq.). No interest shall be charged for assessments, or parts thereof, paid within 30 days of the time the city council determines the final amounts. 
(Code 2017, § 23-135) 
Secs. 19-187-19-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DRIVEWAYS AND CURBS 

Sec. 19-211. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to clarify the responsibilities of the city and owners of abutting property for the construction, reconstruction or repair of driveways. 
(Code 2017, § 23-156; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-212. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City engineer means the city engineer or the officer designated by the city council to perform the duties prescribed for the engineer by this article. 
    Driveway means that part of any approach for motor vehicles to private property that lies between the property line and the roadway of the public street. 
    Owner means the person owning the fee title or the contract purchaser for purposes of notification required herein. For all other purposes, the term "owner" includes the lessee, if any. 
    Paving means any kind of hard surfacing including, but not limited to, Portland cement, concrete, bituminous concrete, brick, stabilized gravel or combinations of such materials, with the necessary base. The term "paving" shall not include surfacing with oil, gravel, oil and gravel, or chloride. 
(Code 2017, § 23-157; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-213. - Consent required before cutting, removing curbs or constructing driveway. 
    No person shall cut or remove a curb or construct a new driveway without first obtaining the consent of the city council or its authorized representative. 
(Code 2017, § 23-158; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-214. - Permit required for construction of driveway entrance; fee. 
(a)  No person shall construct or reconstruct with concrete or asphalt surfacing the driveway entrance lying between the curb and the street line without first obtaining a permit signed by the city engineer. 
(b)  The fee for each permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be in an amount as established annually by resolution by the city council. The city engineer maintains the right to waive the permit fee at the discretion of said engineer. The fee shall be payable in advance to the city clerk. 
(Code 2017, § 23-159; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992; Ord. No. 2067, § 24, 10-10-1994) 
Sec. 19-215. - Application for permit to construct driveway entrance; contents. 
    The application for a permit to construct or reconstruct a driveway entrance shall be upon a form furnished by the city and shall contain the name of the owner of the property, a description of the lot, lots or parcels of ground in front of which the driveway entrance is to be built, a statement that the entrance will be constructed in accordance with this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-160; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-216. - Improper construction of driveway entrance to nullify permit. 
    Failure of the property owner to build or have built a driveway entrance in accordance with this article shall nullify the permit and subject the entrance to removal. 
(Code 2017, § 23-161; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-217. - Contractor's bond. 
    Any person constructing or building driveways within the city must first file a bond with the city clerk, with a copy with the city engineer, in the sum of $5,000.00, or the estimated total cost of the construction work covered by the permit as determined by the city engineer, whichever is greater, conditioned on: 
(1)  The faithful performance of all duties and regulations required by this article regulating the construction, reconstruction or repair of driveways within the city; 
(2)  The prompt payment to the city of any sums that may become due by reason of this article; and 
(3)  The payment of all fines imposed on said person for violation of this article when said violations occur during the life of the bond. In addition, such person shall provide a certificate of liability insurance to the city clerk with a copy to the city engineer, which policy shall indemnify the city from all liability for damages arising from negligence in doing, protecting or completing the driveway work. Said insurance policy shall have limits in the aggregate of $1,000,000.00 and shall include the city as an additional named insured. Said bond and liability insurance policy shall provide coverage on a calendar year basis. 
(Code 2017, § 23-162; Ord. No. 2758, § 3, 1-23-2012) 
Sec. 19-218. - Standard driveway and curb cut plans and specifications. 
    The city engineer shall prepare complete plans and specifications for the construction, reconstruction, and repair of driveways, curb cuts, which upon approval of the city council, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The specifications shall include requirements for barricades and warning lights. 
(Code 2017, § 23-163; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-219. - Plans, specifications for driveway entrances. 
(a)  All driveway entrances shall be constructed in accordance with the plans prepared by the city engineer. 
(b)  Concrete driveways shall meet the following criteria: 
(1)  The concrete mix shall be a proportion to develop a minimum ultimate 28-day compressive strength of 4,000 pounds per square inch and shall be of air-entrained and shall otherwise meet the requirements of city specifications type C concrete paving. 
(2)  Residential. Entrances shall have a minimum thickness of five inches with a six-inch by six-inch, ten-ten steel mesh reinforcing or a six-inch nonreinforced thickness. 
(3)  Commercial. Entrances shall be constructed with a minimum concrete thickness of six inches. Thickness and reinforcing is to be determined by an analysis of projected traffic axle loads. 
(c)  A one-half-inch asphaltic expansion joint shall be placed on each side of the public sidewalk as shown on the plans. 
(d)  Asphaltic concrete driveways shall meet the following criteria: 
(1)  The entrance shall be constructed to the requirements of city specification on asphaltic concrete paving. No asphalt driveway work shall be placed after October 15, except with the approval by the city engineer. Asphalt shall not be used for any sidewalk or overlay of any sidewalk. 
(2)  Residential. Minimum of five inches of compacted stone base topped by 11/2 inches of type A asphaltic concrete. 
(3)  Commercial. Minimum of six inches of compacted stone base topped by three inches of type A asphaltic concrete. 
(e)  Driveway culverts shall be installed within rural portions of the city as directed by the city engineer. Minimum size culvert shall be 15 inches in diameter and shall be either corrugated culvert pipe or 2000D concrete culvert pipe conforming to standard specifications for highway and bridge construction, state department of transportation. Actual culvert size will be determined from an upstream analysis of stormwater surface runoff. 
(f)  All driveway improvement in public property, whether performed by the owner of the abutting property or by the city, shall be performed under the supervision and inspection of the city engineer, and in accordance with the plans and specifications adopted in accordance with this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-164; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-220. - Location of curb openings. 
    Curb openings shall be placed on the center of existing or proposed driveways. No opening, however, shall extend beyond the side lines of the owner's premises. 
(Code 2017, § 23-165) 
Sec. 19-221. - Width and number of curb openings. 
    The curb opening for a single drive shall be not less than 16 feet nor more than 20 feet and the opening for a double drive shall not exceed 24 feet in width. In general, only one opening shall be granted per residence in residential areas. The council may grant additional openings in special cases such as for large corner lots, etc. The width and number of curb openings for business and commercial places shall be determined as to the needs by the council. 
(Code 2017, § 23-166; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-222. - Method of cutting curb. 
    All new and reconstructed curb openings shall be constructed of a minimum two feet curb and gutter section and separate from the driveway. Any cutting which is less than two feet from an existing traverse, joint or 18 inches from an existing longitudinal joint, shall be taken to that joint. All curb cuts shall be neatly sawed to a depth of at least one-half the thickness of the existing street surface with a method approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 2017, § 23-167; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-223. - Driveway width. 
    The driveway width at the owner's property line shall not be less than ten feet for a single drive and not less than 18 feet for double drives. Where possible, no drive shall be placed nearer than three feet to the side lines of the owner's premises. 
(Code 2017, § 23-168; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-224. - Inspection of driveway entrances. 
    All driveway entrances shall be inspected by the city engineer or his representative for proper grade and subgrade preparations prior to the placing of the concrete or asphalt slabs. The city engineer shall have the right to inspect the finished driveway entrances to determine whether or not the provisions of this article have been complied with. 
(Code 2017, § 23-169; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-225. - Barricades and warning lights. 
    Proper warning lights and barricades shall be placed to protect persons from materials, equipment and dangerous conditions. Placement and maintenance of adequate warnings is the responsibility of the constructor, the owner and the lessee of the property. 
(Code 2017, § 23-170; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Sec. 19-226. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to have committed a municipal infraction and shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 2017, § 23-171; Ord. No. 1985, § 1, 8-24-1992) 
Secs. 19-227-19-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 19-246. - General plan. 
    Except as otherwise provided, the following plan shall apply for numbering buildings within the city: 
(1)  That portion of the city lying south of the Cedar River shall have the river as the dividing line for Main Street and all streets parallel thereto. Main Street shall be the dividing line for all streets running east and west and transversely thereto. 
(2)  Main Street and all streets parallel thereto, south of the Cedar River, shall be so numbered that all buildings in the first block shall be numbered over 100 and less than 200, and numbers shall rise by 100 for each consecutive block to the south limits of the city. 
(3)  All streets intersecting Main Street shall be termed "West" by their respective names in that portion of the city lying west of Main Street and south of the Cedar River, and in the portion of the city lying east of Main Street and south of the river they shall be termed "East" by their respective names. 
(4)  The buildings on the streets running transversely to Main Street shall be so numbered on either side of Main Street that the buildings within the blocks next to Main Street shall be numbered over 100 and less than 200, and numbers shall rise by 100 for each consecutive block to the east and west limits of the city. 
(5)  That portion of the city lying north of the Cedar River shall be numbered in a manner using the river and Lincoln Street as the dividing lines, and shall be so numbered that the first block on Lincoln Street, and all streets running parallel thereto, shall be numbered over 100 and less than 200, and numbers shall rise by 100 for each block to the city limits. 
(6)  All streets intersecting and running transversely to Lincoln Street shall be termed "North" by their respective names for those portions north of Lincoln Street; those portions of such streets lying south of Lincoln Street shall be termed "South" by their respective names, and shall be numbered in a manner similar to the method of numbering the intersecting streets on the south side of the river. 
(Code 2017, § 23-221) 
Sec. 19-247. - Numbering to commence at dividing lines; use of odd and even numbers. 
    Except as otherwise provided, the numbering of buildings shall commence at the dividing lines established in section 19-246, and be so fixed across the streets from right to left that all odd numbers shall be on the right side and all even numbers on the left side. 
(Code 2017, § 23-222) 
Sec. 19-248. - Numbering on University Avenue. 
    Effective on July 1, 1970, University Avenue, from the east city limits to the west city limits, shall not be termed east or west, and University Avenue shall be numbered commencing at the east city limits with the number 4100 and the street shall be numbered consecutively with odd numbers on the south side of the street and even numbers on the north side of the street, to the west city limits. 
(Code 2017, § 23-223) 
Sec. 19-249. - Effect of lot and building frontage. 
    Each lot having a street frontage of 22 feet shall have a separate number, and buildings having more than a 22-foot frontage shall be numbered by the number to which the lot is entitled upon which the principal entrance to the building is located. 
(Code 2017, § 23-224) 
Sec. 19-250. - Determination of number in case of doubt. 
    In case of doubt as to the proper number for any building or lot subject to the provisions of this article, the city engineer shall, on request, decide on the number. 
(Code 2017, § 23-225) 
Sec. 19-251. - Street number plats. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to prepare and keep on file in his office a plat showing the streets and the numbers required under this article, and whenever a plat is filed as an addition to the city the engineer shall file a copy of such plat with the city clerk, showing the numbers as required under this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-226) 
Sec. 19-252. - Placement of numbers required. 
    All owners or lessees of buildings on any of the streets of the city are hereby required to number their buildings in strict accordance with the provisions of this article, and shall cause the number to be placed in plain view on their property and so maintained. 
(Code 2017, § 23-227) 
Sec. 19-253. - Standards for numbers. 
    The numbers used to number buildings shall be three inches high and two inches wide, and made of metal or other substantial and durable material. 
(Code 2017, § 23-228) 
Sec. 19-254. - Placement of numbers by city. 
    If an owner or lessee neglects or refuses to number the property owned or occupied by him as required in this article, for a period of ten days after being notified either personally or by public notice published in one issue of some newspaper published in the city, then such numbering shall be done by the city under proper order of the city council, and the cost thereof shall be assessed to the property. 
(Code 2017, § 23-229) 
Secs. 19-255-19-271. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MAJOR THOROUGHFARE PLAN 

Sec. 19-272. - Title. 
    The title of this article shall be "A Major Thoroughfare Plan for the City of Cedar Falls, Iowa." 
(Code 2017, § 23-251) 
Sec. 19-273. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building setback line means a line establishing the minimum distance between a building and a property line. This minimum distance is established by chapter 26. 
    Collector street means a street whose function is to collect traffic from residential streets and disperse it upon major thoroughfares. 
    Major thoroughfare means a street designed to carry large volumes of traffic to and from the major traffic generators and to facilitate the movement of through traffic. 
    One-way street means a street in which the traffic is permitted to move in one direction only. 
    Restricted or limited access street means a street where access is permitted at only specifically designated points. 
    Right-of-way means that area owned by the city or state or dedicated for public use for street purposes lying between individual property lines. Right-of-way may be abbreviated as R.O.W. 
    Right-of-way, future, means that right-of-way required for the development of streets in the future. 
    Roadway means that portion of the right-of-way developed for the purpose of moving vehicles. 
    Traffic moving lane means that portion of the roadway devoted to the movement of a single line of traffic, varying in width from ten to 12 feet. 
(Code 2017, § 23-252) 
Sec. 19-274. - Interpretation of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall be held as minimum requirements. Where this article imposes a greater restriction than that of other laws, resolutions, restrictions or ordinances, the provisions of this article shall apply. 
(Code 2017, § 23-253) 
Sec. 19-275. - Amendment of article. 
    The council may, after public notice and public hearing as provided by law, and after recommendation by the city planning and zoning commission, amend, supplement or change the provisions of this article. Such amendment shall not become effective except by the favorable vote of a majority of the members of the council. 
(Code 2017, § 23-254) 
Sec. 19-276. - Official map. 
    The major thoroughfare map, which is integral to and part of this article, is on file in the city clerk's office. References, definitions and regulations in this article are applicable to the map, and all data on the map is applicable to the text of this article, the same as if it were set forth in this article. 
(Code 2017, § 23-255) 
Sec. 19-277. - Measuring of setback lines. 
    Building setback lines, as established in chapter 26, shall be measured from the future right-of-way as established by this article. Where setback requirements have been established along primary, state and federal highways by the state highway commission, the requirements of the state shall apply. 
(Code 2017, § 23-256) 
Sec. 19-278. - Development of thoroughfares. 
(a)  All designated thoroughfares shall be developed in the most expeditious manner, as provided in the capital improvements program. 
(b)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance prescribing schedules for the development of specific and designated thoroughfares as prescribed in the capital improvements program, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 2017, § 23-257) 
Sec. 19-279. - Location of access to major thoroughfares. 
    Access to major thoroughfares, wherever possible, particularly in new areas, shall be confined to street intersections located at not less than one-fourth-mile intervals. 
(Code 2017, § 23-258) 
Sec. 19-280. - Access by other than major thoroughfare required for certain property. 
    Property platted subsequent to June 9, 1958, which abuts a major thoroughfare shall, wherever possible, provide access to and from the property on streets other than the major thoroughfare. This may be done through the use of parallel frontage roads, or by double frontage lots where the lots in question back onto the thoroughfare and have street access in front upon a secondary street. 
(Code 2017, § 23-259) 
Sec. 19-281. - Discharge of water on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause the waterspouts, troughs or gutters from any building owned or leased by him to discharge or conduct water upon the surface of any sidewalk in the city, but permission may be given by the council to conduct water over or under any sidewalk under the direction of the operations and maintenance manager. Violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute a municipal infraction, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished in accordance with section 1-9. 
(Code 2017, § 13-3) 
Chapter 20 - SUBDIVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - General provisions. 
(a)  Short title. This chapter shall be known as the "subdivision ordinance" of the city. 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to provide minimum standards for the design, development, and improvement of all new subdivisions and resubdivisions of land, so that existing land uses will be protected, and so that adequate provisions are made for public facilities and services, and so that growth occurs in an orderly manner, consistent with the comprehensive plan, and to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(c)  Application. Every owner of any tract or parcel of land who has subdivided or shall hereafter subdivide or plat said tract or parcel into two or more parts, for the purpose of laying out an addition, subdivision, building lot, or lots, acreage or suburban lots within the city shall cause plats of such area to be made in the form, and containing the information, as hereinafter set forth before selling any lots therein contained or placing the plat on record. 
(d)  Subdivided land. Land to be subdivided shall be of such character that it can be used safely for building purposes without danger to health or peril from fire and flood and shall not be subdivided until adequate public utilities, sanitary sewer, streets and similar infrastructure and improvements exist or are satisfactorily provided to the property and to all building sites prior to building construction. Furthermore, all such subdivisions shall, to the extent that is practical, protect and preserve important environmental features of the land, as specified herein, and shall provide effective stormwater runoff controls and soil erosion control features in a manner that minimizes flooding, soil erosion, waterway embankment erosion, and contamination of water resources. 
(e)  Recording of plat. No subdivision plat, resubdivision plat or street dedication within the city shall be filed for record with the county recorder, or recorded by the county recorder, until a final plat of such subdivision, resubdivision, or street dedication has been reviewed and approved in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(f)  Filing plat. Upon the approval of the final plat by the city council, it shall be the duty of the subdivider to immediately file such plat with the county auditor and county recorder, as required by law. 
(g)  Request dely. In those cases where the owner/subdivider requests a delay in referral of a subdivision plat from the planning and zoning commission to the city council, such delay shall be allowed. However, if any plat, whether a preliminary plat, final plat or minor plat is delayed for referral from the planning and zoning commission to the city council for a period longer than one year from the date of review by the commission, said plat shall be resubmitted in the original fashion including payment of platting fees and updated dates on the submitted plat. City staff shall evaluate whether circumstances have changed with respect to details on the plat, with respect to the property being subdivided or with respect to developments on nearby properties that may have an effect on the proposed plat. If city staff feel that no changes are necessary regarding the proposed plat, the matter may be referred directly to the city council with no further review by the planning and zoning commission. 
(h)  Fees established. The city council shall, from time to time, establish by resolution fees for the review of plats. No plat for any subdivision or resubdivision shall be considered filed with the city clerk, unless and until said plat is accompanied by the fee, as established by resolution of the city council from time to time, and as required by this chapter. 
(i)  Lot sales before final plat approval. No owner, subdivider or other person representing or working on behalf of the owner shall dispose of or sell any lot or lots within the area of jurisdiction of this chapter before the final plat thereof has been approved by the city council, and recorded as required by law. Any such lot sale or disposal prior to final plat approval shall result in forfeiture and payment of $300.00 for each lot or part of lot sold or disposed. Nothing contained herein shall in any way limit the city's right to any other remedies available to the city for the enforcement of this chapter. This provision shall not prevent marketing efforts to advertise or offer for sale such proposed lots subject to final plat approval. 
(j)  Building permit to be denied. No building permit shall be issued for new building construction on any lot, parcel, or tract, where a subdivision is required by this chapter, unless and until a final plat of such subdivision has been approved and recorded in accordance with this chapter, and until all public infrastructure improvements required by this chapter have been accepted by the city, unless a final plat has been approved in lieu of completion of required public improvements as specified herein. 
(Code 2017, § 24-1; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means public property dedicated to public use primarily for vehicular access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a public street. An alley is not a street. 
    Block means an area of land within a subdivision that is entirely bounded by streets, railroad rights-of-way, rivers, tracts of public land, or the boundary of the subdivision. 
    Building line means a line on a plat between which line and a street, alley, public right-of-way line or private place no building or structure may be erected. Building lines may establish front yard, side yard and rear yard building setbacks. 
    City engineer means the professional engineer registered in the state designated as city engineer by the city council. 
    Comprehensive plan means the general plan for the development of the community, which may be titled master plan, comprehensive plan or some other title, which plan has been adopted by the city council. Such "comprehensive plan" shall include any part of such plan separately adopted, including master street plan, transportation plan or recreation or trails plan or public parks plan and any amendment to such plan or parts thereof. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having one end connecting to another street, and the other end terminated by a vehicular turn around. 
    Deed transfer means transfers or sales of smaller parcels of land from one property owner to another where said parcel transfer or sale will not result in the creation of a potentially developable parcel by virtue of added lot width, lot depth or lot area. 
    Developable parcel means one or more proposed lots, parcels or land area that have sufficient area, width and depth and are in a location where the potential for future new building construction is likely by virtue of an appropriate zoning classification for the property or likely zoning designation in the future, the presence of street frontage/street access or reasonable expectation of said street or roadway extension and ready, immediate access to all basic municipal utility services. Basic municipal utility services include water, gas, electric, communication and sanitary sewer services. In addition to these considerations, the presence or absence of environmentally sensitive land features may also influence the evaluation of whether the parcel in question is developable. 
    Development or redevelopment means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate including, but not limited to, new building or construction of other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations. 
    Easement means an authorization by a property owner for another entity or person to use a designated part of the owner's property for a specified purpose. 
    Environmental report means a graphic and/or written summary of observed physical features on a parcel of land prepared by a person or firm with the background and credentials to perform such assessments and reports with particular attention paid towards natural topographic features such as steep slopes (greater than 18 percent slope), soils, wetlands and related drainage areas of local streams or rivers, floodplain areas, floodways and important plant communities including significant tree stands. The city engineer shall provide a list of pre-approved firms to the subdivider judged to be qualified to prepare the environmental report. The report must contain comments on the general characteristics of the subject property and, where appropriate, identification of important environmentally sensitive features on abutting property if protection measures on the subject property under consideration are necessary to protect the integrity of an important environmental feature on an abutting property. Said report shall recommend whether the site is suitable for development or if special measures need to be taken to protect identified environmentally sensitive land features on the subject property or if measures are necessary to protect such features on abutting properties with recommendations on the means to protect said features.
