    Environmentally sensitive land features means those natural features of land that are characterized by elements such as wetlands as defined herein and adjacent drainage areas important to the natural function of the wetlands, steep slopes (at least 18 percent slope), floodplains and floodways, natural prairie plant areas and significant tree stands, said tree stands consisting of overstory hardwood species trees with a mature height exceeding 30 feet, said species including oak, maple, linden, hickory and evergreen species such as pine, spruce and fir. 
    Environmentally sensitive slopes means naturally occurring slope features prior to development or land alteration with the following characteristics: 
(1)  Steep slope: 18 percent-25 percent, managed development allowed; 
(2)  Critical slope: 25 percent-40 percent, restricted or limited development allowed if engineering designs are deemed acceptable; 
(3)  Protected slopes: 40 percent or more, no development allowed. 
    Final plat means the map or plan of record of a subdivision and any accompanying material, as described in this chapter. 
    Flood hazard area and 500-year floodplain mean any area subject to flooding by a two-tenths percent (0.2 percent) probability flood, otherwise referred to as a 500 year flood; as designated by the state department of natural resources or the Federal Emergency Management Agency of the United States Department of Homeland Security. The flood hazard area is made up of two components: the floodway area and the floodway fringe area. 
    Floodplain buildable area means that portion of the lot remaining after the minimum yard area requirements (i.e., setbacks) of the zoning chapter have been met and shall not include that portion of the property within the 500-year floodplain. 
    Floodway , which is part of the flood hazard area or 100-year floodplain, means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent lands that must be reserved and protected in order to discharge and convey the waters of a 100 year flood event without cumulatively raising the waterway surface elevation more than one foot. The floodway is that area designated by the official flood boundary and floodway map for the city. 
    Floodway fringe means that portion of the 100-year (one percent flood) and 500-year (0.2 percent flood) floodplain extending beyond the floodway boundary. These boundaries are illustrated on the officially adopted flood boundary and floodway map for the city. 
    Governing body means the city council of the City of Cedar Falls, Iowa. 
    Improvements , also meaning required public infrastructure, means changes to land necessary to prepare it for building sites including, but not limited to, grading, filling, street paving, turning lanes, roadway medians, curb paving, sidewalks, walk ways, parking lots, recreation trails, bicycle paths, public parks, landscaping, including earthen berms or grass sod, tree plantings, water mains, sewers, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, drainageways, traffic signals, other traffic control devices, public utilities and any other public works, fixtures and appurtenances required by the city. 
    Lot means a tract of land represented and identified by number or letter designation on an official plat. A lot, not an outlot, identified on an official plat, will be presumed to be that portion of the plat that is intended for new building development. 
    Lot, corner, means a lot situated at the intersection of two streets. 
    Lot, double frontage, means any lot which is not a corner lot which abuts two streets on two sides. 
    Major subdivision means all subdivisions not classified as minor subdivisions, including, but not limited to, subdivisions of three or more lots, or any size subdivision requiring any new street or extension of local government public service or utility facilities, street extension or the creation of any public improvements. 
    Metes and bounds means the method used to describe a tract of land that uses distances and angles, distances and bearings, or describes the boundaries of the parcel by reference to physical features of the land. 
    Minor subdivision and minor plat means any subdivision of land, which results in the creation of at least one potentially developable parcel as determined by city staff. Said subdivision shall contain no more than three lots including the remaining portion of the original parcel fronting on an existing street, not involving any new public street or road extension or construction and not involving the extension of municipal facilities, or the creation of any public improvement, and not adversely affecting the remainder of the parcel or adjoining property, and not in conflict with any provision or portion of the master plan, official map, zoning chapter, or this chapter. In general, deed transfers of smaller unbuildable parcels of land between property owners will not be considered a minor plat. In certain situations, a reconfiguration of existing lots or property lines on existing lots may not result in creation of any new developable lots. However, said reconfiguration of lot lines may result in the need for added utility easements or possible relocation of certain existing municipal service facilities. In these cases a minor plat will be required in order to establish and record proper utility line locations or utility easements. A minor plat shall also be considered to be a "final plat" for purposes of review, approval and recording of the approved minor plat. 
    Nonresidential subdivision means a subdivision, the intended use of which is other than residential, such as a commercial or industrial use. Such subdivision shall comply with the applicable provisions of this chapter. 
    Official plat means either an auditor's plat or a major or minor subdivision plat that meets the requirements of Iowa Code chs. 354 and 355 and that has been filed for record in the offices of the recorder, auditor and assessor. 
    Outlot means an area of a subdivision plat that is reserved or set aside for some purpose other than new building construction or public street use and is identified on the plat as an outlot or separate tract. 
    Owner means the legal entity holding title to the property being subdivided, or such representative as is fully and legally empowered to act on the owner's behalf. The owner may also be known as the subdivider. 
    Planning commission means the appointed commission designated by the city council for the purpose of this chapter, and may also be known as the zoning commission, in which case such commission shall be known as the planning and zoning commission. 
    Plat means a map, drawing, or chart on which an owner's or subdivider's plan for the subdivision of land is presented, which the owner or subdivider submits for approval and intends, in final form, to record. 
    Resubdivision means a change in a plat of an approved or recorded subdivision plat if such change affects any street layout on such map or area reserved thereon for public use or any lot line, or if such a change affects any map or plat legally recorded prior to December 10, 1979. 
    Separate tract or outlot means a parcel of land or a group of contiguous parcels of land under one ownership not intended for building development. All such tracts or outlots illustrated on a subdivision plat must be identified in the deed of dedication or owner's statement submitted with the plat as to their future intended usage, maintenance and ownership. 
    Soils report also geotechnical soils report means a report prepared by a licensed geotechnical engineer or a registered civil engineer experienced in soils engineering. A report that provides an understanding of soil conditions affecting the site. The report evaluates projects where foundations are supported by fill, locations with high groundwater tables, steep slopes or areas within floodplains. When these conditions are present a geotechnical soils report shall be required by the city engineer. 
    Street means public property, not an alley, intended for vehicular circulation. In appropriate contexts, the term "street" may refer to the right-of-way bounded by the property lines of such public property, or may refer to the paving installed within such right-of-way. 
    Street, arterial, major or minor arterial, means a street primarily intended to carry large volumes of traffic from one part of the city to another, and not intended to provide access to abutting property via curb cuts for private driveways. Arterial streets are characterized by relatively few intersections with other streets. Said streets must be established with a dedicated public right-of-way area measuring at least one 100 feet in width. 
    Street, collector, means a street primarily designed to collect traffic from residential streets and to provide a linkage to arterial streets. Collector streets must be established with a dedicated public right-of-way area measuring at least 80 feet in width. Private driveway curb cut access points are to be limited or consolidated upon review and approval by the city engineer. 
    Street, residential sub-collector, means a street primarily designed to provide access to individual building lots with frequent driveway/curb cut access points and frequent intersections with other residential streets, said street providing an access route to nearby collector streets. All such residential streets must be established with a dedicated right-of-way area measuring at least 60 feet in width unless a waiver from this requirement is granted by the city council. 
    Subdivider means the owner of the property being subdivided, or such other person or entity legally empowered to act on the owner's behalf. 
    Subdivision means the division of land into two or more parts, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership and/or building development. The term "subdivision," when appropriate to the context, may refer to the process of subdividing or to land subdivided. The term "subdivision" shall also apply to proposals to establish public roadways or public rights-of-way for dedication to the city. However, the sale or exchange of small parcels of land to or between the owners of adjacent platted lots i.e., deed transfers, where such sale or exchange does not create any additional building lots or developable parcels and where the land sold or exchanged constitutes less than 25 percent of the area of the enlarged lot after such transfer, shall not be considered a subdivision. 
    Subdivision agent means any person who represents, or acts for or on behalf of a subdivider or owner, in selling, leasing or developing, or offering to sell, lease or develop any interest, lot, parcel, unit, site or plat in a subdivision, except an attorney-at-law whose representation of another person consists solely of rendering legal services. 
    Subdivision plat means the graphic representation of the subdivision of land, prepared by a state licensed land surveyor, having a number or letter designation for each lot, tract or outlot within the plat and a succinct name or title that is unique for the county where the land is located. 
    Traffic study or traffic report means a study prepared by a licensed transportation engineer or registered civil engineer experienced in transportation engineering. The study evaluates the existing transportation system serving a particular area and identifies any improvements necessary to maintain or improve the level of service of the transportation system. Typical components of a study include data collection, existing and projected traffic volumes, necessary improvements, impacts upon private properties and structures, alternate alignments, physical constraints and roadway design criteria to be utilized. Traffic studies shall be required when the city engineer determines that known or suspected traffic conflict issues are presented in conjunction with a proposed subdivision plat. 
    Utilities means systems for the distribution or collection of water, gas, electricity, wastewater, sewage, stormwater, telephone, cablevision, internet or other communication or information systems. 
    Watercourse means intermittent and perennial drainageways as indicated by the county soil survey or other official source. 
    Wetlands means that classification of land subject to protection measures as indicated by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers or this Code. The term shall also mean those lands transitional between terrestrial and aquatic systems where the water table is usually at or near the surface and the land is normally or intermittently or seasonally covered in shallow water. Said wetlands must: 
(1)  Have a predominance of hydric soils; 
(2)  Be inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support a prevalence of hydrophytic vegetation (i.e., plants that tolerate seasonal or permanent saturated soil conditions) typically adapted to life in saturated soil conditions; and 
(3)  Under normal circumstances, support a prevalence of hydrophytic vegetation. 
(Code 2017, § 24-2; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010; Ord. No. 2854, § 1, 10-5-2015) 
Sec. 20-3. - Approval required. 
    Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, before any sale or contract for sale is made for any part thereof, and before any permit for the erection of a structure, parking lot or other facility in such proposed subdivision shall be granted, the subdivider, or the developer, or his authorized agent shall apply for and secure approval of such proposed subdivision in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 2017, § 24-3; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-4. - Manner of classification. 
    The department of community development shall determine whether the proposed subdivision is a major or minor subdivision as defined in section 20-2. To aid in this determination, the subdivider or authorized subdivision agent shall submit in writing or otherwise document the principal features of access, relationship to public streets and public utilities, proposed number of lots, and other pertinent data. If the proposed subdivision is determined to be major, the developer shall be required to submit preliminary and final plats in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. If the proposed subdivision is determined to be a minor subdivision the developer shall be required to submit a minor plat in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 2017, § 24-4; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-5. - Improvements. 
(a)  Required. The owner shall, at the owner's expense, install and construct all improvements required by this chapter. All required improvements shall be installed and constructed in accordance with the design standards established for such improvements by the city and Cedar Falls Utilities (CFU) and as shown on the approved preliminary plat. 
(b)  Inspection. All improvements shall be inspected to ensure compliance with the requirements of this chapter. The cost of such inspection shall be borne by the subdivider, and shall be the actual cost of the inspection to the city. 
(c)  Minimum improvements. The improvements set forth below for all proposed subdivision plats shall be considered the minimum improvements necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(1)  Streets. 
a.  The owner of land being platted/subdivided shall provide the grading of the entire street right-of-way, alley or public place and provide appropriate paving, including curb and gutter on all streets. All streets or alleys shall be of such width and shall be so constructed as to meet the standards of the city (and be in compliance with state law). If any street is established with boulevards or divided lanes that incorporate natural landscaping, private entry signs or other optional decorative components desired by the subdivider, said street must be established with adequate provision for future maintenance of said landscaped area and other private components by the subdivider or property owners' association within the subdivision plat area unless the city agrees to assume maintenance responsibilities. These provisions relating to boulevard establishment and maintenance must be outlined in the subdivision deed of dedication or statement of restrictions and shall be subject to approval by the city council. 
b.  Under appropriate circumstances the city may require, as a condition for approval of the plat, dedication and improvement of a street having a width greater than necessary to meet the needs of the platted area, but necessary to complete the city street system as it relates to both the area being platted and other areas. In such event, the city shall pay the subdivider the difference in cost of improving the wider street and the street width reasonable to meet the foreseeable needs of the subdivision taken alone. The streets shall, upon final approval by the city engineer and acceptance by the city, become the property of the city. In order to provide a continuous street system that will serve adjacent properties in the future, all streets shall be constructed to the outer or perimeter boundary of the plat area to allow for the future extension of said street to adjacent properties. An adequate turn-around area at the end of said streets as determined by the city engineer, must be provided and maintained by the subdivider until a connecting street is improved, dedicated and accepted by the city council. A waiver of the requirement of street construction to the outer boundary of the plat area may be granted by the city council in consideration of special circumstances upon the recommendation of the city engineer. In such cases of waiver, adequate easements must be provided in anticipation of future street extension. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer system. 
a.  The owner of the land being platted shall make adequate provision for the disposal of sanitary sewage from the platted area with due regard being given to present or reasonably foreseeable needs. There shall be constructed, at the subdivider's expense, a sanitary sewer system including all necessary pumping stations, pumping equipment, manholes, and all other necessary or desirable appurtenances to provide for the discharge of sanitary sewage from all lots or parcels of land within the platted area to a connection with the city's sanitary sewer system. The sanitary sewer system shall be constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications of the city and at the sewer grades as established by the subdivider's engineer and reviewed and approved by city staff. In order to provide for the future extension of sanitary sewer service to adjacent properties, the sanitary sewer system shall be installed and constructed to the outer or perimeter boundaries of the proposed subdivision area. A waiver of the requirement of sanitary sewer construction to the outer boundary of the plat area may be granted by the city council in consideration of special circumstances upon the recommendation of the city engineer. In such cases of waiver, adequate easements must be provided in anticipation of future sewer extension. The developer shall pay any sanitary sewer tapping fees that may be required by the city. Said tapping fees must be paid at the time of final plat approval by the city council. 
b.  Under appropriate circumstances the city may require, as a condition for approval of the plat, installation of a sanitary sewer that is larger than necessary to meet the needs of the platted area, but necessary to complete the city sanitary sewer system as it relates to both the area being platted and other areas. In such event the city shall pay the subdivider the difference in cost of the pipe and installation between the sewer required for the subdivision plat and the larger sewer structure necessary to serve the larger area beyond the boundaries of the plat. The above-mentioned facilities for the collection and disposal of sanitary sewage from the platted area shall, upon final approval and acceptance by the city, become the property of the city and shall be established within the public street right-of-way or within public easements of sufficient width to allow adequate access for future maintenance, repair and reconstruction of said facilities, including excavation. 
(3)  Storm sewer system. The owner of land being platted shall install and construct a storm sewer system adequate to serve the plat area. The storm sewer system shall be extended to the outer or perimeter boundaries of the proposed subdivision plat area for the purpose of future extension to adjacent properties. A waiver of the requirement of storm sewer construction to the outer boundary of the plat area may be granted by the city council in consideration of special circumstances upon the recommendation of the city engineer. In such cases of waiver, adequate easements must be provided in anticipation of future sewer extension. 
a.  Under appropriate circumstances the city may require, as a condition for approval of the plat, installation of a storm sewer system that is larger than necessary to meet the needs of the platted area, but necessary to complete the city storm sewer system as it relates to both the area being platted and other areas. In such event, the city will pay the subdivider the difference in cost of the pipe and installation between the sewer required for the subdivision plat and the larger sewer structure necessary to serve the larger area beyond the boundaries of the plat. 
b.  The sewers shall, upon inspection, approval, and acceptance by the city, become the property of the city and said sewers shall be established within the public street right-of-way or within public easements of sufficient width to allow adequate access for future maintenance, repair and reconstruction of said facilities, including excavation. In the storm sewer design phase, consideration shall be given to alternatives and principles of stormwater management, such as "conservation design principles" or in conformance with the provisions of a stormwater management plan if such plan has been adopted by the city. 
(4)  Stormwater management. All requirements outlined in this Code relating to stormwater management, illicit discharges and erosion control, or any similar provisions (chapter 24) shall be followed in accordance with city engineering division specifications. 
(5)  Water distribution system. The owner of land being platted shall install and construct a water main distribution system in accordance with the service policy of the municipal water utility of the city to adequately serve all lots or parcels of land within the platted area, with due regard to the present and reasonably foreseeable needs of the entire area including extension of said water distribution system to the outer or perimeter boundaries of the proposed subdivision plat area for the purpose of future extension to adjacent properties, and shall connect the same to the existing municipal water distribution system. Extension of the water main/distribution system to the outer boundary of the subdivision plat may be waived by the city council and Cedar Falls Utilities upon recommendation by the city engineer. In such cases of waiver, adequate easements must be provided in anticipation of future water line extension. 
a.  The water mains/distribution system and service stubs or service conduits shall be constructed in accordance with specifications of the municipal water utility of the city. The subdivider or subdivider's engineer shall apply for a construction permit, submitting reproducible copies of the required state department of natural resources forms and appropriate schedules and water system construction plans for review by the municipal water utility of the city. 
b.  The owner shall construct the water system extension according to requirements of the municipal water utility of the city and provide the required bonds and insurance documents to the city. Upon final approval and acceptance by the municipal water utility of the city the water mains shall become the property of the municipal water utility of the city. Said water system lines and facilities shall be established within public street right-of-way or public easements of sufficient width to allow adequate access for future maintenance, repair and reconstruction of said facilities, including excavation. 
(6)  Electric distribution system. Underground electric facilities shall be installed by the municipal electric utility of the city to all newly platted residential subdivisions in accordance with the electric service policy of the municipal electric utility of the city. 
a.  The owner of the land being platted shall submit a plan of the proposed subdivision to the municipal electric utility of the city. The municipal electric utility shall design and request easements to accommodate electric facilities in the newly platted subdivision. All said public easements shall be established of sufficient width to allow for adequate access for future maintenance, repair and reconstruction of said facilities, including excavation. Said electric facilities shall be extended to the outer perimeter or boundary of the subdivision plat area unless a waiver of said extension is granted by the municipal electric utility of the city and the city. In such cases of waiver of extension, adequate easements must be provided in anticipation of future electric line extensions. 
b.  Requests for unusual underground electric facilities shall be evaluated on an individual basis. For these unusual cases, an allowance of three years base revenues shall be made by the municipal electric utility to cover installation of electric facilities with the balance of the estimated extension cost to be paid in advance by the owner/subdivider. At the end of the three years the owner/subdivider may request a review of the actual cost of the extension and the actual base revenue for three years. 
(7)  Street lighting. Street lighting for newly platted subdivisions shall normally be designed and installed by the municipal electric utility of the city with the approval of the engineering division of the city. All lighting system costs shall be borne and paid for by the owner. Allowable street lighting fixtures shall be determined by the municipal electric utility. Any unusual request for street lights other than the standard fixture and pole shall be at the customer/developer expense and approved by the municipal electric utility of the city of and the city. 
(8)  Communication systems. The owner of the land being platted shall submit a plan of the proposed subdivision to all authorized communication network providers in the area. These providers include private service providers and the municipal communication utility of the city. All communication facilities established within a subdivision shall utilize a common trench area as designed and constructed by city utilities personnel and the city engineer. Public easements must be established of sufficient width necessary to accommodate the installation and excavation/repair of all communication facilities in the newly platted subdivision. 
(9)  Natural gas distribution system. Natural gas service shall be made available to the land being platted in accordance with the service policy of the municipal gas utility of the city. The subdivider of land being platted shall apply for natural gas service, submitting a plan of the proposed subdivision to the municipal gas utility of the city. The owner and the municipal gas utility of the city shall install a natural gas distribution system in accordance with the service policy of the municipal gas utility of the city. The natural gas distribution system is the property of the municipal gas utility of the city. Said natural gas system lines and facilities shall be established within the public street right-of-way or within public easements of sufficient width to allow adequate access for future maintenance, repair and reconstruction of said facilities, including excavation. Said natural gas lines must be extended to the outer perimeter or boundary of the subdivision plat area unless a waiver of said extension is granted by the municipal gas utility of the city and the city council upon the recommendation of the city engineer. In such cases of waiver, adequate easements must be provided in anticipation of future water line extension. 
(10)  Other improvements. The owner of the land being platted shall be responsible for the installation of sidewalks within the public right-of-way, grading, seeding or sodding of all lots, the planting of any required trees in the parking areas and the installation of street signs and other public appurtenances such as traffic signals, medians, turn lanes, extension of existing turn lanes, etc., as required by the city engineer. All such improvements shall be constructed under the direction of the appropriate city authority. Public sidewalks shall be installed at the time of new building construction on new or recently platted lots or within five years following final subdivision approval. The required width of the sidewalk shall be determined by the city engineer. Sidewalks must also be installed at the time of new home construction adjacent to abutting streets outside of the subdivision if lots within the subdivision abut the adjacent street right-of-way. After five years following final subdivision approval the owners of any undeveloped lots or properties adjacent to public right-of-way areas where public sidewalks are required, shall install the required sidewalk to city specifications upon notification by the city engineering division. In those cases where a property owner is unable or unwilling to install said required sidewalk the city council may contract the work to be completed and assess the cost for said sidewalk installation to said property owner. Future maintenance of all such sidewalks will be the responsibility of the owner of the private property abutting said public sidewalk in conformance with chapter 19. In appropriate circumstances the city may require the installation of a sidewalk wider than 48 inches. In these cases the city may pay for the "over-size" difference in cost between the typical sidewalk width (i.e., 48 inches width) and the enlarged sidewalk width. 
(11)  Public accessways, walkways or sidewalks. In appropriate circumstances public accessways, walkways or sidewalks shall be required to be installed by the owner across private land for purposes of providing access to nearby subdivisions, schools, recreation trails, parks, open green space areas or other facilities where public access is judged to be necessary. The required width of said walkway or accessway shall be determined by the city engineer. In these cases the subdivider shall be required to provide public access easements of sufficient width to allow installation and maintenance of said pedestrian accessways. The subdivider shall be required to install said pedestrian accessways in conjunction with the installation of other required public infrastructure facilities and improvements in the subdivision in conjunction with final plat approval. The owner or property owners' association within the subdivision shall be responsible for future maintenance of said pedestrian accessways. In cases of doubt regarding responsibility or maintenance, the immediately abutting property owners shall be responsible for maintenance of said walkways, accessways or sidewalks. In appropriate circumstances a delay in pedestrian accessway or sidewalk installation may be appropriate beyond the time needed to construct and install other required public infrastructure and shall be subject to a special agreement between the subdivider and the city with respect to timing of installation of said walkways, access ways or sidewalks. 
(12)  Public recreation trails. In those cases where the city trails plan illustrates the need for the establishment of a public recreation trail that may pass through or upon the proposed subdivision plat, the subdivider shall be required to provide adequate access easements for the establishment of said trail area in conformance with city engineering specifications. The required width of all such trails shall be determined by the city engineer. Recreation trail installation costs shall be shared between the owner and city with an approved agreement upon recommendation by the city engineer. In those cases where a public recreation trail is indicated on the city trails plan in a location where a typical city sidewalk is to be installed (i.e., in the adjacent public right-of-way), the owner shall be responsible for installing the recreation trail in lieu of the typical public sidewalk in that location with the provision that the city shall pay for the difference in the cost of a typical sidewalk section (i.e., 48 inches width) compared to the cost of the trail section. Public recreation trail installation shall normally be completed in conjunction with the installation of other required public infrastructure improvements in conjunction with final plat approval. In appropriate circumstances a delay in trail installation may be appropriate and such delay beyond the time frame for installation of other required public infrastructure shall be subject to a special agreement between the owner and the city. 
(d)  Easements required. Easements shall be established when specified by city officials including city utilities personnel for purposes of providing access to or use of various public facilities including, but not limited to, municipal utilities, sewers, drainageways, trails, public access ways or any other such designated easement areas. All said easements shall remain open without any obstruction, and no building structures of any kind, whether permanent, temporary or portable, shall be permitted within said easement areas. All easement areas shall be free of building obstructions and made accessible in order to allow ease of entry and permit repair and maintenance activities as needed within said easement area. Property line fences, landscaping materials or driveways may be installed in said easement areas upon condition that all said components or obstructions shall be removed at the expense of the property owner in case of repair, maintenance, installation or excavation in the easement area. All required easements shall be clearly shown and labeled on subdivision plats and described further within the subdivision owner's statement of deed of dedication using standard easement provision language as specified by city officials. 
(1)  Public utilities. Where alleys are not provided, or where otherwise required by the present or future placement of public utilities, utility easements of not less than ten feet in width shall be granted by the owner along rear, and where necessary, along front or side lot lines for public utility requirements. Except where prohibited by topography, such easements shall be centered on lot lines. Easements of greater width may be required along lot lines, or across lots when necessary for the placement and maintenance of utilities. No buildings or structures, except as necessary for utilities, shall be permitted on such easements. 
(2)  Easements along streams and watercourses. Wherever any stream or surface watercourse is located in an area that is being subdivided, the subdivider shall, at the subdivider's own expense, make adequate provisions for the proper drainage of surface water and shall provide and dedicate to the city an easement along said stream or watercourse as necessary for the proper maintenance of the watercourse, as recommended by the city engineer. All said drainage easements must be kept free of any obstruction including landscaping features, fences, berms, re-grading or similar activities that alter or change the drainage patterns through the easement area. 
(e)  Maintenance bond required. The owner of the land being platted shall be required to provide to the city property maintenance bonds satisfactory to the city, so as to ensure that for a period of three years from the date of acceptance of any required public improvement the owner shall be responsible to maintain all such improvements in good repair. In those situations where repairs of certain infrastructure are necessary within the three-year bonding period, the city engineer shall determine whether a new maintenance bond shall be established by the owner for an additional three-year period following reconstruction/repair of said infrastructure. This additional bonding period shall be established only for the portion of failed infrastructure which has been repaired. 
(Code 2017, § 24-5; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-6. - Minimum standards for the design of subdivisions. 
(a)  Standards prescribed. The standards set forth in this chapter shall be considered the minimum standards necessary to protect the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)  Land suitability. No land shall be built upon which is found to be unsuitable for building construction by reason of flooding, ponding, poor drainage, adverse soil conditions, adverse geological formations, unsatisfactory topography or other conditions likely to be harmful to the public health, safety or general welfare, unless such unsuitable conditions are corrected to the satisfaction of the city. Other land features that shall be deemed to be undevelopable shall be any that are judged to be an environmentally sensitive land feature including wetlands and adjacent drainage areas important to the natural function of the wetlands, steep slopes, natural prairie areas, and significant tree stands. These land features shall be identified and evaluated as to their environmentally sensitive importance by an environmental report to be provided by the owner. If land is found to be unsuitable for subdivision for any of the reasons cited in this section, the city council shall state its reasons in writing and afford the subdivider an opportunity to present data regarding such unsuitability. Thereafter, the city council may reaffirm, modify or withdraw its determination regarding such unsuitability. 
(c)  Lands subject to flooding. Any portion of a proposed subdivision or plat that encroaches into or incorporates into the plat any portion of the floodway zone of the 100-year flood hazard area (i.e., 100-year floodplain), said floodway zone shall be shown on the plat as an unbuildable tract or outlot and shall not be shown as part of any platted building lot or public street or as contributing to minimum required lot area of any proposed building lot. In appropriate circumstances, bridges or stream crossings may be approved subject to Iowa Department of Natural Resources (DNR) review and approval. Clearly stated restrictions or provisions permanently prohibiting any disturbances of said floodway zone (relating to activities such as excavation, landscaping, placement of fill material, establishment of building structures, fences, parking lots or other similar facilities) shall be stated in the subdivision deed of dedication and in any document transferring ownership to said tract or outlot. Such provision shall be made permanent by the owner granting a perpetual easement in favor of the city and the general public, in the nature of a permanent floodway easement, which shall be established across the floodway area for purposes of protecting the floodway zone perpetually from development or disturbance. It is intended that all floodway zones shall remain in open green space and/or shall be used for a passive public purpose with only such minimum level of disturbance as may be permitted, subject to city review and approval. Furthermore, with respect to areas of the 100-year (one percent) or 500-year (0.2 percent) flood hazard area extending beyond the floodway zone (i.e., floodway fringe areas), no subdivision shall contain a lot or part of a lot or property intended for new building construction that is either wholly or partially located within the 500-year flood hazard area and outside or beyond the floodway zone, provided, however, that the subdivision may include newly-created lots with a floodplain buildable area outside of the 500-year flood boundary, and, provided further, that the 500-year floodplain does not encompass more than 25 percent of the newly created lot, as provided in section 26-177(c). Said floodway fringe areas may be used for open space uses such as parks, playgrounds, gardens, and parking lots. No building structures including dwellings, commercial buildings, storage sheds or garages are to be allowed in the 500-year floodplain area. 
(d)  Wetlands. No portion of a proposed subdivision or plat shall establish building lots, streets or other facilities wholly or partially in areas that are identified as wetlands or contain characteristics of wetlands as defined herein or as defined by the United States Army Corps of Engineers. All such wetland areas shall be preserved and protected along with any adjacent stream or drainage area that is necessary to the natural function of said wetland. No said wetland or nearby stream or drainage channel shall be shown on the plat as part of any developable lot for purposes of satisfying minimum required lot area. All such wetland and corresponding drainage areas must be identified and shown on the subdivision plat as a separate undevelopable tract or outlot with provisions outlined in the deed of dedication and in any document transferring ownership of said tract or outlot with clearly stated provisions permanently prohibiting any disturbances of said wetland and adjacent stream or drainage channel relating to excavation, landscaping, placement of fill material, establishment of building structures, fences, parking lots or other facilities. Such provisions shall be made permanent by the owner granting a perpetual easement in favor of the city and the general public, in the nature of protecting said wetland area perpetually from development or disturbance. All natural vegetation associated with the wetland and adjacent stream or drainage area must be maintained. Furthermore, said wetland area and, where appropriate, any adjacent stream and drainage area shall be protected with a permanent drainage/wetland easement so as to ensure no future disturbance or alteration of said wetland and drainage area. In appropriate circumstances certain wetland areas may be deemed to be of "lesser quality" or to be "less critical" wetlands by an approved environmental report, in which cases said lesser quality or less critical wetlands may be removed via an approved mitigation approval process through the United States Army Corps of Engineers along with approval by the city council upon recommendation by the city engineer. 
(e)  Plat to conform to comprehensive plan. The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets and the general nature and extent of the lots and land uses proposed shall conform to the comprehensive plan of the city, provided such plan has been adopted by the city; and shall conform to other plans, including, but not limited to, a major street plan, a sanitary sewer system plan or a parks, trails and open space plan, provided such plan has been adopted by the city. 
(f)  Construction standards for improvements. In addition to the standards set forth in this chapter, the city engineer shall from time to time prepare, and the city council shall from time to time adopt by resolution, technical standards for the construction of public improvements. Such technical standards for public improvements shall contain the minimum acceptable specifications for the construction of public improvements. Such technical standards may vary for classes of improvements, giving due regard to the classification of streets or other improvements, and the extent and character of the area served by the improvements. Upon adoption by the city council by resolution, such technical standards for public improvements shall have the same force and effect as if they were fully set forth herein. 
(g)  Parks and open space. All residential subdivisions shall be so designed as to meet the neighborhood park and open space needs of its residents. Such needs may be met by dedication and acceptance of public park land and/or by reservation by covenant of private open space, provided there shall exist sufficient covenants running with the land to ensure adequate maintenance by the property owners benefiting from such open space. 
(h)  Parks and school sites reserved. If a tract being subdivided includes lands proposed to be parks or school sites in the comprehensive plan or other official plan of the city, the owner shall indicate such areas on the plat and shall make provisions for reservation of said sites. 
(i)  Special development area (SDA). In those areas where a proposed subdivision plat incorporates special or unique environmentally sensitive land features such as floodways, floodplains, wetland areas and adjacent stream or drainage areas, steep slopes, highly erodible soils, prairie areas or significant tree areas, all said areas judged to be worthy of special protection and preservation, a special development area may be designated by the city council upon recommendation by the planning and zoning commission. A decision to allow a special development area shall be accompanied by evidence that the developer is unable to meet intended development goals due to unusual environmental features present on the property. The special development area shall afford to the subdivider an opportunity to alter the subdivision plat in such a manner that preserves and protects the identified environmentally sensitive areas while accommodating, to the maximum extent that is practicable, the density of uses envisioned by the subdivider. Only those land uses permitted in the zoning district shall be permitted. One hundred percent replacement or fulfillment of the subdivider's subdivision goals (i.e., creation of maximum number of building lots) is not ensured or guaranteed by this provision. The accommodations that may be considered by the city council as recommended by the commission are reduced lot areas, lot widths, lot depths and reduced building setback requirements, particularly relating to rear yard and side yard setback requirements, allowance of increased building height and also including minor reductions to on-site parking requirements specified in the zoning chapter along with possible reduced street widths. Reduced street widths are to be considered only in extremely unusual circumstances. As a general rule, exceptions to lot area, lot width, lot depth or building setback requirements are to be no less than 75 percent of the normal requirement for the district in which the development is located (i.e., up to 25 percent reduction). Parking requirement reductions, including certain design standards such as parking stall dimensions or driveway widths, shall be kept to a minimum and shall be allowed only the extent that such a reduction shall not create traffic or parking problems. These accommodations may be achieved through a "cluster development plan," which sets aside and preserves the identified environmentally sensitive areas and establishes a plan for the development to occur in a more compact, "cluster" development scheme on the remaining land area within the proposed subdivision. A special development area plan must be accompanied by a development agreement between the owner and the city that outlines the special accommodations, provisions and exceptions to normally required standards. The agreement must also identify the key environmentally sensitive land features to be preserved and protected and how those components will be maintained and protected in the future. 
(Code 2017, § 24-6; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010; Ord. No. 2854, § 2, 10-5-2015) 
Secs. 20-7-20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 
DIVISION 1. - MINOR PLAT 

Sec. 20-31. - Submission required. 
(a)  In a minor subdivision of land, the owner shall file for approval a minor plat which shall include six copies of said minor plat submitted to the city planner for initial review by city staff along with one reduced copy (no larger than 11 inches by 17 inches) for reproduction/copying purposes. An electronic copy of the proposed plat must also be submitted to the city engineering division utilizing a compatible AutoCAD program. The plats shall be accompanied by a signed statement from the property owner addressed to the planning and zoning commission stating the proposed intent and uses of the proposed minor plat. The plat fee must be submitted at the time of initial plat submittal. In certain cases a sanitary sewer tapping fee may be required in conjunction with minor plat approval. Said fee, if required, must be paid at the time of initial plat submittal. 
(b)  This minor plat provision shall not apply to lands acquired by the city or any city agency for use by the city. 
(Code 2017, § 24-16; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-32. - Required scale. 
    A minor plat required in this article shall be drawn to a scale of 100 feet to one inch or larger. 
(Code 2017, § 24-17; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-33. - Information required to be shown. 
    The minor plat shall be clearly labeled "minor subdivision plat" with a unique name and shall comply with relevant state code requirements pertaining to "plats of survey" and shall be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  A plat illustrating all contiguous holdings of the owner, with an indication of the portion which is proposed to be subdivided, the location of public streets and the manner wherein the property is to be subdivided, accompanied by an affidavit of ownership, which shall include the dates the respective holdings of land were acquired. 
(2)  All public streets, subdivisions, landowners and landowners' addresses within 200 feet of the boundaries of the plat. The location of adjacent landowners' properties must be shown on the plat. Addresses for each individual landowner may be provided on a separate sheet. 
(3)  A key location map showing the general location of the proposed subdivision in relation to surrounding development and in relation to the city boundaries. 
(4)  The current zoning classification of the property under consideration along with zoning classifications of all abutting properties. In addition, the required building setbacks for the property as specified in the zoning chapter shall be provided on the plat and illustrated on each lot. 
(5)  The plat shall contain the location and dimensions of: 
a.  The proposed minor subdivision's exterior boundaries and proposed lots, streets, drives, or easements therein. 
b.  Existing property lines, streets, easements, buildings, drainageways, tree masses, soil types, and other existing features affecting the plat or affected thereby. 
c.  The location and width of proposed and existing accessways, streets, highways, roads and pedestrian ways. 
d.  The location and size of existing and proposed public sewer lines, gas mains, water mains, culverts, pipelines, cables or other underground utility installations, with a description of the effect on each utility capacity and service level. 
e.  Public and private parks and open spaces. 
f.  Lot and block numbers of proposed and existing lots with the area of each lot provided on the plat. 
g.  North arrow, scale, date, subdivision's name and address, and the property's legal description. 
h.  The distance from some corner of the subdivision to some corner of the congressional division of which it is a part. 
i.  The location and dimension of any and all wetland areas shall be clearly shown. Provisions regarding the disposition of such lands shall be stated. 
j.  Areas within the 500-year flood hazard area shall be clearly shown on the plat with no lots to be established in these areas, except to the extent specifically authorized by sections 20-6(3) and 26-177(c). 
k.  Topographic elevations and contours at two-foot intervals of the property along with a soils map analysis of the property, which describes soil types and soil characteristics. Topographic elevations and soils information may be shown on an attached plat that also shows proposed lot lines and street locations of the plat map. 
l.  A written environmental report for the proposed plat area shall be completed for all minor plats containing three acres or more. Following receipt of the environmental report, city staff shall evaluate whether the minor plat may be processed as submitted or if the plat must be modified in order to preserve or protect the identified environmentally sensitive land features. It may be necessary to establish a special development area (SDA) prior to or in conjunction with minor plat approval. In appropriate cases, the requirement for submittal of an environmental report may be waived by city staff if it is clear that the proposed minor plat is merely revising property boundaries and where no new building construction is anticipated or on properties already developed where it is clearly evident that no such environmentally sensitive land features exist. In those situations where a plat contains less than three acres in area, where it is clearly evident that an important environmentally sensitive land feature exists, measures shall be taken by the owner to preserve or protect said environmental features in conformance with this article. 
m.  A written and signed statement in which the owner sets forth the proposed land uses, current zoning district, restrictions, easements, building lines, public improvements (if any), or connections to public improvements within the area of the plat. Any tracts or outlots illustrated on the plat but not intended to be developed must be identified in the owner's statement as to their intended usage, future maintenance and ownership. 
(Code 2017, § 24-18; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010; Ord. No. 2854, § 3, 10-5-2015) 
Sec. 20-34. - Procedure for approval; effect of approval. 
(a)  Following review of the initial minor plat submittal to city staff, six copies of the final minor plat signed by a licensed land surveyor in the state along with one reproducible size plat (i.e., 11 inches by 17 inches), one affidavit of ownership addressed to the planning and zoning commission, and three copies of a written and signed statement of proposed restrictions, easements and improvements within the area of the plat shall be filed with said commission, accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as stated within the city fee schedule and sanitary sewer tapping fee unless said fees have already been paid. Appropriate city council resolution forms must also be submitted by the owner (three copies each). There shall be forthwith referred to the city engineer and other city technical staff copies of said minor plat and a copy of the owner's statement along with other relevant information including the environmental report. The city engineer shall carefully examine the plat for its conformance with the laws, ordinances and policies of the city, the existing street system and good engineering practices, and shall submit findings in duplicate to the commission, together with a copy of the plat received. 
(b)  When said engineer's report is received by the planning and zoning commission, it shall as soon as possible thereafter consider the report and pass upon the minor plat. Said commission shall then set forth its recommendations in writing, whether of approval, modification or disapproval, and, in case of modification or disapproval, give its reasons therefor. Thereafter, the commission must submit all six copies of the minor plat, together with a copy of the owner's statement, a copy of the engineer's report, and a signed copy of its recommendations, to the city council. 
(c)  After receipt of the foregoing documents, the city council shall take action upon the minor plat, certifying its approval, modification or disapproval. In case of modification or disapproval, it shall give its reasons therefor. If approved, all six copies shall be duly certified and one copy shall be delivered to the planning and zoning commission, one to the city engineer, one to the city clerk, two copies to CFU and the sixth shall be returned to the owner or subdivider. 
(d)  Following final approval of the minor plat the subdivider shall supply to the city engineer a reproducible full sized paper copy along with an electronic copy of the approved plat to the city engineering division utilizing a compatible AutoCAD format. 
(e)  The approval of the minor plat by the city council constitutes acceptance of the subdivision and authorization to proceed with development. 
(f)  Prior to approval of the minor plat by the city council, if any public improvements are required, the owner shall proceed with submittal of construction plans for all said required improvements to the city engineer and shall submit construction plans, bonds, financial security and other required documents and certifications in conformance with section 20-125. 
(Code 2017, § 24-19; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Secs. 20-35-20-56. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 20-57. - Submission required. 
    Requirements of the preliminary plat. The subdivider shall prepare and file with the city planner six copies of the preliminary plat, drawn at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet or larger to be submitted for initial city staff review. A reduced size plat (i.e., 11 inches by 17 inches) shall be submitted for reproduction/copying purposes. A proposed owner's statement or deed of dedication shall also be submitted along with plat fee payment. Sheet size of full size plats shall not exceed 24 inches by 36 inches. Where more than one sheet is required, the sheets shall show the number of the sheet and the total number of sheets in the plat, and match lines indicating where other sheets adjoin. 
(Code 2017, § 24-27; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-58. - Information required to be shown. 
    The preliminary plat shall be clearly marked "preliminary plat" and shall present the total land holdings of the owner on adjacent land or abutting the area intended for immediate development unless said larger property area is allowed to be excluded from the preliminary plat presentation by the city engineer. The preliminary plat shall show or have attached thereto, the following: 
(1)  Title, scale, north arrow and date. 
(2)  Proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not duplicate or resemble existing subdivision names in the county, as approved by the county auditor. 
(3)  The name and address of the owner and the name, address and profession of the person preparing the plat. The agent, if any, representing the owner must be clearly identified with name, address and profession. 
(4)  A key location map showing the general location of the proposed subdivision in relation to surrounding development and in relation to the city boundaries. 
(5)  The names and locations of adjacent subdivisions and the names of record owners and location of adjoining parcels of unplatted land shall be shown on the plat. A list of all owners of record of property located within 200 feet of the subdivision boundary shall be attached. The addresses of all record owners within 200 feet shall also be provided. These addresses may be provided on a separate sheet. 
(6)  The location of existing property lines, streets and alleys, easements, buildings, utilities, watercourses, tree masses, and other existing features affecting the plat. 
(7)  Existing and proposed zoning of the proposed subdivision and adjoining property with a statement of minimum required building setbacks on each lot as specified in the zoning chapter. 
(8)  Topographic elevations and contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet accompanied by a note on the plat briefly describing the nature and extent of any topographic changes. 
(9)  The legal description of the area being platted. 
(10)  The boundary of the area being platted, shown as a dark line, with the approximate length of boundary lines and the approximate location of the property in reference to known section lines. 
(11)  The layout, numbers and approximate dimensions and area of proposed lots. Building setback lines as specified in the zoning chapter, must be illustrated on each lot adjacent to all proposed public rights-of-way. 
(12)  The location, width and dimensions of all streets and alleys proposed to be dedicated for public use. If boulevard streets are proposed, said boulevards must be clearly illustrated and indicated whether the boulevard is to be landscaped or made up of other material, specifying such material. 
(13)  Illustrate the location of all existing and proposed public sidewalks, trails or other pedestrian pathways. 
(14)  The proposed names of all streets in the area being platted. Proposed street names shall not resemble or duplicate the names of existing streets within the city unless the proposed street is a continuation of an existing street. 
(15)  Present and proposed utility systems, including sanitary and storm sewers, other drainage facilities, water lines, gas mains, electric utilities. 
(16)  Present and proposed easements, showing locations, widths, purposes and limitations. 
(17)  Parcels of land proposed to be dedicated or reserved for schools, parks, playgrounds, or other public, semi-public or community purposes, or shown for such purpose in the comprehensive plan or other adopted plans. 
(18)  Regulatory flood elevation data. Limits of the 500-year floodplain boundaries including floodway and floodway fringe, original and revised, must be shown upon the plat. 
(19)  The location and dimensions of any and all wetland areas, as defined herein, shall be clearly shown. Provisions regarding the disposition of such lands shall be stated. 
(20)  The plat shall be accompanied by a written and signed statement or deed of dedication in which the subdivider sets forth the proposed restrictions, easements, building lines, public improvements and other features, within the area of the plat. Any tracts or outlots illustrated on the plat but not intended to be developed must be identified in the owner's statement or deed of dedication as to their intended usage, future maintenance and ownership. 
(21)  The plat shall be accompanied by an aerial photograph of the proposed development site with soil types identified on said photograph. A soils analysis shall also be provided which describes soil types present on the site along with a description of the key characteristics of each soil type. 
(22)  Any other pertinent information, including, but not limited to, traffic reports, or more detailed soils reports, geotechnical soils reports as specified by the city engineer. 
(23)  The fee, as required by the city's fee schedule for subdivision plats. 
(Code 2017, § 24-28; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-59. - Submittal of environmental report. 
(a)  In all cases, where a preliminary plat is submitted for consideration, a written environmental report must be submitted in conjunction with plat submittal. 
(b)  Following receipt of the environmental report, city staff shall evaluate whether the preliminary plat can be processed as submitted or if the plat must be modified in order to preserve or protect any identified environmentally sensitive land features. 
(c)  If a preliminary plat is submitted at the time of year when it is not practical to produce a thorough environmental report or when it is difficult to conduct accurate on-site inspections (i.e., mid-winter), the preliminary plat may be considered with the understanding that a complete environmental report reflecting actual site conditions shall be submitted prior to final plat submittal. If the final environmental report indicates that streets or lot lines may need to be relocated or similar plat changes are necessary in order to accommodate environmentally sensitive land features, the preliminary plat shall be amended accordingly. The preliminary plat may need to be re-submitted illustrating the necessary revisions. In appropriate circumstances a special development area (SDA) shall be established with city council approval in conjunction with preliminary plat approval. In appropriate circumstances establishment of an SDA may involve rezoning a portion of said property, which shall be accomplished prior to final plat approval. Approval of the preliminary plat without an approved environmental report on file does not guarantee final plat approval based on the original preliminary plat submittal. A final plat shall not be approved without submittal of the required environmental report. 
(Code 2017, § 24-29; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-60. - Procedure for approval; effect of approval. 
(a)  Following preliminary staff review of the plat, six copies of the corrected preliminary plat shall be submitted along with one copy of an attorney's title opinion addressed to the city planning and zoning commission, together with three copies of the owner's statement or deed of dedication, shall be filed with the commission, accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as stated within the city fee schedule. The attorney's title opinion shall state the names of the owners or holders of mortgages, liens or other encumbrances on the land being platted and shall note the encumbrances, along with any bonds securing the encumbrances. Lien waivers and mortgage approvals shall be submitted prior to plat approval. The plat and plat fee along with all required documents shall be in order and in conformance with city requirements prior to referral of the plat to the planning and zoning commission. 
(1)  Appropriate city council resolution forms shall be submitted by the developer (three copies each). 
(2)  There shall forthwith be referred one copy of the plat and a copy of the owner's statement to the city engineer. The city engineer shall carefully examine the plat as to its compliance with the laws and ordinances of the city, the existing street system and good engineering practices, and shall submit the engineer's findings in duplicate to the commission, together with the copy of the plat received. 
(b)  When the engineer's report is received by the commission, it shall as soon as possible thereafter consider the report and pass upon the plat. It shall then set forth its recommendations in writing, whether of approval, modification or disapproval. In case of modification or disapproval, it shall give its reasons therefor. The commission shall forthwith submit six copies of the preliminary plat, together with a copy of the owner's statement, a copy of the engineer's report and a signed copy of its recommendations to the city council. The preliminary plat shall be in complete conformance with city engineering specifications prior to submittal of the plat to the city council. 
(c)  The council shall then take action upon the preliminary plat, certifying its approval, modification or disapproval. In case of modification or disapproval, it shall give its reasons therefor. If approved, all six copies shall be duly certified and one copy shall be delivered to the commission, one to the city engineer, one to the city clerk, two to Cedar Falls Utilities and the sixth shall be returned to the owner or subdivider. 
(d)  Following final approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall supply to the city engineer a reproducible copy of the approved plat and an electronic version on a compatible AutoCAD program. Approval of the preliminary plat by the city council shall not constitute acceptance of the subdivision, but shall be authorization to proceed with the preparation of the final plat. 
(e)  Duration of approval of preliminary plat. The approval of a preliminary plat by the city council shall be valid for a period of two years from the date of such approval, except upon application for and approval of an extension of such period of validity, by the city council. A preliminary plat shall remain valid indefinitely as long as some portion of the original preliminary plat area has been developed as part of a final plat during subsequent two-year intervals until the entire preliminary plat area is developed. 
(Code 2017, § 24-30; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-61. - Authorization to install improvements. 
(a)  The approval of the preliminary plat shall constitute authorization by the city council for the subdivider to proceed with installation and construction of required public improvements as required by this division, and as shown on the preliminary plat, subject to submittal of an approved environmental report. The environmental report shall be prepared by a qualified person or firm with demonstrated training and experience in environmental assessments. In those cases where a special development area (SDA) has been approved on a preliminary basis, construction of infrastructure shall not proceed until the SDA has gained final approval by the city council. In appropriate circumstances, approval of the SDA may involve rezoning of a portion of the property under consideration. In such circumstances, the rezoning must be completed prior to installation of any public infrastructure. 
(b)  No such improvement shall be constructed or installed until and unless the plans, profiles, cross sections, and other specifications for the construction of such improvement have been submitted to, and approved in writing by, the city engineer. All said construction plans, profiles and specifications for construction of all required improvements and public infrastructure as indicated on the preliminary plat, including cost estimates, shall be submitted and approved by the city engineer prior to submittal of the final plat to city staff for review and consideration. 
(Code 2017, § 24-31; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Secs. 20-62-20-99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 20-100. - Submission required. 
    The owner shall, within two years from the date of approval of the preliminary plat, unless such time period has been extended by the city council, prepare and file with the city planner, six unsigned copies of the proposed final plat and required attachments, as set forth in this division along with at least one reproducible-size copy (no larger than 11 inches by 17 inches) of the final plat. An electronic copy of the plat in an approved AutoCAD program must also be submitted. The proposed deed of dedication or owner's statement shall be submitted along with the plat fee. Sewer tapping fees, if any, shall be submitted at the time of initial plat submittal. Except for a final plat for a minor subdivision as set forth herein, no final plat shall be considered by the city council until and unless a preliminary plat for the area included in the proposed final plat has been approved. The final plat shall be in substantial conformance with the approved preliminary plat as determined by the city engineer. Furthermore, a final plat shall not be accepted for consideration by city staff until all required construction plans and specifications for all required improvements and public infrastructure as indicated on the approved preliminary plat, including cost estimates, have been submitted and approved by the city engineer. In addition a written environmental report shall be submitted and approved by the city engineer prior to final plat submittal. Lien waivers and mortgage releases of all interested parties shall be provided to the city prior to final plat approval. 
(Code 2017, § 24-38; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-101. - Required scale. 
    The final plat shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet or larger. Sheet size shall be no greater than 24 inches by 36 inches nor smaller than 81/2 inches by 11 inches and shall be of a size acceptable to the county auditor. If more than one sheet is used, each sheet shall clearly show the number of the sheet, the total number of sheets included in the plat, and match lines indicating where other sheets adjoin. 
(Code 2017, § 24-39; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-102. - Information to be shown. 
    The final plat shall be clearly marked "final plat" and shall comply with Iowa Code chs. 354 and 355 and show the following: 
(1)  The name of the subdivision. 
(2)  Name of the owner. 
(3)  Scale, and a graphic bar scale, north arrow and date on each sheet. 
(4)  Legal description of the property under consideration for platting. 
(5)  All monuments to be of record, as required by Iowa Code chs. 354 and 355. 
(6)  Identification of all public rights-of-way for street purposes and all other lands set aside for public purposes, said areas to be identified on the plat as separate tracts. 
(7)  Sufficient survey data to positively describe the bounds of every lot, block, street, easement, or other areas shown on the plat, as well as the outer boundaries of the subdivided lands. 
(8)  All distance, bearing, curve, and other survey data, as required by Iowa Code chs. 354 and 355. 
(9)  Street names and clear designation of public alleys. 
(10)  Block and lot numbers including the area of each proposed lot. 
(11)  Identification of building setback lines, as specified in the zoning chapter, adjacent to all public rights-of-way. 
(12)  Identification of any outlots proposed within the plat. 
(13)  Accurate dimensions for any property to be dedicated or reserved for public use, and the purpose for which such property is dedicated or reserved for public use. 
(14)  The purpose of any easement shown on the plat shall be confined to only those easements pertaining to public utilities including, but not limited to, natural gas, electric power, telephone, cable television, water, sewer; easements for recreational purposes, for pedestrian access, for ingress and egress; and such drainage easements as are deemed necessary for the orderly development of the land encompassed within the plat. 
(15)  All interior excepted parcels, clearly indicated and labeled, "not a part of this plat." 
(16)  The minimum unadjusted acceptable error of closure for all subdivision boundaries shall be 1:10,000 and shall be 1:5,000 for any individual lot. 
(17)  A statement by an state licensed land surveyor that the plat was prepared by the surveyor or under the surveyor's direct personal supervision, signed and dated by the surveyor and bearing the surveyor's state registration number or seal. 
(Code 2017, § 24-40; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-103. - Submittal of environmental report. 
    A written environmental report shall be submitted unless an environmental report for the same property has previously been submitted in conjunction with the preliminary plat for the property. If a special development area (SDA) is recommended for approval, the SDA, including any rezoning if necessary, shall gain final approval of the city council prior to final plat approval. City staff shall evaluate whether the final plat may be processed as submitted or if the plat shall be modified in order to preserve or protect the identified environmentally sensitive land features. 
(Code 2017, § 24-41; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-104. - Attachments to the final plat. 
    The following shall be attached to and accompany any final plat: 
(1)  Statement by the owner that the plat is prepared with the owner's free consent, and in accordance with the desire of the owner. This statement shall be signed and acknowledged by the owner before some officer authorized to take the acknowledgments of deeds. The statement by the owner shall also include a dedication to the public of all lands within the plat that are designed for streets, alleys, parks, open areas, school property or other public use subject to such dedication being approved by the city council. 
(2)  A statement from the mortgage holders or lien holders, if any, that the plat is prepared with their free consent and in accordance with their desire, signed and acknowledged before an officer authorized to take the acknowledgement of deeds. An affidavit and bond as provided in Iowa Code § 354.12 may be recorded in lieu of the consent of the mortgage or lien holder. When a mortgage holder or lien holder consents to the subdivision plat, a release of mortgage or lien shall be furnished for the areas of conveyance to the city or dedicated to the public. 
(3)  A complete abstract of title and an attorney's opinion showing that the fee title to the subdivision land is in the owner and that the land is free from encumbrances other than those secured by an encumbrance bond. The attorney's opinion shall state the names of the owners or holders of mortgages, liens or other encumbrances on the land being platted and shall note the encumbrances, along with any bonds securing the encumbrances. 
(4)  The encumbrance bond, if any. 
(5)  A statement of restrictions of all types that run with the land and become covenants in the deeds of lots. Any tracts or outlots illustrated on the plat but not intended to be developed must be identified in the owners' statement of restrictions as to their intended usage, future maintenance and ownership. 
(6)  A statement by the county auditor approving the name or title of the subdivision plat as required by Iowa Code § 354.11(1)e. 
(7)  A certificate by the city engineer that all required improvements have been satisfactorily completed in accordance with the construction plans as approved and in substantial compliance with the approved preliminary plat. Prior to such certification, reproduceable as built plans for all improvements shall have been provided to the city engineer in paper form and electronic AutoCAD format. In lieu thereof, the city clerk may certify that a payment and performance bond guaranteeing completion has been approved by the city attorney and filed with the clerk, or that the city council has agreed that the city shall provide the necessary improvements and installations and assess the costs against the subdivider or future property owners in the subdivision. 
(8)  Where the improvements have been installed, a resolution accepting and approving such improvements, along with the maintenance bond required by this division. 
(9)  If private streets or other private improvements have been approved by an agreement in the form of a covenant running with the land, in a form approved by the city attorney, providing for the construction or reconstruction of any improvements to meet city standards, and the assessment of all costs to the property owners in the event of annexation and dedication and acceptance, shall be required. 
(10)  All resolution forms and certificates necessary for approval by the planning and zoning commission and the city council and for signatures by the mayor and city clerk. 
a.  The maintenance bond required by sections 20-5(e) and 20-125(c). 
b.  The applicable plat fee, if any. 
(Code 2017, § 24-42; Ord. No. 2724, § 1, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 20-105. - Procedure for approval; disapproval to state reasons.
