(2)  The industrial user shall request permission from the city, as required by section 24-92, to discharge any of the wastes listed in table 1. The city shall then determine, based on the estimated maximum quantity of discharge, the monthly cost to the industrial user associated with the discharge of said waste. The wastewater discharge permit shall include the quantity and types of pollutants which may be discharged. 
a.  The superintendent has the right and authority to allocate a quantity of all restricted waste components to industrial users in a manner which is in the best interests of the city. It is the intent of the city to allocate the restricted wastes in a manner which will provide a reserve for future industries and expansion of existing industries. 
b.  No single industrial user shall be allocated any more than two times their present need (at the time of permit application) or any more than 50 percent of the allotment currently available for that pollutant, whichever is less. 
(3)  The monthly charge shall be fixed based upon the industrial user's estimated maximum quantity of discharge; not the industrial user's actual quantity of discharge. 
(4)  The industrial user shall agree to a maximum quantity of discharge for any and all restricted wastes which will be discharged. Any discharge in excess of the industrial user's allotment is not acceptable and the industrial user shall take immediate steps to eliminate future violations. In no case shall the industrial user exceed federal categorical pretreatment standards. See section 24-82. 
(b)  A surveillance monitoring fee of $350.00 per installation of equipment shall be assessed against each industrial user for which the city (rather than the user) installs surveillance monitoring equipment for the purpose of conducting wastewater sampling. 
(c)  Fees for investigating accidental discharges and permit violations may be imposed and shall be based on the time expended at $30.00 per hour. 
(d)  A wastewater discharge permit application fee shall be assessed each request for a wastewater discharge permit in the amount of $400.00. Wastewater discharge permit applications for permit renewals shall be assessed for each request in the amount of $400.00. An additional fee shall be assessed in the amount of $100.00 for past due applications as required by this division. 
(e)  The city and the user will enter into an agreement (wastewater discharge permit) as described hereinafter. The industrial user may be subject to a civil penalty of up to $1,000.00 per day for failure to meet the discharge requirements stated in the wastewater discharge permit. 
(f)  A decision of the superintendent in regard to a determination that a violation of this division has occurred and is subject to a civil penalty, may be appealed to the city council, in writing, upon payment of a filing fee of $100.00 which shall become the property of the city. The city council shall, after a public hearing on the matter, have the authority to uphold, revise, or overrule the superintendent's decision. Appeals must be made in writing within 60 days of notification of the final decision of the superintendent. 
(Code 2017, § 27-68; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-91. - Regulation of wastewater discharges. 
    No direct or indirect nondomestic contributor shall discharge or convey, or permit or allow to be discharged or conveyed, any wastewater to the POTW without a city wastewater discharge permit except as authorized under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 2017, § 27-69; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-92. - Wastewater discharge permits. 
(a)  Notification. Upon request by the superintendent, industrial users shall provide information deemed necessary by the superintendent to determine if an industrial wastewater discharge permit is required. The superintendent shall be given notice prior to making any changes in an industrial user's operations that may change its wastewater discharge characteristics. 
(b)  General permits. All significant industrial users proposing to connect to the POTW shall obtain a wastewater discharge permit before connecting to or contributing to the POTW. Each individual building sewer of a significant industrial user must have a wastewater discharge permit. Proposed new industrial users must obtain such permit prior to connecting or contributing to the POTW. 
(c)  Permit application. Industrial users required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit shall complete and file with the superintendent an application, in the form prescribed by the superintendent, and accompanied by the appropriate fee. Proposed new industrial users shall apply for an industrial wastewater discharge permit at least 90 days prior to connecting to or contributing to the POTW. In support of the application, the industrial user shall submit, in units and term appropriate for evaluation, the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and location (if different from the address), and the authorized representative; 
(2)  Primary SIC number according to the Standard Industrial Classifications Manual, Bureau of the Budget, 1972, as amended; 
(3)  a.  Wastewater constituents and characteristics including, but not limited to, those mentioned in this division 2 as determined by a reliable analytical laboratory; sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with procedures established by the EPA pursuant to section 304(g) of the Act and contained in 40 CFR 136, as amended; 
b.  Where 40 CFR 136 does not include a sampling or analytical technique for the pollutant in question, sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with the procedures set forth in the EPA publication, Sampling and Analysis Procedures for Screening of Industrial Effluents for Priority Pollutants, April 1977, and amendments thereto, or with any other sampling and analytical procedures approved by the EPA; 
(4)  Time and duration of contribution; 
(5)  Average daily and estimated peak wastewater flow rates, including daily, monthly and seasonal variations if any; 
(6)  Show all sewers, sewer connections, testing places and provide site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans when available. 
(7)  General description of activities which may be discharged to POTW; 
(8)  Where known, the nature and concentration of any pollutants in the discharge which are limited by any federal or categorical pretreatment standards, and a statement reviewed by an authorized representative of the industrial user certified to by a qualified professional indicating whether or not the pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis and if not, whether additional operation and maintenance and/or additional pretreatment is required for the industrial user to meet applicable pretreatment standards; 
(9)  If additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance will be required to meet the pretreatment standards, the schedule by which the industrial user will provide such additional pretreatment. The completion date in this schedule for categorical pretreatment standards shall not be later than the compliance date established for applicable pretreatment standards. The following conditions shall apply to the schedule: 
a.  The schedule shall contain increments of progress in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet the applicable pretreatment standards (e.g., hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans, completing final plans, executing contract for major components, commencing construction, completing construction, etc.); 
b.  The schedule shall be submitted to the superintendent for approval; 
c.  Not later than 14 days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the superintendent or his designee in cluding, as a minimum, whether or not it complied with the increments of progress to be met on such date and, if not, the date on which it expects to comply with this increment of progress, the reason for delay, and the steps being taken by the user to return the construction to the schedule established. In no event shall more than six months elapse between such progress reports to the superintendent or his designee; 
(10)  Each product produced by type, and amount; 
(11)  Number and type of employees, and hours of operation of plant and proposed or actual hours of operation of pretreatment system; 
(12)  Any other information as may be deemed by the superintendent to be necessary to evaluate the permit application. 
(d)  Permit issuance. The superintendent will evaluate the data furnished by the industrial user and may require additional information. After evaluation and acceptance of the data furnished, the superintendent may issue a wastewater discharge permit subject to terms and conditions provided herein. 
(e)  Permit modifications relative to categorical standards. As soon as possible, preferably within 90 days, after the promulgation of a federal categorical pretreatment standard, the wastewater discharge permit of the industrial users subject to such standards shall be revised to require compliance with such standard within the time frame prescribed by such standard. Where an industrial user, subject to a federal categorical pretreatment standard, has not previously submitted an application for a wastewater discharge permit as required by subsection (c) of this section, the industrial user shall apply for a wastewater discharge permit within 90 days after the promulgation of the applicable federal categorical pretreatment standard. 
(f)  Permit conditions. Wastewater discharge permits shall be expressly subject to all provisions of this division and all other applicable regulations, industrial user charges, and fees established by the city. Permits may contain the following as determined by the superintendent: 
(1)  The unit charge or schedule of charges and fees for the wastewater to be discharged to the POTW; 
(2)  Limits on the average and maximum wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(3)  Limits on average and maximum rate and time of discharge or requirements for flow regulations and equalization; 
(4)  Requirements for installation and maintenance of inspection and sampling facilities; 
(5)  Specifications for monitoring programs which may include sampling locations, frequency of sampling, number, types and standards for tests and reporting schedule; 
(6)  Compliance schedules; 
(7)  Requirements for submission of technical reports or discharge reports (See section 24-94.); 
(8)  Requirements for maintaining and retaining plant records relating to wastewater discharge as specified by the city, and affording city access thereto; 
(9)  Requirements for notification of the superintendent of any new introduction of wastewater constituents or any substantial change in the volume or character of the wastewater constituents being introduced into the POTW; 
(10)  Requirements for notification of accidental discharges as per section 24-87; 
(11)  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the superintendent to ensure compliance with this division. 
(g)  Permit duration. Permits shall be renewable as directed by the superintendent for a specified time period, not to exceed three years. Permits may be issued to expire on a specific date. The industrial user shall apply for permit reissuance a minimum of 90 days prior to the expiration of the user's permit. In the event that an application for permit reissuance was submitted and a new permit has not been issued at the time the existing permit expires, the existing permit expiration date will automatically extend until a new permit is issued. 
(h)  Permit transfer. Wastewater discharge permits are issued to a specific operation. A wastewater discharge permit shall not be reassigned or transferred or sold to a new owner, new user, different premises, or a new or changed operation without the approval of the city. Any succeeding owner or user shall also comply with the terms and conditions of the existing permit. 
(i)  Permit modification or revocation. Permits may be modified, revoked and reissued, or terminated for good causes including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  To incorporate any new or revised federal, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements; 
(2)  Material or substantial alterations or additions to the user's operation are made which are not covered in the effective permit; 
(3)  Failure of the industrial user to report significant changes in wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(4)  A change in any condition that requires either a temporary or permanent reduction or elimination of the authorized discharge; 
(5)  Information indicating that the permitted discharge poses a threat to the POTW, city personnel or the receiving waters; 
(6)  Violation of any terms or conditions of the user's wastewater discharge permit; 
(7)  It is found that the industrial user's wastewater discharge permit was obtained by misrepresentation or failure to disclose fully all relevant facts; 
(8)  Refusal of reasonable access to the industrial user's premises for the purpose of inspection or monitoring; or 
(9)  Upon request of the permittee (industrial user), provided such request does not create a violation of any existing policy, applicable requirements, standards, laws, or rules and regulations. The filing of a request by a permittee (industrial user) for a permit modification, revocation and reissuance, or termination, or a notification of planned changes or anticipated noncompliance, does not stay any permit condition. 
The industrial user shall be informed of any proposed changes in his permit at least 30 days prior to the effective date of the change. Any changes or new conditions in the permit shall include a reasonable time schedule for compliance. 
(j)  Permit violations. If sampling performed by the industrial user indicates a violation, the industrial user shall notify the superintendent within 24 hours of becoming aware of the violation. The industrial user shall also repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results of the repeat analysis to the superintendent within 30 days after becoming aware of the violation, except the industrial user is not required to resample if: 
(1)  The control authority performs sampling of the industrial user's discharge at a frequency of at least once per month. 
(2)  The control authority performs sampling of the industrial user's discharge between the time when the user performed its initial sampling and the time when the user receives the results of the initial sampling. 
(3)  The violation was the result of an infrequent batch discharge that occurs less frequently than once every 30 days and a repeat sampling would be of no value in confirming the nature or degree of the original violation. 
(Code 2017, § 27-70; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-93. - Holding tank waste haulers. 
(a)  Users discharging septic tank waste or any type of liquid waste from tank trucks or liquid haulers may be subject to the conditions of this division. 
(b)  Industrial process wastes or any other wastes that may be classified as hazardous wastes as defined by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (40 CFR 261) are prohibited. Such wastes shall not be delivered or sent to the POTW by truck, rail or dedicated pipe. 
(c)  These users shall be permitted to discharge waste to the POTW only if they have received permission to do so from the superintendent. Permission will be granted after these users have provided sufficient information to the superintendent which may include the following: 
(1)  The total volume of waste to be discharged on a weekly or monthly basis; 
(2)  The original sources of the waste; 
(3)  The components and quantities thereof of the various wastes which will be discharged including, but not limited to: BOD, COD, TSS, pH, oil and grease, toxic substances, and the restricted wastes listed in section 24-90, table 1; 
(4)  Their normal hours of operation. 
(d)  The superintendent will determine the hours that the user may discharge into the POTW. The superintendent will also determine the fee which the user will pay. The fee will be fair compensation to the city for the cost of treating the waste. This fee shall be in addition to any fees or civil penalties which may be charged as per section 24-90. 
(e)  The superintendent will prohibit the user from discharging certain wastes which may interfere with the operation or maintenance of the POTW. 
(f)  The superintendent shall have the right to inspect and sample wastes discharged from tank trucks or liquid haulers. The superintendent may require that these wastes not be discharged to the POTW if an inspection indicates that the waste may contain substances prohibited by this division. 
(g)  The introduction of any trucked or hauled wastes into the POTW except at discharge points designated by the superintendent is prohibited. 
(Code 2017, § 27-71; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-94. - Reporting requirements. 
(a)  Baseline monitoring reports. Within 180 days after the effective date of a categorical pretreatment standard, existing industrial users subject to such categorical pretreatment standards and currently discharging to or scheduled to discharge to the POTW shall be required to submit to the superintendent a report conforming to the requirements of 40 CFR 403.12(b). At least 90 days prior to commencement of discharge, new sources, and sources that become industrial users subsequent to the promulgation of an applicable categorical pretreatment standard, shall be required to submit to the superintendent a report conforming to the requirements of 40 CFR 403.12. 
(b)  90-day compliance reports. Within 90 days following the date for final compliance with applicable pretreatment standards or, in the case of a new source, following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the POTW, any industrial user subject to pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit to the superintendent a report indicating the nature and concentration of all pollutants in the discharge from the regulated process which are limited by pretreatment standards and requirements and the average and maximum daily flow for these process units in the industrial user's facility which are limited by such pretreatment standards or requirements. Reports must comply with requirements of 40 CFR 403.12. The report shall include a statement reviewed by an authorized representative of the industrial user and certified to by a qualified professional indicating whether the applicable pretreatment standards or requirements are being met on a consistent basis and, if not, what additional operation and maintenance and/or pretreatment is necessary to bring the user into compliance with the applicable pretreatment standards or requirements. 
(c)  Periodic reports. Any industrial user subject to a pretreatment standard or pretreatment requirement shall submit to the superintendent a report indicating the nature and concentration of pollutants in the effluent that are limited by that standard. The report shall also include a record of all daily flows that exceed the daily flow reported by the user on its wastewater discharge permit. The superintendent has the right to require as many reports as he deems necessary but reports must be submitted at least twice annually on dates determined by the superintendent. If a user is subject to mass limitations, the report shall also indicate the mass of regulated pollutants in the user's effluent. Reports must comply with requirements of 40 CFR 403.12. 
(d)  Notice of potential problems, including slug loading. All categorical and noncategorical industrial users shall notify the POTW immediately of all discharges that could cause problems to the POTW, including any slug loadings, as defined by this division section 24-81. 
(e)  Discharges of hazardous wastes notification. Pursuant to 40 CFR 403.12(p), all industrial users must notify, in writing, the POTW, the state and EPA of any discharge to the POTW that would be considered a hazardous waste if disposed of in a different manner. 
(1)  Industrial users are exempt from this requirement during a calendar month in which they discharge no more than 15 kilograms or 33 pounds of hazardous wastes, unless the wastes are acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e). 
(2)  Discharge of more than 33 pounds of nonacute hazardous wastes in a calendar month, or of any quantity of acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e), requires a one-time notification. 
(f)  Other reports. The superintendent may require other reports from industrial users as necessary, including, but not limited to, the reports required by 40 CFR 403.12. Reporting requirements will be made conditions of the wastewater discharge permit. 
(g)  Report retention. Any industrial user subject to the reporting requirements established in this section shall be required to retain for a minimum of three years the reports themselves and any records or supporting documents used in the compilation of those reports, and shall make such records or supporting documents available for inspection and copying by the superintendent. This period of retention shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation regarding the industrial user or the POTW or when requested by the superintendent. 
(h)  Signatory requirements. The reports required by subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section shall include the certification statement as set forth in 40 CFR 403.6(a)(2)(ii), and shall be signed as follows: 
(1)  By a responsible corporate officer, if the industrial user submitting the reports is a corporation. For the purpose of this subsection, a responsible corporate officer means a president, secretary, treasurer, or vice president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation. 
(2)  By the manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operating facilities, provided, the manager is authorized to make management decisions which govern the operation of the regulated facility including having the explicit or implicit duty of making major capital investment recommendations, and initiate and direct other comprehensive measures to ensure long-term environmental compliance with environmental laws and regulations; can ensure that the necessary systems are established or actions taken to gather complete and accurate information for control mechanism requirements; and where authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
(3)  By a general partner or proprietor if the industrial user submitting the reports required by subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section is a partnership, or sole proprietorship respectively. 
(4)  By the administrator, chairman, director, or principal executive responsible for operations at the facility if the industrial user submitting the reports is a government entity. 
(5)  By a duly authorized representative of the individual designated in the preceding subsection (h)(1), (2) or (3) of this section if: 
a.  The authorization is made in writing by the individual described in subsection (h)(1), (2), or (3) of this section: 
b.  The authorization specifies either an individual or a position having responsibility for the overall operation of the facility from which the industrial discharge originates, such as the position of plant manager, operator of a well or a well field superintendent, or a position of equivalent responsibility, or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company; and 
c.  The written authorization is submitted to the control authority. 
(6)  If an authorization under this subsection (h)(6) is no longer accurate because a different individual or position has responsibility for the overall operation of the facility, or overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, a new authorization satisfying the requirements of this subsection (h)(6) must be submitted to the control authority prior to or together with any reports to be signed by the authorized representative. 
(i)  Collection and analysis techniques. Collection and analysis of samples required by permit shall be performed in accordance with the techniques prescribed in 40 CFR 136 and amendments thereto. 
(j)  Reports. If an SIU monitors any pollutant more frequently than is required by their permit using procedures prescribed by 40 CFR 136, the results of this monitoring also shall be included in any required reports. 
(Code 2017, § 27-72; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-95. - Monitoring facilities. 
(a)  The city may require to be provided and operated at the industrial user's own expense, monitoring facilities to allow inspection, sampling, and flow measurement of the building sewer and/or internal drainage systems. The monitoring facility should normally be situated on the industrial user's premises, but the city may, when such a location would be impractical or cause undue hardship on the user, allow the facility to be constructed in the public street or sidewalk area and located so that it will not be obstructed by landscaping or parked vehicles. 
(b)  There shall be ample room in or near such sampling manhole or facility to allow accurate sampling and preparation of samples for analysis. The facility, sampling, and measuring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition at the expense of the industrial user. 
(c)  Whether constructed on public or private property, the sampling and monitoring facilities shall be provided in accordance with the city's requirements and all applicable local construction standards and specifications. Construction shall be completed within 90 days following written notification by the city. 
(Code 2017, § 27-73; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-96. - Inspection and sampling. 
(a)  The city shall inspect the facilities of any user to ascertain whether this division is being met and all requirements are being complied with. Persons or occupants of premises where wastewater is created or discharged shall allow the city or its representative ready access at all times to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, random sampling, records examination and copying, or in the performance of any of their duties. 
(b)  The city shall have the right to set up on the user's property such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling inspection, compliance monitoring and/or metering operations. Where an industrial user has security measures in force which would require proper identification and clearance before entry into its premises, the industrial user shall make necessary arrangements with its security guards so that upon presentation of suitable identification, personnel from the city will be permitted to enter, without delay, for the purposes of performing their specific responsibilities. 
(c)  The city has the right to randomly sample industry without notification of the sample taking. 
(Code 2017, § 27-74; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-97. - Pretreatment. 
(a)  Industrial users shall provide necessary wastewater treatment as required to comply with this division and shall achieve compliance with all federal categorical pretreatment standards within the time limitations as specified by the federal pretreatment regulations. The superintendent may require the development of a compliance schedule by an industrial user for the installation of technology required to meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. This schedule may include milestone dates and regular progress reports. 
(b)  Any facilities required to pretreat wastewater to a level acceptable to the superintendent shall be provided, operated, and maintained at the industrial user's expense. Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the superintendent for review, and shall be acceptable to the superintendent before construction of the facility. The review of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the industrial user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent acceptable to the superintendent under the provisions of this division. Any subsequent changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation, which affects quality or quantity of discharge, shall be reported to and be acceptable to the superintendent prior to the industrial user's initiation of the changes. 
(Code 2017, § 27-75; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-98. - Confidentiality of information. 
(a)  Information and data on a user obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications, permits and monitoring programs, and from inspections shall be available to the public or other governmental agency without restriction unless the user specifically requests and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the city that the release of such information would divulge information, processes or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets of the user. Data on wastewater constituents and characteristics will not be recognized as confidential information. 
(b)  When requested by the person furnishing a report, the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public but shall be made available to governmental agencies for uses related to this division, the national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) permit, state disposal system permit and/or the pretreatment program; provided, however, that such portions of a report shall be available for use by the state or any state agency in judicial review or enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. 
(Code 2017, § 27-76; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Sec. 24-99. - Falsifying information; tampering with monitoring device. 
(a)  Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation or certification in any application, records, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this division or wastewater discharge permit, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this division, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 30 days in jail. 
(b)  Industrial users may also be assessed civil penalties of up to $1,000.00 per day. 
(Code 2017, § 27-77; Ord. No. 2702, § 1, 1-25-2010) 
Secs. 24-100-24-126. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONNECTION CHARGES 

Sec. 24-127. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Interceptor or intercepting sewer means a main sewer. 
    Lateral sewer means a sewer which contributes sewage from a local area to a main sewer or outlet. 
    Main sewer means a sewer which serves as an outlet for two or more lateral sewers, and which is commonly referred to as an "intercepting sewer" or "interceptor," "outfall sewer" or "trunk sewer." 
    Sewer means structures designed, constructed and used for the purpose of controlling or carrying off waste or sanitary sewage. 
    Sewer systems are composed of the main sewers, sewage pumping stations, treatment and disposal plants, lateral sewers and sewer connections in easements, public streets or other rights-of-way for private property. 
    Total cost or cost of a sewer system includes the cost of engineering, preliminary reports, property valuations, estimates, plans, specifications, notices, legal services, acquisition of land, consequential damages or costs, easements, rights of way, construction, repair, supervision, inspection, testing, notices and publication, interest during construction and for not more than six months thereafter, and printing and sale of bonds. 
(Code 2017, § 27-96; Ord. No. 2269, § 1, 7-12-1999) 
Sec. 24-128. - Assessment. 
    All sanitary sewer systems constructed by the city, or constructed by a property owner or property developer for which the city incurs any costs, the total cost of which has not been assessed against the benefited properties by the levying of special assessments, shall be paid for by the owners of benefited properties before the sanitary sewer systems, or any part of parts thereof, are tapped or used, the connection charge to be determined as provided in this division. 
(Code 2017, § 27-97; Ord. No. 2269, § 2, 7-12-1999; Ord. No. 2322, §§ 1, 2, 1-22-2001) 
Sec. 24-129. - Report of costs; determination of charges. 
(a)  When a sanitary sewer line, consisting of one or more lateral sewers, main sewers, or interceptor sewers, is or has been constructed as described in section 24-128, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to report the total cost thereof to the city council. The city council shall then divide or prorate the total cost thereof among the properties benefited thereby and shall adopt an ordinance setting forth charges against respective properties which connect into the sanitary sewer line. Such ordinance shall only be adopted after 20 days' notice published in accordance with the requirements of state law, and only after a public hearing thereon. 
(b)  The tapping, use or connection charges shall be paid prior to or at the time of minor or preliminary plat approval by the city, the charges to be equal in value to the total cost, including the construction costs, incurred by the city made by the advance installation of the sewer line required for the development of the property. The property owner or the property developer will be responsible at a minimum for the cost of an eight-inch sewer line installation, or for a greater charge if the property's future development necessitates a larger size sewer line. When sewer lines are installed to serve an entire subbasin, the total cost thereof shall be prorated among the benefited properties, regardless of the sewer line sizing. 
(Code 2017, § 27-98; Ord. No. 2269, § 3, 7-12-1999) 
Secs. 24-130-24-156. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CHERRYWOOD INTERCEPTOR SEWER DISTRICT 

Sec. 24-157. - Establishment of district; definition. 
    There is hereby established the Cherrywood Interceptor Sewer District, which shall be referred to in this division as the district. The district consists of all property served and benefited by the Cherrywood Interceptor Sewer, which property is legally described in section 24-158. 
(Code 2017, § 27-99; Ord. No. 2276, § 1, 9-13-1999) 
Sec. 24-158. - Description of benefited properties. 
    The property served and benefited by the district consists of 688.27 acres of property legally described as follows: 
(1)  Southeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 of section 9, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M. 
(2)  The northeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 of section 9, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M., except that part thereof conveyed to the city for street purposes in Book 551 of Land Deeds at page 763, and also except that part thereof lying north of a line extending from a point on the west line of said section 9 which is 239.02 feet south of the northwest corner of the northeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 of said section 9, to a point on the west right-of-way line of Union Road which is 238.99 feet south of the north line of the northeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 of said section 9. 
(3)  The west 985 feet of the south 465 feet of the southwest 1/4 of the southwest 1/4 of section 10, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M. 
(4)  Northeast 1/4 of the northeast 1/4 of section 16, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M. 
(5)  East 1/2 of the southeast 1/4 of the northeast 1/4 of section 16, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M. 
(6)  Northwest 1/4 of section 15, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M. 
(7)  The north 660 feet of the northwest 1/4 of the southwest 1/4 of section 15, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M.

(Code 2017, § 27-100; Ord. No. 2276, § 1, 9-13-1999; Ord. No. 2389, § 1, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 24-159. - Description of excluded properties. 
    Certain property lying within the district was either previously assessed a portion of the costs of the Cherrywood Interceptor Sewer, or is appropriately exempted from such assessment by reason of its owner having made certain stormwater detention improvements which are of public benefit, at a cost greater than the amount of such assessment. These properties, which are referred to as the excluded properties, consist of 55.15 acres, and are exempt from the sewer connection charge imposed by this division. The excluded properties are legally described as follows: 
(1)  Lots 1 through 56, inclusive, in Cherrywood Acres in Black Hawk County, Iowa (now in the city of Cedar Falls, Iowa). 
(2)  That part of the south 1/2 of the northeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 except the north 260 feet of the south 1802.40 feet of the east 837.69 feet of section 9, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M., described as follows: Commencing at a point on the east line of said section which is 1542.40 feet north of the southeast corner of said section, thence west 263 feet; thence south at right angles 216.25 feet; thence east at right angles 263 feet; thence north along the east line of said section 216.25 feet to the point of beginning, except street right-of-way. 
(3)  That part of the northeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 of section 9, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M., described as follows: Commencing at a point on the east line of said section which is 1542.40 feet north of the southeast corner of said section; thence west at right angles 263 feet; thence north at right angles 260 feet; thence east at right angles 263 feet to the east line of said section; thence south along the east line of said section 260 feet to the point of beginning, except street right-of-way. 
(4)  Beginning at a point 232.4 feet east of the northwest corner of the northeast 1/4 of the northeast 1/4 of section 16, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M.; thence east 260.0 feet along the north line of said section; thence south 400.0 feet; thence west 260.0 feet; thence north 400.0 feet to the point of beginning, except street right-of-way. 
(5)  The west 232.4 feet of the north 400 feet of the northeast 1/4 of the northeast 1/4 of Section 16, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th P.M., in the City of Cedar Falls, Iowa, except street right-of-way. 
(6)  The south 1/2 of the northeast 1/4 of the southeast 1/4 of section 9, Township 89 north, Range 14 west of the 5th Principal Meridian in the city of Cedar Falls, Black Hawk County, Iowa, except that part thereof described as follows: Commencing at a point on the east line of said section which is 1542.40 feet north of the southeast corner of said section, thence west 263 feet; thence south at right angles 216.25 feet; thence east at right angles 263 feet; thence north along the east line of said section 216.25 feet to the point of beginning, except street right-of-way; and also except that part thereof described as follows: Commencing at a point on the east line of said section which is 1542.40 feet north of the southeast corner of said section; thence west at right angles 263 feet; thence north at right angles 260 feet; thence east at right angles 263 feet to the east line of said section; thence south along the east line of said section 260 feet to the point of beginning, except street right-of-way. 
(Code 2017, § 27-101; Ord. No. 2276, § 1, 9-13-1999; Ord. No. 2389, § 2, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 24-160. - Imposition of sewer connection charge. 
    There is hereby imposed on each property lying within the district which is not an excluded property a sewer connection charge of $294.63 per acre, based upon the area or size of each property. The sewer connection charge shall be payable in cash, and shall be in addition to all other fees or charges imposed by the city. 
(Code 2017, § 27-102; Ord. No. 2276, § 1, 9-13-1999) 
Sec. 24-161. - Timing of payment of sewer connection charge. 
    The owner of every property for which a sewer connection charge is imposed by this division shall pay the sewer connection charge as follows: 
(1)  Charges for existing residential property. Residential property located within the district which is not an excluded property and which is currently serviced by a septic tank shall pay a sewer connection charge to the city at the time that the septic tank serving the residential property falis, or a sanitary sewer connection is requested by the subject property owner, or is ordered by the city, whichever occurs first. 
(2)  Charges for residential plats. Each owner or developer of property which lies within the district and which is not an excluded property, and who files a minor plat or a preliminary plat shall pay a sewer connection charge to the city prior to or at the time of minor plat or preliminary plat approval by the city. This subsection shall be applicable to all minor plats and preliminary plats of any property lying within the district filed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived. 
(3)  Other property owners. Any owner of any other property lying within the district which is not an excluded property shall pay a sewer connection charge to the city at such time as the owner connects the property to the city sewer system. 
(Code 2017, § 27-103; Ord. No. 2276, § 1, 9-13-1999) 
Secs. 24-162-24-190. - Reserved.
